questions.text: Among the following bones, which one is the skeletal derivative of the 2nd pharyngeal arch?
questions.solution:
Option D: Stapes

  • Stapes come from the second arch (Reichert's cartilage - secondary mesenchyme)
  • Other structures from the 2nd arch are the Styloid process, Stylohyoid ligament, Lesser horn and upper part of the body of the hyoid bone

Option A: Malleus

  • Malleus, Maxilla, and Incus come from 1st arch (Meckel cartilage - secondary mesenchyme)
  • Other structures from 1st arch are Mandible (GT), Anterior ligament of malleus and Sphenomandibular ligament

Option B: Maxilla

  • Malleus, Maxilla and Incus come from 1st arch (Meckel cartilage - secondary mesenchyme)
  • Other structures from 1st arch are Mandible (GT), Anterior ligament of malleus and Sphenomandibular ligament

Option C: Incus

  • Malleus, Maxilla and Incus come from 1st arch (Meckel cartilage - secondary mesenchyme)
  • Other structures from 1st arch are Mandible (GT), Anterior ligament of malleus and Sphenomandibular ligament

questions.text: 11-year-old girl with fever, sore throat, and bilateral swellings between palatoglossal and palatopharyngeal folds, which lymph nodes should be evaluated to assess the initial spread of infection from the affected lymphoid tissue?
questions.solution:
Option D: Jugulodigastric

  • This is a case of tonsillitis involving the jugulodigastric lymph node.
  • The Jugulodigastric lymph nodes are deep cervical lymph nodes.
  • Deep cervical lymph nodes are related to the internal jugular vein.
  • The jugulodigastric lymph nodes drain lymph from the tonsils.
  • The jugulodigastric lymph node (tonsillar lymph node) is located near the angle of the mandible where the posterior belly of digastric muscle crosses the internal jugular vein. It receives lymph from the tongue and pharynx and is commonly enlarged with tonsillitis.

Option A: Submental

  • The submental lymph nodes are superficial cervical lymph nodes. They drain lymph from the submental region.
  • The apex of the tongue, frenulum, and central part of the lower lip drain into submental lymph nodes that can be palpated, when enlarged, in the submental triangle.

Option B: Submandibular

  • The submandibular lymph nodes are superficial cervical lymph nodes draining lymph from the submandibular region.
  • Most of the skin of the face, lateral part of the body of the tongue, and the floor of the mouth drain into the submandibular lymph nodes. These lymph nodes lie superficial to the submandibular gland and, when enlarged, can be palpated along the inferior border of the body of the mandible.

Option C: Parotid

  • The parotid lymph nodes are also a part of superficial cervical lymph nodes draining lymph from the parotid area.
  • They are located on the capsule of the parotid gland and drain the lateral aspect of the face, scalp, and eyelids.

questions.text: Which of the following structures forms the posterior boundary of the carotid triangle?
questions.solution:
Option D: Sternocleidomastoid

  • The neck is divided into anterior and posterior triangles by the Sternocleidomastoid muscle. The anterior triangle is further divided into four triangles.
  1. Carotid Triangle
  2. Submental Triangle
  3. Submandibular Triangle
  4. The muscular triangle is also known as the infrahyoid triangle

Boundaries of Carotid Triangle:

  • Superior: Stylohyoid and posterior belly of digastric
  • Anterior: Superior belly of omohyoid
  • Posterior: Anterior margin of sternocleidomastoid muscle

Contents of Carotid Triangle:

  • The common carotid artery divides into internal and external carotid arteries within the carotid triangle
  • Internal jugular vein
  • Hypoglossal Nerve
  • Vagus nerve 
  • Carotid Sinus    

Its floor is formed by

  • Hyoglossus
  • Thyrohyoid membrane
  • Medial and inferior constrictor muscles.

 

Option A: Superior belly of the omohyoid

  • The superior belly of the omohyoid forms the anterior border of the carotid triangle.

Option B: Posterior belly of digastric

  • The posterior belly of the digastric forms the superior border of the carotid triangle.
  • The posterior belly of the digastric is attached to the hyoid bone & mastoid process.

Option C: Mylohyoid Muscle

  • The Mylohyoid muscle is not a part of the carotid triangle
  • It extends between the mandible and hyoid bone and is present on the floor of the Digastric Triangle.

questions.text:
A 32-year-old male presents with weakness on the left side of the face, inability to close his left eye, drooping of the mouth, and drooling of saliva. There is no wrinkling on the left side of the forehead. The rest of the examination findings are shown below.



The structure damaged in the given condition is responsible for all of the following except?
questions.solution:
Option C: Parotid gland secretion

  • The condition given here is Bell's palsy, i.e., lower motor neuron lesion of the Facial Nerve.
  • Parasympathetic innervation of the parotid gland begins with the glossopharyngeal nerve, which synapses in the otic ganglion. The otic ganglion then provides parasympathetic fibers to the parotid gland through an auriculotemporal nerve. This parasympathetic pathway controls the secretions of the parotid gland.
  • On the other hand, the auriculotemporal nerve provides sensory innervation to the gland, whereas the great auricular nerve provides sensory innervation to the fascia.

Option A: Taste sensation of anterior 2/3rd tongue

  • Taste from the anterior 2/3rd of the tongue is carried by the chorda tympani nerve, a branch of the facial nerve to the nucleus tractus solitarius.

Option B: Lacrimal gland secretion

  • The facial nerve controls the secretions of the lacrimal gland through the greater petrosal Nerve.

Option D: Platysma contraction

  • The platysma is supplied by one of the five terminal branches of the facial nerve called the cervical nerve. Therefore, contractions of platysma will be affected by Bell's Palsy.

questions.text: A 33-year-old male who underwent surgery for mandibular condyle injury following a road traffic accident complains of sweating on the face when eating. Which nerve could have been iatrogenically injured to cause this symptom?
questions.solution:
Option D: Auriculo-temporal Nerve

  • The patient’s complaint of gustatory sweating (sweating in response to gustatory stimulation) after surgery in the parotid gland vicinity is consistent with Frey's syndrome, also known as Auriculotemporal syndrome.
  • The auriculo-temporal nerve, a branch of the mandibular (V3) part of the trigeminal nerve, carries parasympathetic secretomotor fibers to the parotid gland.
  • After parotidectomy or another surgery in the vicinity of the parotid gland, there may be damage and subsequent regeneration of secretomotor fibers in the auriculotemporal nerve.
  • This regeneration of nerve endings is misdirected into sweat glands.
  • Thus, whenever the patient thinks of food or smells or chews food, there would be stimulation of sweat glands and hyperemia, resulting in redness and sweating in front of the ear on the cheek.
  • An overview of the misalignment of the nerve branches in the case of Frey's syndrome is shown as follows:

 

Option A: Glosso-pharyngeal Nerve

  • The glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX) supplies the carotid body and carotid sinus, posterior 1/3rd of the tongue, tonsils, and stylopharyngeus muscle and gives a branch to the tympanic plexus in the middle ear.
  • It does not supply to the parotid gland or play any role in the auriculotemporal syndrome.

Option B: Chorda Tympani Nerve

  • Chorda tympani is a sensory branch of the facial nerve (CN VII).
    • It carries taste sensations from the anterior two-thirds of the tongue.
    • It can get damaged during dental or inner ear surgical procedures and can lead to taste disturbances.
    • It does not participate in anomalous connections leading to gustatory sweating.

Option C: Facial Nerve

  • The facial nerve (CN VII) emerges from the pons of the brainstem, travels through the facial canal medial to the medial wall of the inner ear, and exits the skull through the stylomastoid foramen.
  • It supplies motor innervation to the muscles of the facial expression.
  • Sensory branches of the facial nerve carry taste sensations from the anterior two-thirds of the tongue.
  • It does not participate in abnormal connection formation in gustatory sweating.

questions.text: Which muscle is responsible for the vocal cord's abduction?
questions.solution:
Option C: Posterior cricoarytenoid muscle

  • The only abductor of the vocal cords is the posterior cricoarytenoid.
  • It is essential in coughing, speaking, sniffing, and respiration.
  • As it is the only muscle that opens the vocal cords. Its paralysis can cause asphyxia.

Option A: Lateral cricoarytenoid muscle

  • Lateral cricoarytenoid muscle and Interarytenoid muscle are adductors of the vocal cords.

Option B: Vocalis muscle

  • Vocalis can tense the vocal cords and plays a role in changing the pitch of voice. It does not abduct the vocal cords.

Option D: Cricothyroid muscle

  • Cricothyroid muscle tenses the vocal cords.

questions.text: Which of the following parts of the vertebral canal will show secondary curves with posterior concavities?
questions.solution:
Option A: Cervical

  • At 2 months (holding of the neck)cervical lordosis is present.
  • Cervical lordosis is due to neck holding.
  • Concave posteriorly.
  • The concavities align the center of gravity of the body through the pelvis, thereby contracting the weight of the thoracoabdominal viscera, allowing the head to balance on top of the vertebral column and enabling upright posture.
  • However, in initial development, the fetal vertebral column has only one continuous anterior concavity.
  • As the development proceeds, the lumbosacral angle appears at the junction of the L5 and S1 vertebrae, forming 2 anterior concave curves.
  • After birth, the cervical curve forms with the child raising their head and keeping it poised on the vertebral column.

Option A: Thoracic

  • Because thoracic vertebrae have anterior concavities.

Option B: Sacral.

  • Because sacral vertebrae have anterior concavities.

Option D: Coccyx

  • Because the coccyx has anterior concavities.

questions.text: The hepatic sinusoids correspond to the capillary bed of the Liver and represent the segment of the microcirculation in which the supply of nutrients and removal of metabolic products by hepatocytes takes place. Which one of the following statements concerning liver sinusoids is true?

choices.text: They receive bile from the hepatocytes
They are lined by nonfenestrated endothelial cells
Space of Disse is located between sinusoidal cells and hepatocytes

questions.solution:
Option D: Space of Disse is located between sinusoidal cells and hepatocytes

Liver sinusoids:

  • Convey blood to the central vein.
  • Their endothelial cells are fenestrated,
  • Material from the sinusoids may enter the space of Disse through the fenestrae, where hepatocytes may endocytose it.
  • The space of Disse houses Ito cells (fat-storing cells).
  • Because bile is the exocrine secretion of hepatocytes, it does not enter the sinusoids.

Option A: Their lining includes Ito cells:

  • The space of Disse houses Ito cells
  • They do not receive bile from the hepatocytes
  • They are lined by fenestrated endothelial cells
  • Space of Disse is located between sinusoidal cells and hepatocytes

Option B: They receive bile from the hepatocytes

  • They do not receive bile from the hepatocytes

Option C: They are lined by nonfenestrated endothelial cells

  • They are lined by fenestrated endothelial cells

questions.text: The surgeon performs an open laparotomy to address carcinoma of the colon in a 50-year-old patient. During the procedure, the surgeon preserves the major vein of the abdomen. Which of the following statements regarding this patient's vein, responsible for carrying blood from the gut into the liver, are incorrect?

choices.text: Formed behind the neck of the pancreas
The bile duct lies anterior and right to it
The gastroduodenal artery lies to the right and anterior to it
Ascends behind the 2nd part of the duodenum

questions.solution:
Option D: Ascends behind the 2nd part of the duodenum

  • The portal vein brings blood from the gut into the liver and aids nutrient absorption and utilization.
  • It is formed behind the neck of the pancreas.
  • The portal vein ascends behind the first part of the duodenum
  • The bile duct lies right and anterior to it, and the Gastroduodenal artery lies to the left and anterior to it

Option A: Formed behind the neck of the pancreas

  • The portal vein brings blood from the gut into the liver and aids nutrient absorption and utilization.
  • It is formed behind the neck of the pancreas.
  • The portal vein ascends behind the first part of the duodenum
  • The bile duct lies right and anterior to it, and the Gastroduodenal artery lies to the left and anterior to it

Option B: The bile duct lies anterior and right to it

  • The portal vein brings blood from the gut into the liver and aids nutrient absorption and utilization.
  • It is formed behind the neck of the pancreas.
  • The portal vein ascends behind the first part of the duodenum
  • The bile duct lies right and anterior to it, and the Gastroduodenal artery lies to the left and anterior to it

Option C: Gastroduodenal artery lies to the left and anterior to it

  • The portal vein brings blood from the gut into the liver and aids nutrient absorption and utilization.
  • It is formed behind the neck of the pancreas.
  • The portal vein ascends behind the first part of the duodenum
  • The bile duct lies right and anterior to it, and the Gastroduodenal artery lies to the left and anterior to it

questions.text: A 7-year-old girl is brought to the outpatient department physician for intermittent fevers and painful swelling of the left ankle for 2 weeks. She has no history of trauma to the ankle. She has a history of sickle cell disease. On physical examination, she is hypertensive with a blood pressure of 145/71 mmHg, and a palpable enlarged spleen and liver are found. Regarding spleen anatomy, which of the following correctly describes the spleen?

choices.text: Has a notch on the anterior border
Spleen has no relation to the stomach

questions.solution:
Option A: Has a notch on the anterior border

  • The notched border of the spleen is the anterior border; it is said that this allows an enlarged spleen to be identified during abdominal examination.
  • The spleen lies under the 9th to 11th ribs.

Option B: largest organ in the abdomen

  • The liver is the largest solid organ in the abdominal cavity.

Option C: Spleen is retroperitoneal

  • The spleen is completely enclosed in the peritoneum, derived from the dorsal mesogastrium.
  • The spleen lies deep in the rib cage, which is non-palpable but in some slender individuals.
  • Histologically it has two regions red and white pulp.

Option D: Spleen has no relation to the stomach

  • The left kidney and stomach are both direct relations of the spleen. It is, therefore, at risk of left nephrectomy.
  • Mesodermal origin within dorsal mesentery posterior to the stomach.
  • It has blood supply from the foregut (celiac trunk).

questions.text: CORRECT sequence of arterial blood flow in uterus is:
questions.solution: -ARBS: Arcuate → Radial → Basal and Spiral

questions.text: A primigravida at 40 weeks of gestation presents with labour pains for half an hour. During a spontaneous vaginal delivery complicated by obstructed labour, an episiotomy is performed, and forceps are used. Examination reveals a second-degree tear involving a crack in the upper boundary of the superficial perineal space. Which structure is likely damaged?
questions.solution:
Option D: Perineal membrane

  • The perineum is damaged during childbirth, as shown in the woman in the clinical scenario above.
  • Risk factors include primigravida, obstructed labour, forceps delivery and episiotomy.
  • The main structure to be torn is the perineal body that supports the pelvic floor and is attached to the perineal membrane. It is the central point of the perineum.
  • The perineum is the lower part of the pelvic cavity. It is bounded anteriorly by the symphysis pubis, posteriorly by the tip of the coccyx and laterally by the ischial tuberosities.
  • The urogenital diaphragm is a triangular musculofascial diaphragm situated in the anterior part of the perineum. It fills in the gap of the pubic arch.
    • It is formed by the sphincter urethrae and the deep, transverse perineal muscles, which are enclosed between the superior and an inferior layer of the fascia of the urogenital diaphragm.
    • The inferior layer of the fascia is referred to as the perineal membrane.
  • The perineal membrane is perforated by the urethra in both sexes and the vagina in the females.
  • The perineal body and the ischial pubic ramus to which it attaches to provide a foundation for the erectile bodies of the external genitalia, the penis in males and the vulva in females, which are the superior superficial features of the triangle.
  • It divides the urogenital diaphragm into superficial and deep perineal pouches.
  • The perineal membrane forms the upper boundary of the superficial perineal space.

 

  • The diagram below demonstrates the perineum and the pelvic floor muscle. It shows the structure of the perineal membrane and its relations and attachments.

 

Option A: Pelvic diaphragm

  • The pelvic diaphragm is a basin-shaped muscular tissue that forms the inferior border of the abdominopelvic cavity. It isolates the pelvic cavity from the perineum and supports the abdominopelvic viscera.
  • The pelvic diaphragm has three components: levator ani muscles, coccygeus muscle, and fascia surrounding these muscles.
  • It extends from the symphysis pubis to the coccyx and from one lateral wall side to another.

Option B: Colles’ fascia

  • The abdominal fascia is continuous with the perineal fascia.
  • The perineal fascia is divided into two components: the deep fascia and the superficial fascia.
  • The superficial fascia is composed of two layers: superficial and deep layer.
    • The deep layer is known as the Colles’ fascia.
  • The deep membranous layer (Colles fascia) is attached posteriorly to the posterior border of the urogenital diaphragm, laterally to the margins of the public arch, and anteriorly, it is continuous with the membranous layer of the anterior abdominal wall (Scarpa’s fascia).

Option C: Superficial perineal fascia

  • The superficial perineal fascia has two layers: a superficial fatty layer and a deep membranous layer.
    • The superficial fatty layer (basics of Camper) extends to labia majora in females. In males, it is replaced by the dartos muscle in the scrotum. It is continuous with the fat of the ischiorectal fossa and the superficial fascia of the thighs.
    • The deep membranous layer (Colles’ fascia)

questions.text: A 1-month-old newborn is brought to the outpatient department by his mother. She is worried about the yellowing of his skin, poor weight gain and foul-smelling, pale, almost white stools. The laboratory investigations show conjugated hyperbilirubinemia, intrahepatic cholestasis, and high alkaline phosphatase. His liver biopsy is planned. The picture of the liver biopsy of the baby is shown in the image below. What is the suspected diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option A: Alpha-1 Antitrypsin deficiency

  • The above-given case is alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency. A liver biopsy showing eosinophilic, PAS-positive cytoplasmic granules/globules in an infant presenting with jaundice, clay-coloured stools leading to conjugated hyperbilirubinemia and raised alkaline phosphatase is highly suggestive of a diagnosis of Alpha-1 Antitrypsin deficiency.
  • It is a mostly autosomal dominant condition.
  • The patient can present with the following:
    • Jaundice
    • Foul-smelling, pale stools
    • Vomiting or reflux
    • Deranged LFTs
    • Itching
    • Loss of appetite
    • Rarely enlarged liver.

  • The incidence of liver disease increases with age.

  • In the first two decades, major symptoms are due to liver disease, and the pulmonary manifestations appear later.

  • Diagnosis can be made on a simple blood test or liver biopsy.
  • The patient may need a liver transplant if liver fibrosis or cirrhosis has started.

 

Option B: Congenital hepatic fibrosis  

  • A diagnosis of congenital hepatic fibrosis can be made only based on a liver biopsy.
  • The most common classical histological findings of this disease are ductal destruction and hepatic fibrosis with nodular formation to varying degrees and this fibrosis may become extensive as the disease progresses.

Option C: Extrahepatic biliary atresia

 

  • This disorder is characterised by the destruction or absence of all or a portion of the bile duct that lies outside the liver.
  • Its histological features are lobular cholestasis, bile ductular proliferation and occasional bile plugs.
  • They may have vacuoles or lymphocytes. The late presentation shows fibrosis or cirrhosis of the liver.

 

Option D: Ductal plate defect:

  • Ductal plate defects are a group of congenital fibrocystic liver diseases which occur due to any retardation in the ductal plate growth at any of the stages of embryogenesis
  • This leads to various biliary malformations, cysts, hamartomas and congenital hepatic fibrosis.

questions.text: A preterm jaundiced newborn is born to a mother with a history of diabetes and hypertension. The mother also gave an account of jaundice in her second trimester. She also has a previous record of jaundice during both last pregnancies. A baby has a disorder of bile transport that led mild conjugated hyperbilirubinemia. In which of the following is this seen?
questions.solution:
Option C: Dubin johnson syndrome

  • Conjugated hyperbilirubinemia in infancy is seen in Dubin-Johnson syndrome.
  • It is an autosomal recessive disorder.
  • It results from impaired hepatic excretion of bilirubin.
  • It causes conjugated hyperbilirubinemia.
  • Signs and Symptoms include:
    • Jaundice
    • Abnormal urine colour
    • Biliary tract abnormality

Option A: Gilbert syndrome

 

  • It is a condition in which the liver doesn't properly process bilirubin.
  • It is an inherited genetic condition, an autosomal recessive pattern.
  • Patients mostly have elevated unconjugated bilirubin.

Option B: Crigler Najjar syndrome

  • It is an autosomal recessive disorder in which UDP-GT activity is absent.
  • Patients develop severe unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia.
  • If untreated, death occurs by 28-24months of age.

Option D: erythroblastosis fetalis

 

  • It causes hemolytic anaemia in newborns.
  • There is a transplacental transmission of maternal antibodies to fetal RBCs.
  • The main cause is an incompatibility between maternal and fetal blood groups.

questions.text: Four patients are admitted to the paediatric ward. Patient A has Anderson's disease. Patient B has Her's disease. Patient C has Scheie's syndrome, and patient D has Tarui's disease. Which of the following diseases is not a glycogen storage disease?
questions.solution:
Option C: Scheie's disease

Types of Mucopolysaccharidosis (MPS):

Type

Name

Enzyme deficient

I

Hurler/Scheie

α-L-Iduronidase

II

Hunter

Iduronate sulfate sulfatase

III

Sanifilippo

Heparan S sulfamidase

IV

Morquio

N-acetyl galactosamine sulfate sulfatase

VI

Maroteaux-Lamy

Aryl sulfatase B

VII

Sly

β glucuronidase

 

  • Scheie syndrome is a rare hereditary lysosomal storage disorder, not a glycogen storage disease.
  • It is caused by a lack of the enzyme iduronidase, which results in the body's accumulation of glycosaminoglycans (GAGs). It is the mildest variant of mucopolysaccharidosis type I; the most severe subtype is Hurler Syndrome.
  • Scheie syndrome is also characterised by hernia, coarse facial characteristics, joint contracture, bone abnormalities, hepatomegaly, and corneal clouding.

Option A: Anderson's disease

  • Andersen disease is a type IV glycogen storage disease caused by a branching enzyme deficiency that generates α-1,6-glucosidic branches.
  • The disease commonly presents in early infancy with hepatosplenomegaly and failure to thrive. Other findings include muscular weakness, hypotonia, infantile cirrhosis, cardiomyopathy and early childhood death.

Option B: Her's disease

  • Glycogen storage disease type VI (GSD VI) is a glycogen storage disorder caused by a lack of glycogen phosphorylase in the liver or other components of the related phosphorylase cascade system. It is sometimes referred to as "Hers' disease."

Option D: Tarui's disease

  • Tarui's illness is an inborn error of glycogen metabolism characterised by phosphofructokinase deficiency in the muscles and aberrant glycogen accumulation in muscle tissues. Tarui illness often appears as exercise intolerance and anaemia in children.

questions.text: A 35-year-old female primigravida POG 42 weeks presents in the emergency department with pain. She was taken to the labour room, and normal vaginal delivery was done. Following the birth of the baby, the paediatrician takes charge of the baby and begins the resuscitation process in order to clear the airway for the baby to be able to breathe. Suction pressure should not exceed what mm of Hg while suctioning the airway of neonates during neonatal resuscitation?
questions.solution:
Option C: 100 mm

  • Most children born with C-sections may have trouble breathing.
  • The suctioning of the newborn baby is very important.
  • It is the procedure to remove the mucous and fluids from the nose, mouth, and throat by using a nasogastric tube or a catheter.
  • Suction pressure should be kept nearby 80 mm Hg or 100 cm H2O
  • It should not be more than 100 mm Hg or 130 cm H2O.

​​​​​​​Option A: 50 mm

  • Suctioning of mucous should be done gently and slowly.
  • 50 mm suctioning pressure is very low, so it can not clear the airways.

Option B: 140 mm

  • The suctioning pressure should be maintained at 80-100 mmHg.
  • The suctioning pressure of 140 mmHg is very high; it can damage the mucous membrane.

Option D: 130 mm

  • The pressure of 130 is so high for the mucous membrane of newborn babies, so it can easily damage the mucous membrane.
  • The suctioning pressure should not exceed 80-100 mmHg.

questions.text: An IV drug abuser presents you with complaints of fever, malaise and weight loss for the last 3-4 months. Lab investigations show leukopenia, and he tests positive for HIV. Chest X-ray is clear. You advise him to take antiretroviral drugs. Five days after starting the antiretroviral therapy, the patient is brought to the hospital with dyspnea and new-onset lymphadenopathy. Chest X-ray shows pulmonary infiltrates. What is the cause of the worsening symptoms of this patient?
questions.solution:
Option C:  Immune reconstitution inflammatory syndrome

  • Immune reconstitution syndrome (IRIS) is characterized by an excessive inflammatory response from the recovered immune system to subclinical or new-onset opportunistic infections.

  • Immune reconstitution inflammatory response develops within the first week of starting antiretroviral therapy.

  • In patients with immune reconstitution, inflammatory response develops within the first week of starting antiretroviral therapy.

  • This syndrome is commonly observed in patients with progressive disease and severe CD4+ T-lymphocyte depletion.

  • Non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs are used to alleviate the inflammatory surge seen in this syndrome.

Option A: HIV-related hyper-reactivity syndrome

  •  The HIV-related hyper-reactivity syndrome is characterized by hyper-responsiveness of the respiratory tract.

  • This syndrome results in bronchoconstriction and respiratory distress.

  • Pulmonary function tests show an obstructive pattern of respiratory disease.

Option B: Jarisch-herxheimer reaction

  • Jarisch-herxheimer reaction occurs after giving penicillin to syphilis patients.

  • This reaction manifests 1-3 hours after administering the first dose of antibiotics.

  • Lipoproteins released by lysis of Treponema pallidum cause Jarisch-herxheimer reaction.

  • This reaction manifests as fever, chills, rigour, hypotension, headache, tachycardia, hyperventilation, flushing, and myalgia.

Option D: Interstitial pneumonitis

  • Interstitial pneumonitis is due to the inflammation of the lung interstitium.

  • Interstitial pneumonitis is the most common adverse effect of amiodarone therapy.

  • Amiodarone causes interstitial pneumonitis 2-3 months after starting therapy.

  • Amiodarone is used as an anti-arrhythmic.

questions.text: A baby is born to a 30-year-old HIV-positive woman. The baby is healthy and has no abnormal physical or laboratory examination findings. The mother and baby are discharged with advice to start giving co-trimoxazole to the baby after 4 weeks. Which of the following statements is correct about the prophylaxis of co-trimoxazole in HIV patients?

choices.text: Can be administered in all asymptomatic HIV-infected children younger than 5 years of age, irrespective of CD4
Can be administered in all HIV-exposed infants after HIV infection is ruled out
Can be given to all HIV-infected infants less than 1 year ago, according to CD4 counts
Can be started in HIV-exposed infants before the diagnosis of HIV is confirmed

questions.solution:
Option D: Can be started in HIV-exposed infants before the diagnosis of HIV is confirmed

  • Co-trimoxazole is a combination of sulfamethoxazole and trimethoprim.

  • It is given as a prophylaxis against infections in confirmed and potential HIV patients.

  • Co-trimoxazole is started as prophylaxis against pneumocystis pneumoniae in babies born to HIV-positive mothers.

  • Prophylaxis can be started even before the confirmation of HIV infection in the baby.

  • Co-trimoxazole prophylaxis is recommended for all HIV - exposed infants starting at 4-6 weeks of age (or at the first encounter with the health care system) and continued until HIV infection can be excluded.

Option A: Can be administered in all asymptomatic HIV-infected children younger than 5 years of age, irrespective of CD4

  • Co-trimoxazole prophylaxis is given to all HIV-positive children younger than 5 years, irrespective of CD4 count or clinical stage.

  • Co-trimoxazole prophylaxis can be discontinued for clinically stable children older than 5 years of age with a CD4 count of more than 350 cells/mm3.

Option B: Can be administered in all HIV-exposed infants after HIV infection is ruled out

  • HIV exposure occurs intranatally or through breastfeeding.

  • Co-trimoxazole prophylaxis reduces mortality and morbidity from opportunistic infections during infancy and early childhood.

  • Prophylaxis should be continued until HIV infection is excluded by antibody testing (beyond 18 months of age) or virological testing (beyond 18 months of age) at least 6 weeks after cessation of breastfeeding.

Option C: Can be given to all HIV-infected infants less than 1 year ago, according to CD4 counts

  • All HIV-exposed or infected infants less than 1 year of age are given co-trimoxazole prophylaxis irrespective of CD4 counts and clinical symptoms.

  • Cotrimoxazole is recommended for HIV-exposed breastfeeding children of all ages.

  • After one year, prophylaxis treatment with co-trimoxazole is given only to symptomatic children or those with CD4 counts less than 350 cells/mm3.

questions.text: A 45-day-old infant develops icterus, and symptoms and signs of acute liver failure appear two days later. The child is found to be positive for HbsAg. The mother is also an HBsAg carrier. Which of the following is the mother's hepatitis B serological profile?
questions.solution:
Option B: HbsAg and HbeAg positivity

  • A most important risk factor that determines the perinatal transmission of Hepatitis B is HBeAg
  • HBsAg carrier mothers who are HBeAg positive almost invariably (> 90%) transfer infection to their offspring
  • The risk of transmission is greatest if the mother is:
  1. HbeAg positive  
  2. High maternal HBV viral load
  • About 90% of infants with vertical HPV infection progress to chronic HBV infection, leading to cirrhosis, hepatocellular carcinoma and liver failure.
  • All newborns of mothers with active hepatitis B infection should be passively immunised, followed by active immunisation with the Recombinant hepatitis B virus vaccine.
  • There is less than a 2% risk of infection after prophylaxis and a 90% risk of transmission without prophylaxis.

Option A: HbsAg positive

  • HBeAg positive and High maternal HBV viral load are the major markers to determine the risk of infection from mother to the infant.
  • The baby is hepatitis B positive, so the infection must come from the mother.

Option C: HbsAg and anti-Hbe antibody positivity

  • Baby is hep B positive, so he cannot be anti-Hbe antibody positive. Anti-Hbe antibody positivity prevents the person from infection

Option D: Mother infected with mutant HBV

  • So the mother must be HbeAg positive.
  • As the baby is infected with hepatitis B because this infection has passed from the mother to the infant.

questions.text: What is the likely cause of illness in a 14-month-old boy born to an HIV positive mother who presents with symptoms of fever, vomiting, profuse watery diarrhea, moderate dehydration, and deep-set eyes, along with examination findings of normal body temperature, elevated heart rate, and low blood pressure?
questions.solution:
Option A: Cryptosporidium

  • This child is likely suffering from Cryptosporidium, Caused by a microscopic parasite. Cryptosporidium is a common aetiology responsible for most deaths in children younger than 5 years and will be even more severe in presenting in children living with HIV. Diarrhoea is the commonest presentation. The primary initial treatment for cryptosporidiosis in children is ART (anti-retroviral therapy).

Option B: Entamoeba Histolytica

  • Amebiasis, caused by Entamoeba Histolytica parasites, has similar features. Patients who are very young, elderly, and those using corticosteroids all have the more severe form of Amebiasis, but it's not as common in patients with HIV as cryptosporidium. After ingesting the parasite, asymptomatic infections are frequent. The most typical symptom is diarrhoea.

Option C: Giardia lamblia

  • AIDS and non-AIDS individuals are susceptible to intestinal malabsorption and diarrhoea from Giardia, Giardiasis. Due to a humoral immunological deficiency, AIDS patients have a greater incidence rate of diarrhoea caused by Giardia than people without AIDS. The three most typical symptoms are abdominal discomfort, watery diarrhoea, and weight loss.

Option D: Lactose intolerance

  • Those who are lactose intolerant have symptoms after consuming lactose-containing dairy products, such as milk. From mild discomfort to a severe reaction, symptoms can vary. Most lactose-intolerant persons can consume some lactose without developing symptoms. Common symptoms of lactose intolerance are Nausea, Flatulence that causes cramps and bloating in the abdomen or diarrhoea; there is no such history in the above scenario.

questions.text: A 55-year-old female comes to the outdoor patient department with presenting complaints of dysphagia and bilateral facial swelling. She complains of no weight loss, heat intolerance, palpitations or sweating. Her Pulse rate is 74 beats/min. Her blood pressure is 130/90, her temperature is 98 F, and her RR is 19 breaths/min. The anterior neck mass (as shown in the image) is visible on physical examination. The mass is non-tender and nodular on palpation. Proptosis and lid lag is absent in the patient. On Serology, her TSH level is slightly lower than normal, her T3 and T4 levels are slightly raised, and no auto-antibody is seen. Which of the following is most likely seen in this condition?

choices.text: Tall columnar cells with scalloped colloid

questions.solution:
Option D: Colloid-rich follicles

  • The given image shows swelling likely to be a Multinodular goitre. In diffuse non-toxic goitre over time, recurrent episodes of hyperplasia and involution combine to produce a more irregular enlargement of the thyroid, termed Multinodular goitre (MNG).
  • Dominant clinical features of multinodular goitre are those caused by mass effects, which may cause airway obstruction, dysphagia, and compression of large vessels in the neck and upper thorax (superior vena cava syndrome).
  • Most patients are euthyroid or have subclinical hyperthyroidism (identified by reduced TSH levels). Still, about 10% of patients over 10 years develop an autonomous nodule within a long-standing goitre that produces hyperthyroidism (toxic MNG), also known as Plummer Syndrome.
  • The microscopic appearance includes colloid-rich follicles lined by flattened, inactive epithelium and areas of follicle hyperplasia, accompanied by degenerative changes related to physical stress.
  • A radioiodine scan demonstrates uneven iodine uptake (including the occasional “hot” autonomous nodule), consistent with an admixture of hyperplastic and involuting nodules.
  • The incidence of malignancy in long-standing multinodular goitres is low (<5%) but not zero.

Option A: Tall columnar cells with scalloped colloid

  • Tall columnar cells with scalloped colloids are seen in Grave's Disease.
  • Graves disease is the most common cause of endogenous hyperthyroidism.
  • It is a type II hypersensitivity caused by the formation of antibodies against TSH receptors primarily.

Option B: Psammoma Bodies

  • Psammoma Bodies are seen in Papillary Thyroid Carcinoma.
  • It is caused mostly by RET/PTC rearrangements and BRAF mutations.
  • Other features are Orphan Annie cells and nuclear grooves.

Option C: Hurthle’s cells

  • Hurthle’s cells are enlarged eosinophilic follicular cells with eosinophilic cytoplasm usually seen in Follicular Carcinoma of the Thyroid and Hashimoto Thyroiditis.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male has been admitted to the surgical emergency for resectioning pheochromocytoma. During the ward round, the attending surgeon asks the junior residents about the metastatic potential of the pheochromocytoma. Which of the following is the most reliable feature of malignant transformation of pheochromocytoma?

choices.text: Presence of metastasis to other organs

questions.solution:
Option B: Presence of metastasis to other organs

  • There is no histologic feature that reliably predicts malignant pheochromocytoma.
  • Cellular & nuclear pleomorphism, including the presence of giant cells & mitotic figures, are often seen in benign pheochromocytomas, while cellular monotony is paradoxically associated with aggressive tumours.
  • Even capsular and vascular invasion may be encountered in benign lesions.
  • Therefore, the definitive diagnosis of malignancy in pheochromocytomas is based exclusively on the presence of metastases.

Pheochromocytoma:

  • A pheochromocytoma is a catecholamine-secreting tumour that typically develops in the adrenal medulla.
  • Pheochromocytomas are usually benign (∼ 90% of cases) but may also be malignant.
  • Classic clinical features are due to excess sympathetic nervous system stimulation and involve episodic blood pressure crises with paroxysmal headaches, diaphoresis, heart palpitations, and pallor.
  • However, pheochromocytomas may also be asymptomatic or manifest with persistent hypertension.
  • Elevated catecholamine metabolites in the plasma or urine confirm the diagnosis, while imaging studies in patients with positive biochemistry are used to determine the tumour's location.
  • Surgical resection is the treatment of choice but is only carried out once alpha-adrenergic blockade with phenoxybenzamine has become effective.

Option A: Presence of mitotic figures

  • The presence of mitotic figures is characteristic of any malignancy.
  • However, these findings cannot predict the metastatic transformation in pheochromocytoma.

Option C: Vascular/ capsular invasion

  • Vascular invasion or capsular invasion does not predict the metastatic transformation of the pheochromocytoma
  • Rather, metastasis to other organs is the most reliable predictor.

Option D: All of the above

  • The most reliable predictor of malignant transformation of pheochromocytoma is metastasis to other organs.

questions.text: A 34-years-old male comes to the outdoor patient department with complaints of episodic headaches, palpitations, and sweating. On physical examination, his chest shows pectus excavatum and a high extremities-to-body ratio. Growth is seen on her tongue, and a mass on the left flank is also palpated. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option C: MEN2B

  • The clinical picture is closest to MEN2B, which is caused by the gain of function in the RET gene that regulates the membrane-bound tyrosine kinase receptor responsible for cell cycle regulation.
  • Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia is a group of inherited diseases caused by proliferative lesions (hyperplasias, adenomas & carcinomas) of multiple endocrine organs.
  • Types of MEN are MEN1, MEN2A, and MEN2B.
  • The patient complains of episodic headaches, palpitations, and sweating with a mass in the left flank, indicating Pheochromocytoma, the adrenal medulla tumour that releases catecholamines.
  • His pectus excavatum (grooved chest) and high extremities-to-body ratio indicate Marfanoid habitus, which is associated with MEN2B.
  • A growth in his tongue can be suspected of the mucosal neuroma, a benign growth of nerve tissue mostly seen on the tongue and intestine (presented as constipation when occurring here). It is the hallmark of MEN2B.
  • MEN2B is the combination of Pheochromocytoma, Medullary carcinoma of the thyroid, and Mucosal Neuroma and is closely associated with Marfanoid habitus.
MULTIPLE ENDOCRINE NEOPLASIA

MEN 1
  • Pituitary adenoma [prolactin secreting macro-adenoma]
  • Parathyroid adenoma
  • Pancreatic tumours [Zollinger Ellison syndrome]

MEN 2A
  • Medullary thyroid carcinoma (MTC)
  • Pheochromocytoma
  • Parathyroid adenoma
MEN 2B
  • Medullary thyroid carcinoma
  • Pheochromocytoma
  • Marfanoid habitus
  • Mucosal neuromas

Option A: MEN 1

  • MEN 1 presents as a combination of Pituitary, Pancreas, and Parathyroid tumours.
  • It is caused by a mutation in Menin, a tumour suppressor gene.

Option B: MEN2A

  • MEN2A is a combination of Medullary Thyroid Carcinoma, Pheochromocytoma, and Parathyroid adenoma.
  • A mutation in RET gene causes it.

Option D: Neurofibromatosis type 2

  • Neurofibromatosis type 2 is caused by a mutation in the NF2 tumour suppressor gene (merlin).
  • It can present with many tumours, such as Meningiomas, Bilateral Shwannomas, Ependymomas, etc.

questions.text: A 62-year-old male patient presents in OPD with complaints of difficulty swallowing and bad breath. He is concerned about pain in the upper portion of his neck on swallowing. He occasionally regurgitates undigested food shortly after eating. Which of the following is the most likely aetiology of his problems?
questions.solution:
Option B: Zenker’s diverticulum

The patient described in the vignette is a typical case of Zenker diverticulum, which is characterised by:

  • False diverticulum
  • Formed by herniation of mucosa at the junction of the pharynx & oesophagus in the posterior hypopharyngeal wall.
  • Features:
    • Halitosis
    • Regurgitation of the previous day's food
    • If the diverticulum fills with food, can cause dysphagia or obstruction of the oesophagus.

Option A: Mallory-Weiss tear

  • Mucosal tear below gastroesophageal junction secondary to repeated, forceful vomiting; often seen in alcoholics.

Option C: Schatzki rings

  • These are mucosal rings found in the distal oesophagus at the squamocolumnar junction.

Option D: Traction diverticula

  • In contrast to a Zenker’s diverticulum, this is usually asymptomatic & are true diverticula involving all layers of the oesophagus.
  • They are typically caused by adherence of the oesophagus to the scarred mediastinal structure.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man has been presented to the gastroenterology clinic with complaints of blood in stool accompanied by pain in the upper abdomen and vomiting on and off for the past 2 months. He has lost 10 Kg weight since these symptoms started. He has a family history of gastrointestinal stromal tumours. On examination, there is a palpable mass in the epigastric region. He has no anal fissures or haemorrhoids. He has been advised to further workup. Which of the following is the most common site of gastrointestinal stromal tumours?
questions.solution:
Option C: Stomach

  • The stomach is the most common site of gastrointestinal stromal tumours.
  • Approximately 50-70% of them originate in the stomach.

Option A: Small intestine

  • The second most common site of gastrointestinal stromal tumours is the small intestine.

Option B: Colon

  • Gastrointestinal stromal tumours are rare lesions that constitute the majority of mesenchymal tumours in the gastrointestinal tract.
  • Within the colon and rectum, they represent 0.1% of all cancers.

Option D: Liver

 

  • Gastrointestinal stromal tumours can metastasise to the liver but can never originate from there.

questions.text: A 38-year-old male patient was admitted to the surgical ward with advanced colorectal cancer. A left hemicolectomy was performed. The specimen was sent for histopathology, which suggested poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma. Family history was taken in detail, which showed 4 members (two of them were first-degree relatives) with colon cancer. Their malignancy was diagnosed before 40 years of age. Doctors suggested this as a case of Lynch syndrome. Which of the following options best correlates with Lynch syndrome?

choices.text: Sarcoma, breast, leukaemia, and adrenal cancers

questions.solution:
Option C: Colon, endometrium, and ovary cancers

  • Lynch syndrome, also known as hereditary non-polyposis colorectal cancer syndrome, is the most frequent genetic form of colorectal cancer (HNPCC).
  • The most common cancers involved in Lynch syndrome are colorectal, endometrial and ovarian carcinoma. Other primary malignancies in these people include gastric, ovarian, small bowel, urothelial (ureter, renal pelvis), biliary tract, pancreatic, brain (glioblastoma), sebaceous gland adenomas, and keratoacanthomas.
  • A germline mutation causes Lynch syndrome in one of four MMR genes: MLH1, MSH2, MSH6, and PMS2.
  • Mismatch repair genes are required for fixing erroneous nucleotide base pairing during DNA replication. Lynch syndrome is responsible for 2% to 4% of all colorectal cancer cases and 2.5% of endometrial cancer cases.
  • Immunohistochemical staining and microsatellite instability testing are used to screen for Lynch syndrome.
  • Patients who meet the Amsterdam II criteria, the revised Bethesda guidelines, have endometrial cancer diagnosed before 50 or have a family history of Lynch syndrome should be examined for genetic testing

Option A: Breast, colon, and ovary cancers

  • Women with BRCA1 or BRCA2 mutations are at an increased risk of developing breast, ovary, colon, stomach, pancreas, and gallbladder malignancies.
  • BRCA1 and BRCA2 are both thought to function as tumour suppressor genes.

Option B: Leukemia, lymphoma, and breast cancers

  • Ataxia-telangiectasia (A-T) is an autosomal recessive condition caused by mutations in the ataxia-telangiectasia mutated (ATM) gene, which encodes a serine-threonine protein kinase implicated in DNA repair pathways.
  • They are also more likely to acquire cancer, including leukaemia, lymphoma, and ovarian and breast carcinoma.

Option D: Sarcoma, breast, leukaemia, and adrenal cancers

  • Li-Fraumeni syndrome (also known as the sarcoma, breast, leukaemia, and adrenal gland [SBLA] cancer syndrome) is a rare inherited syndrome that increases the risk of a variety of cancers, including sarcoma (including osteosarcoma and soft-tissue sarcomas), leukaemia, brain (central nervous system) cancers, adrenal cortex cancer, and breast cancer.
  • These malignancies frequently arise in young adults or even children.
  • Hereditary mutations commonly cause this condition in the tumour suppressor gene TP53.

questions.text: A 56-year-old diabetic woman has recently been treated with a 2-week course of antibiotics for a skin infection. She returns to the clinic for a follow-up with a new complaint of thick whitish vaginal discharge with significant vaginal itching. The most likely cause of these symptoms is.
questions.solution:
Option B: C. albicans

  • C. albicans is a major cause of vulvovaginitis.
  • The patient presents with thick white vaginal discharge.
  • Opportunistic pathogenic yeast Candida albicans is a frequent constituent of the human gut flora. The human body is not the only place it can survive. It is found in the mouth and gastrointestinal tract between 40% and 60% of healthy persons.
  • The fungus candida albicans cause the majority of vaginal yeast infections.
  • A healthy balance of yeast, including candida, and bacteria naturally exists in your vagina.
  • Several bacteria, including lactobacillus, stop the yeast from growing too much. However, that equilibrium could be upset.

Option A: C. granulomatis

  • C. granulomatis causes granuloma inguinale. Chancroid results in painful genital ulcers caused by the organism H. ducreyi.
  • The genital ulcerative disease granuloma inguinale (donovanosis) is brought on by the intracellular gram-negative bacterium Klebsiella granulomatous (formerly known as Calymmatobacterium granulomatis).
  • One or more painless lumps, commonly located in the genitalia, anal region, or groin, are among the signs and symptoms of donovanosis. The lump or lumps gradually enlarge and eventually ulcerate.
  • These sores are often beefy-red in colour, quickly bleed, and have a rolled edge. The sore may occasionally smell unpleasant.

Option C: Chancroid

  • A sexually transmitted condition (STD) called chancroid causes sores on the genitalia. A soft chancre or an ulcer with jagged edges may be visible. The sore could hurt and have pus in it. It's always important to contact a healthcare provider when someone has any soreness or pain in the genitals.
  • Chancroid is caused by the Haemophilus ducreyi, resulting in painful, superficial ulcers, often with regional lymphadenopathy.
  • It is characterized by painful necrotizing genital ulcers that may accompany inguinal lymphadenopathy. It is a highly contagious but curable disease.
  • No laboratory testing can immediately confirm the diagnosis of chancroid. Chancroid can only be diagnosed with certainty by isolating H ducreyi on a specialized medium. However, these assays are only commonly available in some centres.

Option D: Neisseria meningitidis

  • N. meningitidis can cause meningitis.
  • Neisseria meningitidis bacteria bring on meningococcal disease. Without being ill, one in ten people has these germs in the back of their nose and throat. Being a carrier is what we refer to as.
  • Invading microorganisms can occasionally result in illnesses like meningococcal disease.
  • When a person has meningococcal septicemia, the germs increase in the bloodstream and harm the blood vessel walls.
  • The skin and internal organs bleed as a result of this. Chillers and fever are possible symptoms.

questions.text: A 68-year-old male with a history of smoking and hypertension presents to an outdoor urology clinic with complaints of severe lower back pain associated with anorexia and unintentional weight loss of 15kg in six months. He denies associated urinary urgency, frequency, hesitancy, dysuria, or nocturia. Digital rectal examination reveals a firm, hard, asymmetrical, and stony prostate with a rough nodular surface, suggestive of prostate malignancy. A transrectal biopsy of prostatic tissue is taken and sent for histopathological analysis. Which of the following tumour markers is not useful in the immunohistochemistry analysis of prostatic carcinoma?
questions.solution:
Option D: Ki-67

  • The diagnosis of prostatic carcinoma is confirmed in histopathology. If any suspicion is found on histopathological analysis, then immunohistochemistry is ordered to cross-check the diagnosis, and various markers help assist in this procedure.
    • Here are a few markers used for establishing the diagnosis of CA prostate on immunohistochemistry.
      • AMACR
      • EGR/TMPRSS2
      • NKX3.1
  • Ki-67 is a nuclear protein associated with ribosomal RNA synthesis and may be necessary for cell-cycle proliferation. It makes Ki-67 an important molecular prognostic marker rather than a diagnostic marker for prostatic carcinoma and has very little to no proven benefit for the diagnosis of prostatic carcinoma.
    • Ki-67 is used as a marker for HPV infection in cervical intraepithelial neoplasia.

Option A: NKX3.1

  • NK3 homeobox 1 (NKX3.1) is a validated prostate-specific marker. Most high-grade prostatic adenocarcinomas have distinct nuclear staining in tumour cells.
    • As it lines the benign prostatic epithelium, the loss/absence of NKX3.1 in a biopsy specimen indicates a non-benign (malignant/carcinomatous) process. Hence, prostatic adenocarcinoma is in the differentials.

  • Prostatic adenocarcinoma cells (arrows) show strong nuclear staining for NKX3.1.
  • In the large benign prostatic glands (arrowheads), secretory cells also show strong nuclear staining for NKX3.1, and some benign basal cells also show weaker nuclear staining.

Option B: AMACR

  • AMACR, also known as P504S, is an integral component of the immunohistochemistry (IHC) cocktail and is a molecular marker for prostatic adenocarcinoma - identified by complementary DNA microarray technology.

Option C: TMPRSS2

  • A fusion gene between ERG and the transmembrane protease, serine 2 (TMPRSS) gene, is found in prostatic adenocarcinoma.
    • ERG protein immunostaining has been used to detect the ERG/TMPRSS2 fusion protein, a fusion gene product.
    • This fusion gene product is fairly specific for prostate cancer.
    • It has potential diagnostic value in determining the prostatic origin of a metastatic focus and possibly differentiating a small cell neuroendocrine carcinoma that arose in the prostate from one arising elsewhere (e.g., the lung). ​​​​​​​

questions.text: A 33-year-old male patient presents in the surgical outpatient department with the complaint of testicular swelling for the last 1 month. He is vitally stable, and his physical examination shows asymmetrical testicular masses and gynecomastia. A scrotal ultrasound shows a hypoechoic and hypervascular lesion. His alpha-fetoprotein level is raised. A lesion biopsy is done, showing polygonal acidophilic tumour cells with a round to oval nucleus and cytoplasm showing rod-shaped crystalloids of Reinke. What is the possible diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option A: Leydig cell tumour

  • The clinical history, examination, raised tumour marker, and biopsy report is consistent with the typical presentation of a Leydig cell tumour.
  • Leydig cell tumours are the most common testicular sex cord-stromal tumours (SCSTs) and comprise 1-2% of all testicular tumours.
  • It can present at any age typically; peak presentation in adults is 30 to 35 years and in children 5 to 10 years. In children, it presents with sexual precocity.
  • About 10% of adult Leydig cell tumours are malignant and have the potential for metastasis.
  • Leydig cell tumour produces androgens and, in some cases, estrogens resulting in gynecomastia.
  • Microscopically, cells are large and have polygonal or round cell outlines, abundant granular eosinophilic cytoplasm, and a round central nucleus.
  • About 25% of cases show Reinke's rod-shaped crystalloids, characteristic of leydig cell tumours.
  • Associated diseases include Klinefelter syndrome, hereditary leiomyomatosis, cryptorchidism, and renal cell carcinoma syndrome (caused by germline mutations in the metabolic enzyme fumarate hydratase).

Option B: Granulosa cell tumour

  • The age of presentation and microscopic findings do not suggest a diagnosis of granulosa cell tumour.
  • These are most commonly present in infancy and are rarely seen in adults.
  • These are uniformly benign.
  • The microscopic picture shows scant cytoplasm and elongated and grooved nuclei.
  • These are arranged in solid sheets and microfollicular structures called Call-Exner bodies.

Option C: Gonadoblastoma

  • The age of presentation and microscopic findings do not suggest a diagnosis of granulosa cell tumour.
  • These usually occur before age 20.
  • These are composed of more than one type of cell, including germ cells, granulosa cells, and stromal cells.

Option D: Thecoma

  • The age of presentation and microscopic findings do not suggest a diagnosis of the thecoma.
  • Microscopically, the thecoma shows theca cells but may also have granulosa cells.
  • These are mostly benign and rarely malignant

questions.text: A 5-year-old child has been brought to the clinic with easy bruising and fatigue for the past few weeks. On examination, no abnormal findings are noted. Bone marrow study has revealed the myeloblasts and promonocytes in the bone marrow of more than 20%. Considering the most likely diagnosis, which genetic mutation is present in the given condition?
questions.solution:
Option D: Chromosomal Inversion

  • One of the molecular mechanisms involved in AML is genetic inversion.

AML

  • AML develops due to genetic changes in a hematopoietic precursor cell that alters normal growth and differentiation, resulting in large numbers of abnormal, immature myeloid cells in the bone marrow and blood.
  • These aberrant cells can divide and proliferate but cannot normally differentiate into mature, fully functional hematopoietic cells.
  • Many chromosomal abnormalities and gene mutations are associated with prognosis in AML.
  • Cases of AML may demonstrate mutations in oncogenes (e.g., NRAS, FLT3) and/or loss of tumour suppressor genes (e.g., TP53, WT1 [Wilms tumour suppressor gene]).
  • Any hematologic malignancies are associated with specific chromosomal translocations that generate chimeric fusion genes that are never expressed in wild-type cells.
  • Chromosomal aberrations in AML commonly involve transcription factors that regulate hematopoiesis.
  • The chromosomal aberrations t(8;21)(q22;q22) and the inv(16)(p13q22) in AML involve subunits of the core-binding factor (CBF) group of transcription factors.
  • Members of the CBF group function as heterodimeric complexes regulating diverse target genes involved in tissue differentiation.
  • The cytogenetic hallmark of APL is a translocation involving the retinoic acid receptor-alpha (RARA) locus on chromosome 17.
  • These translocations lead to the formation of chimeric fusion transcripts from each of the derivative chromosomes.

Option A: Trinucleotide repeat expansion

  • Increased repetition of base triplets that leads to faulty protein synthesis or folding
  • Characterized by genetic anticipation
  • Seen in Fragile X syndrome and Huntington's disease

Option B: Anticipation

  • A phenomenon in which disease onset occurs earlier and/or the disease manifestation is more severe in offspring than in parents.
  • Seen in Huntington's disease

Option C: Heteroplasmy

  • The presence of both normal and mutated mtDNA results in variable expression in mitochondrially inherited disease.
  • Seen in mitochondrial disorders

questions.text:
A 25-year-old male presents to the clinic with a history of recurrent episodes of bloody urine and hearing loss. On physical examination, he has mild edema in the lower extremities. Family history reveals that his maternal uncle and grandfather had similar kidney problems and hearing impairment. Laboratory investigations show elevated proteinuria and microscopic hematuria. A renal biopsy is performed, which reveals thinning and splitting of the glomerular basement membrane.

Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The correct option is B) Alport Syndrome.

Option A) IgA Nephropathy: IgA nephropathy is characterized by the deposition of immunoglobulin A (IgA) in the glomerular mesangium, leading to inflammation and damage. It commonly presents with recurrent episodes of gross hematuria following respiratory or gastrointestinal infections. It does not typically cause hearing loss or thinning and splitting of the glomerular basement membrane.

Option C) Berger's Disease (IgA Vasculitis): Berger's disease, also known as IgA vasculitis or Henoch-Schönlein purpura, is a vasculitis affecting small vessels and is characterized by IgA immune complex deposition. It commonly presents with a rash, joint pain, abdominal pain, and occasionally kidney involvement. It does not usually cause hearing loss or glomerular basement membrane abnormalities as described in the case.

Option D) Goodpasture Syndrome: Goodpasture syndrome is an autoimmune disorder characterized by the presence of antibodies against the glomerular basement membrane and the alveolar basement membrane of the lungs. It causes rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis with pulmonary involvement, leading to respiratory symptoms such as cough and hemoptysis. While it does affect the glomerular basement membrane, it does not present with a family history of similar kidney problems and hearing loss, as described in the case.

Correct Option B) Alport Syndrome: Alport Syndrome is a genetic disorder caused by mutations in the genes encoding type IV collagen, leading to abnormal collagen in the glomerular basement membrane, cochlea, and the eye lens capsule. It is characterized by progressive glomerulonephritis, microscopic hematuria, and sensorineural hearing loss. The characteristic renal biopsy finding of thinning and splitting of the glomerular basement membrane, called "basket-weave appearance," is a hallmark of Alport Syndrome. Family history often reveals affected male relatives, as in this case. It is important to note that Alport Syndrome can have X-linked, autosomal recessive, or autosomal dominant patterns of inheritance, with X-linked being the most common and severe form.

In summary, the clinical case presented here is suggestive of Alport Syndrome based on the patient's history, clinical findings, and characteristic renal biopsy findings.

questions.text: A 39-year-old female known case of chronic liver disease presented to the emergency department with complaints of generalized body weakness, malaise, and easy fatigability for one month. On examination, she was pale-looking; the digital rectal examination was performed, which was insignificant. Her complete blood count showed microcytic anaemia with Hb 6.8 g/dL. An iron profile was also ordered. Which among the following is the best parameter for the assessment of body iron stores?
questions.solution:
Option C: Serum ferritin

  • Because plasma ferritin is derived largely from the storage pool of body iron, its levels correlate well with body iron stores.
  • Ferritin is a ubiquitous protein-iron complex found at the highest levels in the liver, spleen, bone marrow, and skeletal muscles.
  • Intracellular ferritin is located in the cytosol and in lysosomes, in which partially degraded protein shells of ferritin aggregate into hemosiderin granules.
  • Iron in hemosiderin is chemically reactive and turns blue-black when exposed to potassium ferrocyanide, which is the basis for the Prussian blue stain.
  • With normal iron stores, only trace amounts of hemosiderin are found in the body, principally in macrophages in the bone marrow, spleen, and liver, most being stored as ferritin.
  • In iron-overloaded cells, most iron is stored in hemosiderin.
  • The normal amount of serum ferritin is 24-336 mcg/L for men and 11-307 mcg/L for women.

Option A: Serum iron

  • Serum iron measures how much amount of iron is circulating in the serum.

  • About 90% of circulating iron is bound to transferrin.

  • Total body iron stores cannot be measured through this test because only the circulating amount is being measured and not the storage form in other organs.

  • Normal serum iron levels are 60-170 mcg/L.

Option B: Serum TIBC

  • TIBC stands for total iron binding capacity or transferrin iron binding capacity.

  • Iron circulates in our body by binding to transferrin.

  • This test measures the binding capacity of transferrin with iron in the blood, not the actually stored iron in the body.

  • Normal levels of serum TIBC are 240-450 mcg/dL.

Option D: Serum transferrin

  • Transferrin is a glycoprotein found in blood plasma.

  • It carries the iron in circulating blood by binding to various organs such as the spleen, bone marrow, and liver.

  • The amount of serum transferrin can be measured through TIBC; the higher the TIBC, the less iron-bound transferrin is present.

  • As it only measures the bound and non-bound iron in the circulating blood, it cannot be the best test to show the storage amount of iron in the total body.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male was diagnosed with haemoglobin C anaemia due to a history of fatigue, weakness, and shortness of breath on exertion for six months. His peripheral blood smear revealed target cells, microspherocytes, and rod-shaped RBCs containing precipitated haemoglobin C crystals. CBC results showed mild anaemia with decreased MCV and MCHC and decreased haptoglobin. The haptoglobin complex is shown in the picture below. What is the half-life of this complex?
questions.solution:
• This is the case of intrinsic hemolytic anaemia caused by haemoglobin C disease in a patient with a history of fatigue, weakness, and shortness of breath on exertion.
  • Peripheral blood smear reveals rod-shaped RBCs containing precipitated haemoglobin C crystals, target cells, and microspherocytes, confirming the diagnosis.
  • CBC results show mild anaemia, decreased MCV, MCHC, and haptoglobin.
  • The haptoglobin complex shown in the picture above is the haptoglobin haemoglobin complex that has a half-life 5 days.
  • Decreased haptoglobin is a common finding in hemolytic anaemias. It is because excess haemoglobin released from RBC destruction is bound to haptoglobin, and its complex is cleared rapidly, resulting in decreased levels of free haptoglobin.
  • Haptoglobin level below 25-28mg/dl is highly sensitive to hemolysis, and although false positive results are quite rare, they can be caused by nonhemolytic disorders like malnutrition, liver dysfunction, etc.

questions.text: A 26-year-old African-American pilot working in the military develops fatigue, weakness and lethargy a week after redeploying to a new area. On examination, he has pallor, jaundice and splenomegaly. His investigations reveal anaemia, hemoglobinuria and hemoglobinemia. He gives a history of having received primaquine chemoprophylaxis for Plasmodium vivax malaria on redeploying to a non-malarious area. Which is the most severe variant of G6PD deficiency?
questions.solution:
Option D: G6PD-Mediterranean

  • The 26-year-old male patient had acute onset of weakness and lethargy a week after receiving primaquine.
  • His physical examination revealed jaundice, pallor and splenomegaly.
  • The investigations showed anaemia, hemoglobinemia and hemoglobinuria.
  • This suggests an acute onset hemolytic anaemia, most likely due to G6PD deficiency.
  • In G6PD deficiency, episodic hemolytic anaemia occurs after exposure to exacerbating factors.
  • Stress causes lysis of elderly erythrocytes, thus producing self-limiting hemolysis.
  • The Mediterranean variant is the most severe variant of G6PD deficiency anaemia.

Option A: G6PD-B

  • G6PD B is one of the less severe variants.
  • It is the normal variant or wild type of allele.

Option B: G6PD-A

  • One of the two common variants, A and A+, occurs in African-American males.
  • It is associated with low levels of G6PD enzymes.

Option C: G6PD-A+

  • G6PD-A is common in African-American men.
  • The G6PD A+ variant is associated with high enzyme levels and no hemolysis.

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department because of a 2-day history of fever, intermittent rigours, and night sweats. She also has a 1-month history of progressive fatigue. Five weeks ago, she was hospitalized and received intravenous antibiotics for treating bacterial meningitis. Her temperature is 39.4°C (102.9°F), her pulse is 130/min, and her blood pressure is 105/70 mm Hg. Examination shows pallor and scattered petechiae and ecchymoses. Laboratory studies show a haemoglobin concentration of 9.0 g/dL, a leukocyte count of 1100/mm3 with 30% segmented neutrophils, and a platelet count of 20,000/mm3. The patient was most likely treated with which of the following antibiotics?
questions.solution:
Option B: Chloramphenicol

  • The patient's pancytopenia is likely caused by an antibiotic that can cause a grey baby syndrome in premature infants.
  • Pancytopenia decreases the number of all cell lines in the blood (i.e., erythrocytes, leukocytes, platelets).
  • It is due to bone marrow suppression is a side effect of therapy with chloramphenicol.
  • It may develop in a dose-dependent, reversible manner or manifest as dose-independent irreversible aplastic anaemia with a sudden onset up to several months after treatment.
  • Aplastic anaemia is a rare but potentially fatal side effect, so the use of chloramphenicol has been limited in resource-rich countries.
  • However, due to its low cost, it is often still used to treat bacterial meningitis caused by H. influenza, N. meningitidis, or S. pneumoniae in resource-limited countries.
  • The treatment is the immediate cessation of the drug and administering bone marrow stimulants.

Option A: Trimethoprim/sulfamethoxazole

  • Sulfonamides (e.g., sulfamethoxazole) may cause pancytopenia. Other more common side effects of trimethoprim/sulfamethoxazole (TMP/SMX) include hyperkalemia, exanthema, photosensitivity, nephrotoxicity, megaloblastic anaemia, and leukopenia.
  • However, TMP/SMX is not recommended for treating bacterial meningitis, so it is unlikely to have been given to this patient.

Option C: Linezolid

  • Linezolid may cause bone marrow suppression, especially thrombocytopenia.
  • However, linezolid-induced bone marrow suppression is usually dose-dependent and occurs during therapy, not weeks later, as in this patient.
  • Moreover, this antibiotic is not recommended as a first-line treatment for bacterial meningitis but is used as a reserve drug for the treatment of resistant gram-positive bacteria.
  • It is, therefore, unlikely that this patient was treated with linezolid.

Option D: Imipenem

  • Imipenem can lower the seizure threshold and cause gastrointestinal upset, skin rash, and thrombophlebitis.
  • However, it is not known to cause pancytopenia. Moreover, imipenem is not recommended for the treatment of bacterial meningitis.

questions.text: Macrophage activation occurs in 2 different pathways; Classical and Alternative pathways. According to different pathogens causing the disease, the pathways differ. Among the given options, which of the following leads to the activation of macrophages via the classical pathway?
questions.solution:
Option A: IFN-ϒ

  • Gamma interferon activates macrophages via the classical pathway.

IFN- ϒ

  • Classically activated macrophages arise in response to interferon-γ (IFNγ), which can be produced during an adaptive immune response by T helper 1 (TH1) cells or CD8+ T cells (not shown) or during an innate immune response by natural killer (NK) cells, and tumour-necrosis factor (TNF), which is produced by antigen-presenting cells (APCs).
  • Wound-healing (alternatively activated) macrophages arise in response to interleukin-4 (IL-4), which can be produced during an adaptive immune response by TH2 cells or during an innate immune response by granulocytes.
  • Regulatory macrophages are generated in response to various stimuli, including immune complexes, prostaglandins, G-protein coupled receptor (GPCR) ligands, glucocorticoids, apoptotic cells, or IL-10.
  • Each of these three populations has a distinct physiology. Classically activated macrophages have microbicidal activity, whereas regulatory macrophages produce high levels of IL-10 to suppress immune responses.
  • Wound-healing macrophages are similar to the previously described alternatively activated macrophages and have a role in tissue repair. TLR, Toll-like receptor.

Option B: IL-4

  • IL4 is involved in the activation of macrophages via an alternative pathway.
  • Therefore this option is incorrect

Option C: IL-13

  • IL13 is involved in the activation of macrophages via the alternative pathway
  • Therefore this option is incorrect

Option D: IL-1

  • IL1 does not activate macrophages.
  • Rather it is an osteoclast activation factor and plays a major role in the fever.
  • Therefore this option is incorrect

questions.text: Decarboxylation of which of the following amino acids yields a biogenic amine, which is a potent vasodilator?
questions.solution:
Decarboxylation of amino acids produces biogenic amines.

Amino acid Biogenic amine
Histidine Histamine (Vasodilator)
5-hydroxy tryptophan Serotonin (5-Hydroxy tryptamine)
Tyrosine Tyramine
DOPA

Dopamine
Serine

Ethanolamine

All the decarboxylases are lyases (EC4).

Extra Edge:

Note: Similarly, from Amino Acid, if Amino group is removed, Acid is formed.

BUT Decarboxylation of Glutamate and Lysine does not form amine.

  • Lysine → Cadaverine (a foul smelling diamine)
  • Glutamate → GABA (Gamma Amino Butyric Acid)

questions.text: A 9-month-old boy is brought to the pediatrics OPD with complaints of irritability, poor feeding, and vomiting. His mother also added that his urine smells like burnt sugar. After a proper physical examination, his urine sample is sent to the laboratory for analysis. Which of the following amino acids will not be found in this patient’s urine test?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: Option B : Phenylalanine

  • This patient is suffering from maple syrup urine disease. A burnt sugar-like smell is a characteristic feature of this disease.
  • Valine, isoleucine, and leucine will be found in urine tests, but not phenylalanine.
  • Phenylalaine is present in the urine in case of phenylketonuria patients which also show musty body odor.

Option A, C and D: Leucine, Isoleucine, Valine

Maple syrup urine disease (MSUD):

  • It is a rare autosomal recessive disease.
  • Typically present in children between 5 months to 7 years of age.
  • It occurs due to the inherited deficiency of branched-chain keto-acid decarboxylase resulting in a defect in oxidative phosphorylation and catabolism of branched-chain amino acids - valine, isoleucine, and leucine. As a result, these amino acids are excreted in the urine.
  • It may cause increased alfa-ketoacid in blood, especially leucine.
  • Typical clinical presentation includes poor feeding, irritability, vomiting, loss of appetite, and poor muscle tone.
  • Urine smells like maple syrup or burnt sugar.
  • It may cause progressive neurological decline.
  • Mental retardation may occur due to increased isoleucine.
  • In untreated cases, the disease may progress to life-threatening coma or respiratory failure, and death can occur within a few months.
  • Treatment: Isoleucine, leucine, and valine restriction in diet and thiamine supplement.

questions.text: Which of the following amino acids is considered a non-protein amino acid, given that biological proteins are synthesized through amino acid polymerization by the translation machinery using information stored in DNA?
questions.solution:
Non-protein amino acids are those found in our body but not incorporated into proteins. They are not coded by codons.

Example of non-protein amino acids:

  • Ornithine
  • Citrulline
  • Homocysteine
  • Beta-alanine
  • GABA
  • Sarcosine
  • Homoserine

questions.text:
Assertion: Conversion of homocysteine to methionine requires folate and vitamin B12 as a cofactor. This reaction is a transmethylation process.

Reason: The enzyme required for this process is homocysteine methyl transferase which requires a methyl group from methylcobalamin. Methylcobalamin, in turn, acquires the methyl group from methyl-THF.

choices.text: Both Assertion and Reason are independently true/correct statements, and the Reason is the correct explanation for the assertion
Both Assertion and Reason are independently true/correct statements, but the Reason is not the correct explanation for the assertion
Assertion is independently a true/correct statement, but the Reason is independently a false/incorrect statement
Assertion is independently a false/incorrect statement, but Reason is independently a true/correct statement.

questions.solution:
Option A: Both Assertion and Reason are independently true/correct statements, and the Reason is the correct explanation for the assertion

Methionine synthase:

  • A big monomeric protein with four distinct modules, methionine synthase, has 1227 amino acid residues in the enzyme from E. coli.
  • Homocysteine is bound and activated by the N-terminal module, and its thiol coordinates to a zinc metal ion necessary for catalysis.
  • Methyl tetrahydrofolate is bound and activated by the following module in the sequence.
  • To move methyl groups to and from the base-off cofactor, each of these substrate-binding modules communicates with the B12-binding module, the third module in the sequence.
  • Methionine synthase must be activated by the C-terminal module when the cobalamin cofactor is oxidized during turnover (1 in 2000 turnovers results in oxidation in vitro).
  • A methyl donor and an electron donor are necessary for the cofactor's inactive cobalamin form to become active.
  • S-adenosylmethionine serves as the methyl donor.

Option B, C and D: refer to explanation of A

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents to the clinic complaining of headache, nausea, vomiting, and dry skin for the last three weeks. She has a past medical history of acne, for which she is receiving treatment. She does not smoke and only drinks socially. Her physical examination reveals hepatomegaly and papilledema. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this presentation?
questions.solution:
Option A: Vitamin A toxicity

  • The most likely cause of vitamin A toxicity is overdose. The clinical manifestations of vitamin A toxicity includes:
Vitamin A toxicity
Acute toxicity
  • Nausea
  • Vomiting
  • Headache
  • Fatigue
  • Blurred vision
Chronic toxicity
  • Pseudotumor cerebri
  • Hepatosplenomegaly
  • Dry skin
  • Scaling
  • Arthralgia
Teratogenic effects
  • Microcephaly
  • Microphthalmia
  • Agenesis of thymus
  • Cardiovascular anomalies
  • Fetus demise

Option B: Iron overload

  • Iron overload occurs in hemochromatosis that can present with abdominal pain, hepatomegaly, liver cirrhosis, diabetes mellitus, bronze skin pigmentation, and cardiomyopathy.

Option C: Copper overload

  • Copper overload occurs in Wilson disease that presents hepatosplenomegaly, abdominal pain, Kayser-Fleischer ring, and neurological symptoms (dysarthria, dystonia, parkinsonism, drooling, and tremors).

Option D: Vitamin D toxicity
