  • Vitamin D toxicity can occur in supplement overdose, sarcoidosis, and lymphomas.
  • Vitamin D toxicity presents symptoms of hypercalcemia that include kidney stones, bone pain, abdominal pain, constipation, nausea, and neuropsychiatric symptoms such as anxiety and depression.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman taking oral contraceptives presents with complaints of peripheral neuropathy, dry, scaly lips with cracks at the corner of the mouth. Blood examination reveals sideroblastic anemia. This patient's condition is caused by the deficiency of a vitamin that acts as a cofactor in which of the following steps of catecholamine synthesis?
questions.solution:
Option C: C

  •  In a patient taking OCPs, clinical features of peripheral neuropathy (paresthesias, decreased sensation in the extremities) and sideroblastic anemia (microcytic hypochromic anemia with sideroblasts in the bone marrow) suggest a vitamin B6 deficiency.
  • DOPA decarboxylase catalyzes the conversion of L-DOPA to dopamine in the presence of the cofactor pyridoxal phosphate (the active form of vitamin B6).
  • Vitamin B6 also cofactor in multiple other reactions, such as cystathionine synthesis, heme synthesis, decarboxylation, and transamination reactions.
  • Clinical features of vitamin B6 deficiency include glossitis, gingivostomatitis, peripheral neuropathy, and sideroblastic anemia, as observed in the patient.

Option A: A

This is false because:

  • Phenylalanine hydroxylase catalyzes the conversion of phenylalanine to tyrosine in the cofactor tetrahydrobiopterin (THB).
  • Clinical features of THB deficiency include swallowing difficulty, behavioral problems, seizures, and progressive neurologic deterioration, which this patient lacks.

Option B: B

This is false because:

  • Tyrosine hydroxylase catalyzes tyrosine's conversion to L-DOPA in the cofactor tetrahydrobiopterin (THB).
  • Clinical features of THB deficiency include swallowing difficulty, behavioral problems, seizures, and progressive neurologic deterioration, which this patient lacks.

Option D: D

This is false because:

  • Dopamine β-hydroxylase catalyzes the conversion of dopamine to norepinephrine in the presence of the cofactor's vitamin C (ascorbic acid) and Cu2+.
  • Clinical features of vitamin C deficiency include follicular hyperkeratosis and perifollicular bleeding, ecchymoses, gingivitis, and impaired wound healing, which are not observed here.
  • Moreover, most patients with vitamin C deficiency will have either normocytic anemia (due to decreased iron absorption in the small intestine) or macrocytic anemia (due to decreased conversion of folate to its active metabolite, folinic acid), unlike this patient.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man on drug therapy with a potent oxidizing agent has a self-limiting episode of hemolysis, back pain, and jaundice. The peripheral blood smear reveals non-spherocytic and normocytic anemia; Heinz's bodies are seen in some of his erythrocytes. Which of the following is the most likely cause of his anemia?

choices.text: A lowered concentration of oxidized glutathione
A lowered concentration of reduced glutathione
A reduction of hydrogen peroxide levels

questions.solution:
Option B: A lowered concentration of reduced glutathione

  • The patient has glucose 6-P dehydrogenase deficiency and cannot generate NADPH from glucose 6-P. In the red blood cells lacking mitochondria, this is the only pathway through which NADPH can be generated.
  • In the absence of NADPH, the molecule which protects against oxidative damage (glutathione) is oxidized preferentially to protect membrane lipids and proteins.
  • There is only limited glutathione in the membrane, so once it is oxidized, it needs to be converted back to reduced glutathione (the protective form).
  • The enzyme that does this, glutathione reductase, requires NADPH to supply the electrons to reduce the oxidized glutathione.

  • In the absence of NADPH, the glutathione cannot be reduced, and the protection offered by reduced glutathione is eliminated, leading to membrane damage and cell lysis.

Option A: A lowered concentration of oxidized glutathione

This is the wrong choice because:

  • Patients with glucose 6-P dehydrogenase deficiency cannot generate NADPH from glucose 6-P.
  • In the absence of NADPH, glutathione cannot be reduced.
  • The oxidized form of glutathione is increased.

Option C: Increased production of NADPH

  • Patients with glucose 6-P dehydrogenase deficiency cannot generate NADPH from glucose 6-P.
  • As the HMP is the major pathway for the production of NADPH, So cell will  have a lower levels of NADPH.

Option D: A reduction of hydrogen peroxide levels

  • H2O2 is a reactive oxygen spec responsible for free radical damage of cell membranes.
  • In the absence of G6PD, H2O2 neutralization will be reduced, so there should be a rise in hydrogen peroxide levels.

questions.text: The oxidation of glucose by the HMP pathway produces which of the following as final products?
questions.solution:
Option A: 6 NADPH

  • In the oxidative phase,2 NADPH are produced from 1 glucose molecule to give a final product of ribulose-5-P.
  • To complete the non-oxidative phase, at least three molecules of ribulose-5-P need to enter this phase.

  • To form three ribulose-5-P, 3 glucose 6-P will need to be oxidized initially, out of which 2 molecules are recovered again at the end.
  • Hence, the total reaction of the HMP pathway can be written as:

  • So, in a net reaction, a single glucose molecule is broken to glyceraldehyde-3-P and 3 CO2 and 6 NADPH.
  • Or, for a complete cycle with 3 glucose-6-P molecules, 6 NADPH are produced
  • Or we can say the final products of HMP are 6 NADPH

Option B, C and D: refer to explanation of A

questions.text: Polyol pathway plays an important role in meeting the energy requirements of sperm cells by which of the following conversions?
questions.solution:
Option A: Fructose from glucose

Sorbitol Pathway

  • This is a short pathway to synthesize fructose in the body via sorbitol. First, glucose is reduced to its alcohol, i.e., sorbitol (or glucitol), by the enzyme aldose reductase (the same enzyme which reduces galactose to galactitol).
  • Then sorbitol is oxidized to fructose by the enzyme sorbitol dehydrogenase.

 

 

  • This synthesis of fructose in the body is especially useful in seminal vesicles for sperms as they mainly use fructose as an energy source.
  • The reason for using fructose instead of glucose is fructose metabolism is faster than glucose.

Option B, C and D: Galactose from glucose and fructose and glucose from fructose

  • These reactions do not happens occur in the body.

questions.text: Which of the following is the major source of NADPH for fatty acid synthesis?
questions.solution:
Option A: HMP shunt

  • Reductases in fatty acid synthesis require NADPH as reducing power
  • Out of all the options, NADPH is produced by the HMP shunt only.
  • Insulin is lipogenic. It increases the production of enzymes in the HMP shunt.

 

Other minor pathways producing NADPH are:

  • The malic enzyme (NADP Malate Dehydrogenase)
  • Cytoplasmic Isocitrate dehydrogenase
  • Glutamate dehydrogenase

Option B: Tricarboxylic acid cycle (TCA)

  • The tricarboxylic acid cycle is a chemical reaction that takes place in mitochondria that releases energy by the oxidation of acetyl-CoA.
  • The energy released by this cycle is stored in the form of GTP, FADH2, and NADH.

Option C: Glycolysis

  • It is a reaction that splits glucose into pyruvate to extract energy.
  • It does not require any oxygen molecule.

Option D: Uronic acid pathway

  • It is used for the synthesis of glucuronic acid, pentose, ascorbic acid, and vitamins.
  • In this pathway, free sugar is involved.​​​​​​​​​​​​​​​​​​

questions.text: Different phases of an action potential include depolarization, initial repolarization, plateau, and rapid repolarization. At the end of repolarization, the nerve is hyperpolarized and reaches the resting membrane potential (RMP). Which of the following plays a role in returning membrane potential to resting membrane potential (RMP)?

choices.text: Closer of voltage gated K+ channels

questions.solution:
Option B: Closer of voltage-gated K+ channels

  • The action potential has different phases, including depolarization, initial repolarization and plateau (in some cells, e.g., cardiac cells), and rapid repolarization.
  • Depolarization is caused by the rapid influx of sodium ions inside the cell. Repolarization is caused by the efflux of potassium ions from the cell by voltage-gated potassium channels.
  • After repolarization, the action potential becomes more negative than the resting membrane potential due to the continuous efflux of potassium ions through the open voltage-gated potassium channels. This is called hyperpolarization, and it is because the potassium channels remain open for a prolonged period making the action potential more negative than the resting membrane potential (as positive ions continue to move out from the cell, making the membrane potential more negative).
  • These open voltage-gated potassium channels return to their closed state after hyperpolarization.
  • The slow return of the K+ channels to the closed state is responsible for hyperpolarization, followed by a return to the resting membrane potential. Thus, the action potential is brought to an end and causes the closure of their gates through a negative feedback process.

Option A: Action of Na+/ K+ -pump

  • In neurons, the concentration of K+ is much higher inside than outside the cell, while the concentration of Na+ is much higher outside than inside the cell. Na+-K+ ATPase establishes this concentration difference.
  • It causes three Na+ ions to move outside the cell in exchange for two K+ ions that move inside the cell, leaving a net deficit of positive ions on the inside; this causes a negative potential inside the cell membrane.
  • This Na+-K+ ATPase moves the ions against their concentration gradient (an example of active transport) and hence requires energy in the form of ATP.

Option C: Increase in K+ efflux

  • Potassium ion efflux is responsible for repolarizing and hyperpolarizing the action potential due to voltage-gated potassium channels in the open state.

Option D: None of the above mechanisms

  • The delayed closure of voltage-gated potassium channels is responsible for the hyperpolarization and the gradual return of the action potential towards the resting membrane potential after hyperpolarization.

questions.text: A neonate presents in a pediatric emergency because of feeding difficulty. The mother reports that he has been normal since birth until he stopped crying today. Mother has not had any prenatal visits or vaccinations. She gave birth to him with the help of a midwife. On physical examination, the baby is stiff, unable to cry, and has a foul-smelling umbilical stump. It is suspected that a bacterial toxin is responsible for his symptoms. Which of the following synaptic proteins is a target of this toxin?
questions.solution:
Option A: R-SNARE

  • This patient has tetanus.
  • Clostridium tetani cause tetanus
    • It is an anaerobic gram + rod
    • It produces a toxin called tetanospasmin toxin
  • Transmission
    • Transmission occurs through direct contact with contaminated soil.
  • Associated conditions
    • Tetanus
    • Neonatal tetanus
      • neonates are born to unvaccinated mothers.
      • It is characterised by the liability to suck or cry after 2 days
      • On physical exam, there is a foul-smelling umbilical stump.
  • Tetanus toxin cleaves synaptobrevin-2.
  • Synaptobrevin is an R-SNARE protein known as vesicle-associated membrane protein (VAMP).
  • Toxin prevents the release of inhibitory neurotransmitters (GABA and glycine) from Renshaw cells in the spinal cord.
  • Thus, there is spastic paralysis, risus sardonicus, and opisthotonus in tetanus.

Option B: Q-SNARE

  • Q-SNARE proteins are syntaxin (Qa), SNAP25 (Qb & Qc), and SM protein (Munc18).
  • Q-SNAREs contribute glutamine (Q) residue in forming the zero ionic layers in the assembled core SNARE complex.
  • Q-SNAREs include syntaxin and SNAP-25. It is not involved in tetanus.

Option C: SNAP25

  • SNAP25 (Qb & Qc) is a Q-SNARE protein.
  • Q-SNAREs contribute glutamine (Q) residue in forming the zero ionic layers in the assembled core SNARE complex. Hence it is not involved in the pathogenesis of tetanus.

Option D: Rab and Munc 18

  • Munc-18 binds syntaxin and forms a syntaxin/munc-18 complex which is thought to precede and regulate vesicle priming, a process mediated by VAMP, SNAP-25, and syntaxin.
  • Munc18-1, a member of the SM family, has multiple roles in exocytosis. Hence it is not involved in the pathogenesis of tetanus.

questions.text:
A 36-year-old female presented with diarrhea for the last 3 days while on vacation. On examination, she looked dehydrated, and her capillary fill was 3 seconds. Her vital signs are normal. On the chest, auscultations are S1 and S2 heart sounds and normal respiratory sounds. The following findings are given:

                                       


	
		
			
			Hemoglobin
			
			
			14
			
		
		
			
			WBCs           
			
			
			12,000/mm3
			
		
		
			
			ALT               
			
			
			52 U/L
			
		
		
			
			AST         
			
			
			39 U/L
			
		
		
			
			PH                 
			
			
			7.28
			
		
		
			
			Pco2             
			
			
			23 mm hg
			
		
		
			
			Bicarbonate   
			
			
			11 mEq/L
			
		
		
			
			Serum electrolytes
			
		
		
			
			Potassium =
			
			
			3.1 mEq/L
			
		
		
			
			Sodium =
			
			
			132 mEq/L
			
		
		
			
			Chloride=
			
			
			110 mEq/L
			
		
	


Which of the following is the correct diagnosis for this patient??
questions.solution:
Option A: Metabolic acidosis

  • This female presented with diarrhea for the last 3 days with low PH, low potassium, low sodium, and low bicarbonate and normal anion gap (anion gap= Na - ( K + Hco3), and has a most likely diagnosis of metabolic acidosis.
  • An acidic PH, along with decreased bicarbonate and decreased Pco2, is consistent with metabolic acidosis with respiratory compensation, e.g., hyperventilation.
  • The main causes of metabolic acidosis with normal anion gap are: Remember that
    • H for hyperchloremia
    • A for alimentation
    • A for Addison disease
    • R for renal tubular acidosis
    • D for diarrhea
    • A for acetazolamide
    • S for spironolactone
    • S for saline infusion
  • Diarrhea causes loss of bicarbonate, so that's why it causes metabolic acidosis.
  • The easiest way to find the cause of acidosis is first to check the pco2 and bicarbonates. If pco2 is more than 44 mmHg, it would be respiratory acidosis, or if bicarbonate is less than 20 mEq/L, it would be metabolic acidosis. If it is metabolic acidosis, then check the anion gap. If the gap is more than 12 mEq/L, it would be high anion gap metabolic acidosis, or if it is less than 12 mEq /L, it would be non-anion gap metabolic acidosis

Option B: Metabolic alkalosis

  • In metabolic acidosis, pH would be increased, and bicarbonate would also be increased, but in this patient, PH and bicarbonate are low.

Option C: Respiratory acidosis

  • In respiratory acidosis, the pH would be low, and pco2 would be greater than 44 mmHg, but in the patient, pco2 is very low, and pH is also low, so that's why this is not respiratory acidosis.

Option D: Respiratory alkalosis

  • In respiratory alkalosis, PCO2 should be less than 36 mmHg and pH greater than 7.45.

questions.text: Many regulatory hormones in the body mimic the sympathetic system (sympathomimetics) to control the body's important functions. There are two types of sympathomimetics, direct and indirect sympathomimetics. Direct sympathomimetics act directly on the receptors, while indirect sympathomimetics increase the level of several direct sympathomimetic hormones by acting as reuptake inhibitors. Which of the following compounds reduces the Regional arterial resistance of Mesentery and Kidney?
questions.solution:
Option A: Dopamine

  • Dopamine acts on D1 and D2 receptors, but they also have very little effect on beta and alpha receptors.
  • The D1 receptors in renal and mesenteric blood vessels are the most sensitive.
  • Intravenous infusion of a low dose of dopamine dilates these vessels (by raising intracellular cAMP).
  • Dopamine increases GFR; dopamine also exerts a natriuretic effect by D1 receptors on proximal tubules.
  •  They have dual effects depending on the doses. At a low dose,  it causes vasodilation (dilation of interlobular arteries, afferent arterioles, efferent arterioles).
  • At high doses, dopamine causes vasoconstriction through alpha receptors. It increases blood pressure at high doses and heart rate and cardiac output.
  • Proximal converted tubule cells secrete dopamine.
  • Dopamine is used clinically to treat unstable bradycardia and shock due to its inotropic and chronotropic properties at low doses; it increases blood pressure at high doses and increases heart rate and cardiac output.

Option B: Nor adrenaline

  •  Nor adrenaline is also known as norepinephrine.
  •  It mainly acts on alpha one receptors to increase blood pressure (due to increased arterial resistance) and decrease heart rate by reflex bradycardia, so it is clinically used to treat hypertension and shock.

Option C: Adrenaline

  • Adrenaline is also called epinephrine; it has more effect on beta receptors.
  • At high doses, it increases blood pressure due to alpha stimulation. It increases heart rate and cardiac output, so it is used clinically in treating asthma, anaphylactic shock, shock, and open-angle glaucoma.

Option D: Isoproterenol

  • Isoproterenol acts on beta 1 and beta 2 receptors, so it decreases blood pressure due to vasodilation. It increases heart rate and cardiac output by acting on beta 1 receptors.
  •  Dopamine should never use in myocardial infarction because it can exacerbate ischemia due to alpha effects.

questions.text: Which of the following is the correct pairing of its nuclei and respective function?

choices.text: Satiety center: lateral nucleus of the hypothalamus
Reward center: Ventromedial nucleus of the hypothalamus
Circadian rhythm: preoptic nuclei of the hypothalamus
Oxytocin secretion: paraventricular nuclei of the hypothalamus

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: Option D: Oxytocin secretion: paraventricular nuclei of the hypothalamus

  • Hypothalamus is the control center for the body, which maintains homeostasis in the body through its hormone secretions.
  • It is composed of three zones. One of its zones is the periventricular zone, and the other is lateral and medial.
  • These zones control and regulate specific functions.
  • Medial and lateral zones of the hypothalamus are concerned with autonomic and somatic functions.
  • The periventricular zone is concerned with the regulation of the endocrine system.
  • Hypothalamus is composed of multiple nuclei, which are responsible for multiple functions in the body.
  • The paraventricular and supraoptic nuclei serve the function of oxytocin secretion and ADH secretion.
  • The preoptic, anterior, and posterior nuclei serve the temperature regulation function.
  • The suprachiasmatic nucleus regulates the release of hormones, circadian rhythm, and behavior.
  • The ventromedial nucleus serves as the satiety center of the body.
  • Similarly, the dorsomedial nucleus regulates rage, and the medial forebrain bundle serves as the body's reward center.

Option A: Satiety center: lateral nucleus of the hypothalamus

The pair does not represent the correct pairing of the nucleus and respective function.

  • The ventromedial nucleus serves as the satiety center.
  • The lateral nucleus of the hypothalamus does not serve as the satiety center.

Option B: Reward center: Ventromedial nucleus of the hypothalamus

The pair does not represent the correct pairing of the nucleus and respective function.

  • The media forebrain bundle serves as the reward center.
  • The ventromedial nucleus of the hypothalamus does not serve as the reward center.

Option C: Circadian rhythm: preoptic nuclei of the hypothalamus

The pair does not represent the correct pairing of the nucleus and respective function.

  • The suprachiasmatic nucleus is involved in regulating circadian rhythm.
  • The preoptic nucleus of the hypothalamus is not involved in the regulation of circadian rhythm.

questions.text: Which stage among the following has the maximum contribution to the sleep time of an adult?
questions.solution:
Option C: NREM N2

  • The sleep cycle in a healthy human broadly consists of 2 phases. One is rapid eye movement sleep (REM) and non-rapid eye movement sleep (NREM).
  • Non-rapid eye movement sleep (NREM) consists of 3 stages:
    • Stage N1
    • Stage N2
    • Stage N3

NREM stage N1:

  • Constitutes 5% of the total sleep.
  • EEG shows theta waves (frequency 4-7 Hz).
  • Light sleep.
  • Characterized by myotonic contractions associated with a sensation of falling or twitching.

NREM stage N2:

  • Constitutes 45% of the total sleep.
  • EEG shows sleep spindle (short burst of waves with frequency 12-14 Hz) and K complexes (high amplitude, diphasic waves).
  • Deeper sleep.
  • Characterized by bruxism (tooth grinding).

NREM stage N3:

  • Constitutes 25% of the total sleep.
  • EEG shows delta waves (highest amplitude and low frequency 0-4 Hz).
  • Deepest sleep.
  • Characterized by bedwetting, sleepwalking, and night terrors.

Rapid eye movement sleep (REM):

  • Constitutes 25% of the total sleep.
  • EEG shows beta waves (highest frequency and lowest amplitude).
  • Characterized by atonia, nightmares, Penile/clitoral tumescence, memory processing, and increased heart rate.
  • It occurs every 90 minutes.

Option A: REM

  • REM phases constitute 25% of total sleep time

Option B: NREM N1

  • Stage 1 non-REM constitutes about 5% of the total sleep.

Option D: NREM N3

  • Stages 3 NREM constitutes about 25% of the total sleep.

questions.text: The fibrin-stabilizing factor is otherwise known as factor XIII. Fibrin-stabilizing factor causes covalent bonding between the fibrin monomer molecules and the adjacent fibrin threads, resulting in the strengthening of the fibrin meshwork. Which following will be seen in a patient with a congenital deficiency in factor XIII?
questions.solution:
Option D: Easily breakable clot

  • Fibrin monomers polymerize to form a clot.
  • Factor XIII (fibrin stabilizing factor): It stabilizes the clot; >5% of activity requires to form a normal clot and helps in wound repair and healing.
  • Creating a strong clot requires the presence of a fibrin-stabilizing factor released from platelets within the clot.
  • The other clotting tests determine the activation of extrinsic and intrinsic pathways or the number of platelets.
  • The fibrin meshwork is strengthened by fibrin – stabilizing factor (FSF).
  • The FSF is an enzyme in small amounts in plasma; it is also released by the platelets entrapped in the clot.
  • Fibrin-stabilizing factor causes covalent bonding between the fibrin monomer molecules and the adjacent fibrin threads, resulting in the strengthening of the fibrin meshwork.
  • Factor XIII (FXIII) deficiency is a rare congenital bleeding disorder.

Option A: Prolonged prothrombin time

  • Prothrombin helps blood clot.
  • The prothrombin time (PT) measures how long it takes blood to form a clot.
  • The prothrombin time can be prolonged due to deficiencies in vitamin K, warfarin therapy, malabsorption, or lack of intestinal colonization by bacteria (such as in newborns).

Option B: Prolonged whole blood clotting time

  • Clotting time is prolonged when the defect is in platelets.

Option C: Prolonged partial thromboplastin time

  • When the extrinsic pathway is defective, the prothrombin time is prolonged.​​​​​​​

questions.text:
A 21-year-old woman presents in the emergency with prolonged bleeding during a dental procedure 3 hours ago. She has been unable to control bleeding since then. On inquiring further, she says that she suffered from frequent nosebleeds and profuse bleeding from minor cuts during her childhood. She has a history of heavy menstrual flow as well. The laboratory tests show increased bleeding time and abnormal ristocetin cofactor assay. The coagulation profile reveals an increased PTT but a normal PT. 

Which of the following is not responsible for synthesizing the factor deficient in the etiology of this patient’s presentation?
questions.solution:
Option C: Hepatocytes

  • In the clinical scenario above, the patient has von-Willebrand disease due to a deficiency of the von-Willebrand factor. An autosomal dominant disorder causes an intrinsic pathway coagulation defect and defective platelet plug formation.
  • Clinical findings most commonly include epistaxis and hematomas. Prolonged bleeding from minor cuts, oral cavities, and heavy menstrual flow are also common. Lab value shows increased bleeding time, PTT, and abnormal ristocetin cofactor assay but normal PT and platelet count.
  • The von-Willebrand factor is a glycoprotein that circulates in the blood plasma. It is synthesized and released from the storage granules in endothelial cells (main source) and platelets.
  • It plays a significant role, firstly, in the adhesion of platelets to sites of vascular injury and, secondly, in the binding and stabilization of factor 8 in the intrinsic coagulation pathway.
  • The liver is responsible for synthesizing many clotting factors such as factors 2, 7, 9, 10, protein C, and protein S. These are present in their inactive forms and are activated in the presence of vitamin K in the liver. Factor 8, however, is not synthesized in the liver. It has two components:
    1. Factor 8c (coagulant factor 8): Synthesized in the liver (main source) and kidney.
    2. Von Willebrand factor (vWF): Synthesized in the endothelium (main source) and megakaryocytes.

Option A: Endothelial cells

  • Von Willebrand factor is a multimeric glycoprotein in blood plasma, sub-endothelial matrix, and the Weibel-Palade bodies in the endothelial cells. This factor is released from the storage granules in endothelium in response to vascular injury.

Option B: Megakaryocytes

  • Von Willebrand factor is a glycoprotein circulating in the blood plasma. It is present in the alpha granules of megakaryocytes and released in response to tissue injury to take part in the intrinsic coagulation pathway and platelet plug formation at the sites of vascular injury.

Option D: None

  • Von Willebrand factor is synthesized, stored in granules, and then released from the endothelium and platelets. However, hepatocytes are not responsible for synthesizing the von Willebrand factor.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions increase the serum levels of thyroxine-binding globulin (TBG) in the body?
questions.solution:
Option C: Pregnancy

  • The thyroid cells are typical protein-secreting glandular cells.
  • Thyroglobulin is a glycoprotein made up of two subunits and has a molecular weight of 660 kDa.
  • It contains 10% carbohydrates by weight.
  • It also contains 123 tyrosine residues, but only 4–8 of these are normally incorporated into thyroid hormones.
  • Thyroglobulin is synthesized in the thyroid cells and secreted into the colloid by exocytosis of granules.

TBG concentration increases in (conditions of high estrogen levels) such as:

  • Pregnancy
  • Oral contraceptives.

Option A: Glucocorticoid therapy

  • Serum TBG levels are decreased by glucocorticoid therapy.

Option B: Nephrotic Syndrome

  • Nephrotic syndrome is characterized by protein-losing nephropathy, thus reducing serum levels of different plasma proteins, including TBG.

Choice D: Cancer chemotherapy

  • Cancer chemotherapy also decreases plasma levels of TBG.

questions.text: Which of the following hormones do Osteoclasts have specific receptors for?
questions.solution:
Option B: Calcitonin

  • Calcitonin is a hormone produced by the thyroid gland that acts opposite to PTH and regulates blood calcium levels by decreasing it.
  • Osteoclasts cells also contain their Receptors get inhibited by this process.
  • The binding of this hormone causes osteoclasts inhibition and helps prevent bone resorption, and decreases blood calcium levels.

Option A: Parathyroid hormone

  • Parathyroid hormone is a hormone produced by the parathyroid glands and helps increase calcium levels in the blood and works in antagonism to calcitonin.

Option C: Thyroxin

  • Thyroxin is a hormone also known as T4 that is produced by the thyroid gland and helps in regulating various metabolic activities of the body but has no receptors on osteoclast cells.

Option D: Vitamin D3

  • Vit D3 is a type of activated vitamin D that helps in maintaining body calcium levels and helps mineralisation of bones and maintains bone mass. But its receptors are not present on osteoclast cells.

questions.text: In which of these locations is the sodium-iodide symporter not present?
questions.solution:
Option D: Ovaries.

Sodium-iodide symporter:

  • The sodium-iodide symporter (NIS) is responsible for thyroidal, salivary, gastric, intestinal, and mammary iodide uptake.
  • NIS is an integral plasma membrane glycoprotein that mediates the active transport of iodide into the cells of various body organs.
  • It co-transports two sodium ions and one iodide, with the transmembrane sodium gradient as the driving force for iodide uptake.
  • The sodium-potassium ATPase pump generates the energy for this.

Option A: Thyroid glands

 

 

  • Sodium-iodide symporter is present in thyroid glands.
  • It helps to transport iodides from the blood into the thyroid glandular cells and follicles due to the ability of the basal membrane of the thyroid cell to pump iodide actively to the interior of the cell. This is achieved by the action of the sodium-iodide symporter (NIS), which co-transports one iodide ion along with two sodium ions across the basolateral plasma membrane into the cell. The energy for this process is driven by the sodium-potassium ATPase pump.
  • Concentrating the iodide, called iodide trapping, is an important process in synthesizing thyroid hormones.
  • TSH in the thyroid glands regulates the sodium iodide symporter expression.

Option B: Mammary glands

  • Sodium iodide symporter is present in mammary glands.
  • It is expressed in the normal breast only late in pregnancy and during lactation. Lactation is critical as milk is the only source of iodide ions for the newborn.
  • The sodium iodide symporter expression is regulated by oxytocin, prolactin, and estrogen in the mammary glands.

Option C: Placenta

  • Sodium-iodide symporter is present in the placenta.
  • In placenta. NIS is expressed at the apical membrane of cytotrophoblasts. It regulates the transport of iodide ions from the maternal to the fetal circulation, a process critical for normal fetal thyroid function.
  • The presence of sodium-iodide symporter has been reported in the human placental endometrial glands during the first trimester of pregnancy. Also, it has been reported in postmenopausal and sterile women but to a lesser extent in fertile women. Therefore, it can be used as a biomarker for distinguishing between sterile and fertile endometrial mucosa.

questions.text: Afferent fibers in the auditory department of the eighth CN end in the dorsal and ventral cochlea nuclei, from there the auditory impulses reach the inferior colliculi, the centers of the auditory reflexes, and via the corpus geniculatum mediale in the thalamus to the auditory cortex, which is located in?
questions.solution:
• The auditory cortex (areas 41 & 42) is located in the superior temporal gyrus in the temporal lobe.
  • Postcentral gyrus: In the parietal lobe there is the somatosensory cortex (S I) – areas 3, 1, and 2.
  • Posterior parietal cortex (PPC): Posterior to the S I, this area harbors S II (areas 5 & 7). It receives inputs from S I, and visual & auditory cortices. The area is concerned with visuospatial orientation and the performance of a planned movement.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents with vaginal bleeding lasting longer than her usual menstrual period. She's been taking warfarin for a year and recently started another medication. There were no significant findings on examination. Which drug might be causing her symptoms?
questions.solution:
Option B: Sulphonamide

  • This is a case of warfarin-induced bleeding in which the patient presents with complaints of vaginal bleeding for five days. She further explains that the bleeding was for a prolonged period of time than her usual number of days in her regular menses.
  • She has been on warfarin for the past year. She also gives a history that also took some medication recently before the symptoms appeared.
  • The patient is otherwise vitally stable, and other general physical examination reveals no abnormalities.
  • These are those drugs which inhibit cytochrome 450 and increase the half-life of warfarin, resulting in increased bleeding. Sulphonamides don't allow the degradation of warfarin which results in increased bleeding.

 

 Option A: Phenytoin

  • Phenytoin is a voltage-gated sodium channel blocker. 
  • The drugs which inhibit cytochrome 450 are the drugs which increase the half-life of warfarin and thus can induce bleeding.

 

Option C: Rifampicin

  • Rifampicin inhibits DNA-dependent RNA polymerase.
  • It is an enzyme inducer and hence is not responsible for the condition mentioned in the case above.

 

Option D: Carbamazepine

  • Carbamazepine is an enzyme inducer and hence not responsible for warfarin-induced bleeding.
  • It decreases the half-life of warfarin, leading to decreased activity.

questions.text: A 56-year-old patient with heart failure currently on digoxin therapy presents to the emergency department with blurred vision and yellow-green distortion. The plasma digoxin level is 4 ng/ml(normal 0.8- 2.0). Renal function is normal; this patient's plasma t1/2 for digoxin is 1.6 days. How long should digoxin be withheld to reach a safer yet probably therapeutic level of 1 ng/ml?
questions.solution:
• The patient has digitalis toxicity as the digoxin serum levels are high, and he's experiencing visual disturbances.
  • Elimination of digoxin follows first-order kinetics, i.e. the constant fraction of drugs is eliminated per unit of time, and the half-life remains constant.
  •  The time required to decrease the plasma concentration of digoxin from 4 ng/ml to 1 ng/ml will take approximately two half-lives (From 4 ng/ml to 2 ng/ml in one half-life and from 2 ng/ml to 1 ng/ml in second half-life). Thus, the time required will be two × t½, i.e., two × 1.6 = 3.2 days.
  • Half-life is the time required to change the drug in the body by half during elimination. For drugs following first-order kinetics, the clearance and plasma half-life remains constant.
  • In such drugs, nearly complete drug elimination occurs in 4-5 half-lives.
Number of half-lives 1 2 3 4
Percentage of drug remaining 50% 25% 12.5% 6.25%

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is not generally used for long-term therapy in Heart Failure with reduced Ejection Fraction (HFrEF)?
questions.solution:
Option C: Dobutamine

  • Acute decompensated HF presents with worsening signs and symptoms of HF, including dyspnea on exertion, orthopnea, paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea (PND), and peripheral oedema.
  • In the given scenario, long-term therapy is needed, and dobutamine is primarily used in the short-term treatment of acute HF as an intravenous infusion.
  • Dobutamine is the selective β1 agonist widely used in acutely decompensated heart failure patients.
  • It is used in acute heart failure because it causes an increase in cardiac output with a decrease in ventricular filling pressure.
  • It does not significantly elevate the oxygen demands of the myocardium and improves cardiac performance by causing a positive inotropic effect.
  • Intermittent dobutamine infusion may benefit some patients with chronic heart failure.

Option A: Digoxin

  • Digoxin is a cardiac glycoside which comes from the digitalis (foxglove) plant.
  • It increases the contractility of cardiac muscles without a proportionate increase in oxygen consumption and, therefore, is used in managing heart failure.
  • Cardiac glycosides are one of the drugs used as maintenance therapy for chronic heart failure.

Option B: Ramipril

  • Ramipril is a drug of class ACE inhibitors which reduces both preload and afterload, thereby reducing cardiac work.
  • It may be considered for patients with asymptomatic and symptomatic HFrEF.
  • It is indicated in all cases of left ventricular failure and must be considered along with diuretics as first-line therapy for chronic heart failure.

Option D: Spironolactone

  • Spironolactone, an aldosterone antagonist, is a synthetic steroid that antagonizes aldosterone activity, resulting in the retention of K+ and excretion of Na+.
  • Its principal action in heart failure is to reduce venous pressure and ventricular preload.
  • It decreases preload and improves ventricular efficiency by reducing circulating volume.
  • It decreases morbidity and mortality in patients with severe heart failure who receive ACE inhibitors and other standard therapy.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is used in treatment of Congestive heart failure and can cause vasodilation and increased cardiac output?
questions.solution:
Option C: Amrinone

  • This is a case of congestive heart failure.
  • Amrinone is a bipyridine compound that inhibits phosphodiesterase isozyme-3 (PDE3).
  • The two most important actions of amrinone are positive inotropy and direct vasodilatation.
  • It is also known as an inodilator which increases myocardial contractility by increasing inward calcium influx in the heart during action potential and brings about vasodilatation.
  • In CHF patients, it increases left ventricular ejection fraction and decreases peripheral vascular resistance, central venous pressure, left ventricular end-diastolic volume and pressure.
  • It is used as a short-term therapy in severe and refractory CHF.

Option A: Spironolactone

  • Spironolactone is an aldosterone antagonist considered to be one of the potassium-sparing diuretics.
  • Its principal action in heart failure is to reduce venous pressure and ventricular preload.
  • It decreases preload and improves ventricular efficiency by reducing circulating volume.
  • It decreases morbidity and mortality in patients with severe heart failure.

Option B: Amiodarone

  • Amiodarone is included in class III antiarrhythmics that prolong the duration of action potential and the refractory period by blocking K+ channels.
  • It is effective in the treatment of severe refractory supraventricular and ventricular tachyarrhythmias.

Option D: Carvedilol

  • Carvedilol is a non-selective beta blocker and selective alpha-1 blocking agent.
  • It is indicated in mild to moderate CHF.
  • The immediate hemodynamic action of β blockers is to depress cardiac contractility and ejection fraction.

questions.text: Which of the following antihyperlipidemic drugs exerts its effects through the inhibition of PCSK9?
questions.solution:
Option C: Alirocumab

  • In the above case, the features are suggestive of hypercholesterolemia for which we use PCSK9 inhibitors such as Alirocumab.
  • Monoclonal antibodies that target PCSK9: Alirocumab and Evolocumab.
  • Proprotein convertase subtilisin Kexin type 9 (PCSK9) is a protein that binds LDL receptors and transports them to lysosomes, where these are degraded.
  • Therefore instead of recycling LDL receptors to the surface of hepatocytes, they get destroyed.
  • Inhibitors of PCSK9, therefore, prevent the destruction of LDL receptors resulting in the lowering of LDL cholesterol.

Option A: Reslizumab

  • It is an interleukin-5 antagonist monoclonal antibody. IL-5 is the major cytokine responsible for the growth and differentiation, recruitment, activation, and survival of eosinophils.
  • The most common adverse effect of reslizumab is oropharyngeal (mouth and throat) pain.

Option B: Brodalumab

  • It is a human monoclonal antibody designed for the treatment of inflammatory diseases.
  • Brodalumab binds to the interleukin-17 receptor and so prevents interleukin 17 (IL-17) from activating the receptor.

Option D: Ixekizumab

  • It is an injectable medication for the treatment of autoimmune diseases.
  • The substance acts by binding interleukin 17A and neutralizing it, reducing inflammation.
  • The most common side effects include upper respiratory infections, injection site reactions and fungal (tinea) infections.

questions.text: What items are essential to have on hand in an emergency situation when administering opioids to a patient?
questions.solution:
Option B: Naloxone

  • The complaints of lower abdominal pain at term suggest labour pains. The patient is given Tramadol (opioid analgesic), and its effect can be reversed by giving Naloxone.
  • Naloxone is an opioid antagonist given intravenously.
  • It blocks mu, kappa, and delta receptors.
  • It is the drug of choice for opioid toxicity.
  • Tramadol is an atypical opioid that relieves pain. It is a µ opioid receptor agonist and relieves pain. Its affinity for µ opioid receptor is low, while that for K and delta is very low.
  • Unlike other opioids, it inhibits the reuptake of NA and 5-HT, increases 5-HT release, and thus activates monoaminergic spinal inhibition of pain (descending inhibitory pathway), which relieves pain.
  • The opioid antagonist naloxone only partially reverses its analgesic action.

Option A: Lignocaine

  • Lignocaine belongs to the aminoamide class of local anaesthetics.
  • It is used as an anaesthetic lubricant.
  • Lignocaine is also indicated in ventricular arrhythmia.
  • It is not indicated in the reversal of opioid effects.

Option C: Diphenhydramine

  • Diphenhydramine is a first generation antihistaminic.
  • It temporarily relieves symptoms of hay fever, upper respiratory allergies, and the common cold.
  • It works by blocking histamine in the body.
  • It does not have opioid antagonist properties.

Option D: Fentanyl

  • Fentanyl is a synthetic opioid. It doe not have any opioid antagonist effect.
  • Indications for fentanyl include:
    • Preoperative analgesia
    • Anaesthesia adjunct
    • Regional anaesthesia adjunct
    • General anaesthesia
    • Postoperative pain control

questions.text: In which of the following patients' morphine is safe to use?

choices.text: Elderly male patients with benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH)

questions.solution:
Option A: Ischemic heart disease patients

  • Morphine is an opioid analgesic which exerts its effects by agonism of mu-opioid receptors.
  • It is used as an analgesic agent in cardiac pain.
  • Visceral, dull and constant pain is relieved more effectively than inflammatory pain.
  • Morphine is a part of the MONA therapy used in the emergency management of myocardial infarction, which can lead to acute left ventricular failure.
  • Intravenous morphine is also useful in pulmonary oedema due to acute left ventricular failure.

Option B: Bronchial asthma patients

  • Morphine is contraindicated in asthma as it can cause respiratory depression.
  • It may also aggravate bronchoconstriction in asthmatics by releasing histamine.

Option C: Elderly male patients

  • Morphine is contraindicated in extremes of age, i.e. young children and the elderly.

Option D: Biliary colic patients

  • Morphine is contraindicated in biliary colic as it can worsen the pain of biliary colic by increasing intrabiliary pressure

questions.text: Which of the following antidiabetic drugs can cause Vitamin B12 deficiency on routine consumption?
questions.solution:
Option C: Metformin

  • Metformin is a drug that is given to people with type 2 diabetes to control their high blood sugar levels. When someone has this type  2 diabetes, the insulin made by the pancreas can't get sugar into the body's cells, which is what insulin needs to do its job.
  • When a person's blood sugar level is too high, taking metformin alone, with a certain type of oral diabetes medicine called a sulfonylurea, or in addition to insulin will help to lower the blood sugar level and help the body use the food it eats to make energy again.
  • Lactic acidosis(more with phenformin) and megaloblastic anaemia (more with metformin) due to vitamin B12 deficiency are the major adverse effects of biguanides.
  • Lactic acidosis is more likely to occur in the presence of hepatic and renal impairment or alcohol ingestion.
  • Other contraindications include cardiac failure and chronic hypoxic lung disease.
  • Metformin is also useful for polycystic ovarian disease(PCOD).
  • Metformin is the only oral agent that has been demonstrated to reduce macrovascular events in type 2 DM.

Option A: Glipizide

  • Glipizide does not reduce the absorption of vitamin B12 from the intestine.

Option B: Acarbose

  • Acarbose does not reduce the absorption of vitamin B12 from the intestine.

Option D: Pioglitazone

  • Pioglitazone does not reduce the absorption of vitamin B12 from the intestine.

questions.text: A 41-year-old female presents to the outdoor patient department with complaints of increased frequency of urination and increased thirst. Her BSR chart shows that her postprandial glucose levels are in the range of 400-500 mg/dL. The doctor prescribes her a drug to take during the first part of the meal. Which of the following drugs is taken during the first part of the meal for the purpose of delaying the absorption of dietary carbohydrates?
questions.solution:
Option A: Acarbose

  • Acarbose is a complex oligosaccharide that inhibits both membrane-bound intestinal alpha-glucoside hydrolase and pancreatic alpha-amylase in a manner that is both competitive and reversible. Alpha-amylase originates in the pancreas and is secreted into the small intestine, where it is responsible for hydrolysing complex carbohydrates into oligosaccharides. 
  • An enzyme known as intestinal alpha-glucosidase hydrolase is responsible for converting oligosaccharides, trisaccharides, and disaccharides (such as sucrose and maltose) into monosaccharides. 
  • This conversion takes place in the brush border of the small intestine (such as glucose and fructose). Because it causes a delay in the digestion of carbohydrates, acarbose is effective in lowering the amount of glucose that is absorbed after a meal. Because of this, the amount of glucose that is present in the blood after a meal is reduced.
  • Glipizide is a sulphonylurea of the second generation that assists in the body's natural production of insulin.
  • The metabolic production of glucose is inhibited by the biguanide drug metformin.
  • Exenatide is a GLP-1 analogue that delays stomach emptying, reduces hunger, and increases glucose output.

Option B: Glipizide

  • Glipizide is a second-generation sulphonylurea which helps in the secretion of insulin.

Option C: Metformin

  • Metformin is a biguanide which decreases the synthesis of glucose.

Option D: Exenatide

  • Exenatide is a GLP-1 analogue that delays gastric emptying, decreases appetite, and increases glucose secretion.

questions.text: A 34-year-old female patient is a known case of epilepsy. She has been prescribed phenytoin to control her seizures. After getting into a fight with her husband, she takes the whole bottle of pills. High plasma drug concentrations of phenytoin can cause which of the following adverse effects?
questions.solution:
Option A: Ataxia

  • Phenytoin is an anti-epileptic drug which functions by blocking Na+ channels.

  • It is mainly used in the treatment of focal (partial) seizures.

  • It is also used as the 1st line drug for prophylaxis of recurrent status epilepticus.

  • Cerebellar dysfunction, i.e., ataxia, nystagmus, vertigo, diplopia, and sedation, is seen at toxic plasma concentrations.

Option B: Gum hyperplasia

  • The major side effects of phenytoin that occurs at therapeutic doses but with prolonged use include;

    • Gingival hyperplasia

    • Hirsutism

    • Pseudolymphoma

    • Fetal hydantoin syndrome

    • Cytochrome P-450 induction

    • Yellow-brown discolouration of the skin

    • Osteopenia

    • Inhibited folate absorption

    • Neuropathy

Option C: Steven-Johnson syndrome

  • Steven-Johnson syndrome, DRESS syndrome, and drug-induced lupus occur at therapeutic doses of phenytoin but with prolonged use but occur very rarely.

  • Steven-Johnson syndrome is commonly caused as a side effect of lamotrigine.

Option D: All of the above

  • Although all of the mentioned options are side effects of phenytoin, only cerebellar dysfunction occurs due to phenytoin toxicity. All others occur at therapeutic doses but with prolonged use

questions.text: A 35-year-old male was brought into the emergency department after he was found to have fits. After taking a clear history, it is evident that it was a focal seizure and he had only one prior seizure episode. Liver function tests and renal function tests turned out to be normal. Which of the following drugs is the drug of choice for such seizures?
questions.solution:
Option D: Carbamazepine

  • Carbamazepine and oxcarbazepine (related drugs), phenytoin, lamotrigine and topiramate are currently the drugs of choice approved for the initial treatment of partial seizures, including those that secondarily generalise.
  • Overall they have very similar efficacy.
  • However, differences in pharmacokinetics and toxicity are the main determinants for use in a given patient.
  • Carbamazepine's metabolism follows first-order pharmacokinetics, and the relationship between drug dose, serum levels, and toxicity is linear. 
  • Oxcarbazepine
    • Keto analogue of carbamazepine
    • Advantage of being metabolised (glucuronide conjugation) in a way that avoids an intermediate metabolite associated with some of the side effects of carbamazepine.
    • The potency of enzyme induction is less.
    • Fewer drug interactions than carbamazepine.

Option A: Valproate

  • Valproate is an anticonvulsant that increases Na+ channel inactivation and GABA concentration by inhibiting GABA transaminase.
  • It is generally used for tonic-clonic seizures but can be used for treating partial (focal).
  • It is the drug of choice for absence seizures in India.
  • It is also used for prophylaxis for migraines, myoclonic seizures, and bipolar disorder.

Option B: Pregabalin

  • Pregabalin and the antiepileptic medication gabapentin share molecular similarities, and both treatments act on the alpha2-delta protein, a supporting subunit of voltage-gated calcium channels.
  • Pregabalin treats epilepsy, neuropathic pain, fibromyalgia, restless leg syndrome, opioid withdrawal, and generalised anxiety disorder. Pregabalin has antiallodynic effects as well.
  • Dizziness, tiredness, difficulty concentrating, fuzzy vision, dry mouth, weight gain, and swelling of the hands or feet are the most typical side effects of pregabalin.
  • If these side effects are minor, they can disappear in a few days or weeks.

Option C: Levetiracetam

  • Levetiracetam is an antiepileptic medication that binds to SV2A, a synaptic vesicle integral membrane protein that acts as a positive activator of synaptic vesicle exocytosis.
  • The vesicle-bound neurotransmitter SV2A inhibits glutamate's release, which is an excitatory neurotransmitter.
  • Levetiracetam is commonly used to treat focal seizures, generalised tonic-clonic seizures, and juvenile myoclonic epilepsy.Weight gain, double vision, double dipping, GI distress or nausea, agitation, disorientation, anxiety, and imbalance.
  • Independent of a clinical history of a psychiatric illness, adverse behavioural reactions such as anger, violence, and suicidal thoughts and behaviours are also observed.

questions.text: A 60-year-old lady presents to the outpatient department with complaints of nausea, bloating, and heartburn for three months. She has been a known case of diabetes mellitus for ten years and is noncompliant with her medicine. Her random blood sugar is 300 mg/dL. The physician, mindful of her advanced age, prescribes a prokinetic agent. To mitigate the risk of extrapyramidal side effects, which medication should be avoided?
questions.solution:
Option A: Metoclopramide

  • In this case, the patient has long-standing diabetes mellitus, which has resulted in diabetic gastroparesis. She has chronic symptoms suggesting acid reflux, nausea and bloating due to delayed gastric emptying.
  • Metoclopramide is a pro-kinetic agent frequently used for GERD and diabetic gastroparesis.
  • It crosses the blood-brain barrier and causes extrapyramidal symptoms like muscular dystonia and tardive dyskinesia.
  • Other side effects include hyperprolactinemia, depression, neuroleptic malignant syndrome, hypertension and fluid retention.
  • Physicians should use it with caution in neonates due to the increased risk of methemoglobinemia.
  • Its mechanism of action involves blocking 5 HT3 receptors. It increases antral contraction, relaxes the pyloric sphincter, increases peristalsis and facilitates gastric emptying.
  • In gastroparesis, it increases the sensitivity of gut tissue to acetylcholine.

Option B: Domperidone

  • Domperidone is a dopamine antagonist used for the symptomatic relief of nausea and vomiting.
  • It is the drug of choice for vomiting induced by levodopa.
  • It can result in lightheadedness, disorientation and difficulty in speaking.

Option C: Cisapride

  • 5-10mg orally is used to treat dysfunctional gastrointestinal motility.
  • Side effects include nausea, bloating, blurred vision, joint pain, headache, itching, rash and muscle pain.

Option D: Erythromycin

  • It is a macrolide antibiotic that can be used to treat gastric dysmotility.
  • Side effects include abdominal pain, jaundice, low blood pressure, diarrhoea and itching.

questions.text: An 18-year-old girl is brought to the clinic for a physical examination before participating in sports. She is on the school's cheerleading team and is preparing for an upcoming competition. Menarche was at 12 years of age, and her last menstrual period was 3 months ago. She is 167 cm (5 ft 5 in) tall and weighs 44 kg (99 lb). Examination shows pale skin with thin, soft body hair. A diagnosis of anorexia nervosa is made. Which of the following features differentiate anorexia nervosa from bulimia nervosa?
questions.solution:
Option D: Peculiar patterns of food handling

  • Unlike bulimia, patients with anorexia remain preoccupied with food and show peculiar behavior like hiding food in the house, trying to dispose of food in napkins, cutting food into very small pieces, and rearranging the food around the plate.
  • Features of anorexia nervosa:
  • Significant deliberate reduction in body mass (as measured by BMI) using strategies that include restrictive eating, purging, and excessive exercise
  • Fear of weight gain motivates compensatory behavior that promotes weight loss, even if the patient already has low body weight.
  • Body image disturbance
  • Excessive concern about weight and body shape, despite being considerably underweight
  • Lack of awareness of the seriousness of low body weight

Option A: Intense fear of weight gain

  • Common features of anorexia nervosa and bulimia nervosa are:
  1. Intense fear of weight gain.
  2. Body image distortion.
  3. Adolescence age of onset.

Option B: Disturbance of body image

  • Disturbance of the body image is a common feature of anorexia nervosa and bulimia nervosa.

Option C: Adolescent age

  • Both anorexia nervosa and bulimia nervosa after adolescent age in onset

questions.text: A 39-year-old female presents to the emergency department due to altered sensorium and hypotension. She has been a known case of major depressive disorder for 2 years. She is being treated with amitriptyline. A cardiac monitor attached shows wide QRS complexes and right axis deviation. Which of the following is the next step in managing this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer:Option A: Sodium bicarbonate

  • TCAs include amitriptyline, nortriptyline, imipramine, amoxapine, doxepin, and desipramine.
  • TCAs block the transporter site for norepinephrine and serotonin, thus increasing their synaptic concentrations.
  • Secondary effects include antagonism at the muscarinic acetylcholine, histamine H1, alpha 1, and alpha 2 receptors.
  • TCAs are used for major depressive disorder, obsessive-compulsive disorder, generalized anxiety disorder, panic disorder, agoraphobia, neuropathic pain, childhood enuresis, narcolepsy, nightmare disorder, and post traumatic stress disorder.
  • Side effects resulting from the antagonism include:
    • Constipation
    • Sedation
    • Dry mouth
    • Lightheadedness
    • Blurred vision
    • Delirium
    • Urinary retention
    • Orthostatic hypotension
    • Tachycardia
    • Q-T prolongation
    • Myoclonic twitches and tremors of the tongue
    • Exanthematous rashes
  • It may aggravate narrow-angle glaucoma, which requires emergency treatment.
  • Switch to mania or hypomania can also occur with the use of TCAs.
  • Amoxapine may lead to symptoms of Parkinson’s disease.
  • Clomipramine and amoxapine lower the seizure threshold.
  • TCAs interact with monoamine oxidase inhibitors, beta-blockers, dopamine receptor antagonists, opioids, alcohol, anxiolytics, hypnotics, over-the-counter cold medications, sympathomimetic drugs, oral contraceptives, and nicotine.
  • TCAs should not be taken within 14 days of monoamine oxidase inhibitors administration.
  • Q-T prolongation is one of the side effects of TCAs. It presents as hypotension and tachycardia, and arrhythmias.

.

  • TCAs inhibit fast sodium channels in the His-Purkinje tissue and the myocardium to decrease conduction speed, increase phase 0 depolarization, and prolong the refractory period. This can prolong the QRS interval and cause arrhythmias.
  • TCAs decrease calcium influx into the myocardium and increase vasodilation leading to hypotension.
  • TCA overdose also causes acidemia and a mild increase in serum potassium.
  • Sodium bicarbonate is the most effective agent for managing TCA-induced cardiotoxic effects. It increases serum pH and extracellular sodium. The increased pH modifies TCAs to their neutral form, making them less available to bind to the rapid sodium channels. The elevated extracellular sodium increases the electrochemical gradient across cardiac cells and affects TCAs' ability to bind to the fast sodium channels.
  • Patients refractory to sodium bicarbonate are treated with magnesium or lidocaine.

Option B: Hemodialysis

  • QRS prolongation by TCAs overdose is corrected with sodium bicarbonate.
  • Hemodialysis is ineffective because of the large volume of distribution and high protein binding of TCAs.

Option C: Fomepizole

  • Fomepizole is the treatment of ethylene glycol or methanol poisoning.
  • It does not affect TCAs overdose.

Option D: Flumazenil

  • Flumazenil is a selective GABA receptor antagonist.
  • It is used for the reversal of the sedative effects of benzodiazepines.
  • It has no role in the reversal of TCAs effects.

questions.text: Paranoid psychosis has been described in a 60-year-old man who had first begun to use the substance 6 months before. The paranoid symptoms continued for 3 weeks after he stopped using it. The author suggested that the man’s age may have made him particularly sensitive to the psychiatric effects of :
questions.solution:
• Paranoid Delusions are false, fixed beliefs that someone is going to harm him or his belongings, even when there's strong evidence they aren't.
  • Paranoid delusions, also called delusions of persecution, reflect profound fear and anxiety along with the loss of the ability to tell what's real and what's not real.

HOW TO REMEMBER: cocaine is at PAR than other drugs in cost. It demands a price more than money. So, it gives you PARanoid delusions. or coCAIN Punishes you with Paranoid delusions.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man comes to the office with a 3-week history of fatigue, sleeping difficulty, loss of interest in things he loved, decreased appetite, and depressed mood. The physician diagnosed him with major depressive disorder and prescribed him first-line treatment. The patient is extremely worried about taking a pill as he has read on the internet that some medications for depression can cause sexual dysfunction. Which of the following antidepressants is least likely to have sexual side effects?
questions.solution:
Option B: Bupropion

Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) are the first-line treatment for major depressive disorder. They work by inhibiting the reuptake of serotonin in the synaptic cleft.

Examples of SSRIs include:

  • Fluoxetine
  • Paroxetine
  • Sertraline
  • Citalopram

The side effects of SSRIs include

  • ​​​​​​​Sexual dysfunction
    • Decrease libido
    • Delayed ejaculation
    • Anorgasmia
  • Nausea
  • Vomiting
  • Insomnia
  • SIADH
  • Headache
  • Serotonin syndrome 

Mirtazapine and bupropion have a relatively low risk of causing sexual side effects compared to other antidepressants.

Option A: Sertraline

  • SSRI.
  • Causes sexual dysfunction.

Option C: Fluoxetine

  • SSRI.
  • Causes sexual dysfunction.

Option D: Citalopram

  • SSRI.
  • Causes sexual dysfunction ​​​​​​​

questions.text: Which among the following statements is true about the tail wagging of a bullet?

choices.text: Bullet rotates end-to-end during its path
Causes the tattooing around the entry wound
Seen when the bullet leaves the muzzle at the beginning of its flight
Seen when the bullet loses its velocity near the termination of its flight

questions.solution:
Option C: Seen when the bullet leaves the muzzle at the beginning of its flight

  • Tail wobble/Tail wagging occurs for a few microseconds after a bullet exits the muzzle.

Option A: Bullet rotates end-to-end during its path

  • Tumbling bullet: Bullet rotates end-to-end during its path.

Option B: Causes the tattooing around the entry wound

  • Evidence of burning, singeing, blackening, and tattooing of the skin in and around the entry wound can be seen in a Close Shot (Flame Range).

Option D: Seen when the bullet loses its velocity near the termination of its flight

  • Tail wobble/Tail wagging occurs for a few microseconds after a bullet exits the muzzle, and does not occur when the bullet loses its velocity near the termination of its flight.

questions.text: Autopsy reports of the 25-year-old actor, who had allegedly committed suicide in his farmhouse, revealed petechial hemorrhage around both the orbits and behind the ears. The face appeared congested with minimal bleeding from the nose and mouth. The ligature marks were horizontal, complete around the neck, and were present below the level of the thyroid cartilage. Horizontal ligature marks would be more commonly seen in?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Strangulation:

  • A ligature mark is a well-defined groove, which is slightly depressed and of the same width as that of ligature material.
  • The groove may be narrow at parts due to the folding of the ligature.
  • The furrow is usually horizontally placed across the middle or lower part of the neck, at or below the level of the thyroid cartilage.
  • The mark is transverse, circular and continuous.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Hanging:

  • Ligature mark (‘furrow’) Site: Usually above the hyoid bone.
  • Size/shape: Depends on the type of material used.
  • Direction: It runs obliquely, backwards, non-continuous, upwards and towards the point of suspension. Mark is non-continuous because of a gap at the nape of the neck, and hair intervening between ligature material and the skin underneath.

questions.text: Primary forensic findings have been submitted by the forensic team. The horizontal ligature marks found on the neck were suggestive of strangulation but the team has not yet ruled out hanging, as horizontal ligature marks can also be seen in all of the following cases of hanging, except?
questions.solution:
Option D: Soft ligature material

  • Horizontal or oblique ligature marks can not be formed by Soft ligature material.

Option A: When running noose is applied

  • In hanging, a horizontal ligature mark can be seen when a running noose is applied.

Option B: Low point of suspension

  • A horizontal ligature mark can be also seen at the Low point of suspension.

Option C: Partial hanging

  • In hanging, horizontal ligature marks can be seen in Partial hanging.

questions.text:
A 30-year-old painter, has been working in the construction industry for several years. She specializes in painting and renovation projects for both residential and commercial properties. She starts experiencing fatigue, persistent abdominal pain, and frequent headaches. A physical examination showed the given findings:



Blood tests reveal elevated levels of lead. Which of the following chelating agents cannot be used in this patient?
questions.solution:
Option D: DESFERROXAMINE

  • Desferoxamine is used in iron overload.
  • It is not used in lead poisoning.

Option A/ B/ C: EDTA/ CUPRIMINE/ DMSA

  • Options A, B, and C are the chelating agents used in lead poisoning.
  • The chelating agents used in lead poisoning are EDTA, CUPRIMINE, DMSA, BAL, and DMPS.

questions.text: A 23 year old man has been brought into the emergency from a crash site where he had indulged in illegal racing. After the wounds were cleaned, the medical officer noticed multiple wounds around the right knee showing ragged, irregular edges with shallow tails at the edges. There was minimal clotted blood. There was mud particles and broken hair detected in the depths of the wound. The doctor should document the wound as?
questions.solution:
Option B: Lacerations

  • The margins are ragged, irregular and uneven and may show tearing of the extremities at angles diverging from the main laceration, the so-called ‘swallow tails’.
  • Less hemorrhage because blood vessels are crushed and torn and not cut evenly, thus facilitating hemostasis.

Option A: Incised wounds

  • Incision is a clean cut wound through the tissues (usually the skin and subcutaneous tissues including blood vessels), which is more long than deep, and caused by a sharp-edged instrument. It is produced by pressure and friction against the tissue by an object having a sharp cutting edge or point, such as knife, box cutter, razor or scalpel.

Option C: Chop wounds

  • Chop wounds are deep gaping wounds caused by a blow with the moderately sharp cutting edge of a heavy weapon, applied with a significant degree of force. It is considered a combination of blunt and sharp force injury.

Option D: Stab wounds

  • The force of the stab wound is delivered along the long axis of a pointed object (e.g. knife, scissors, needle, pencil etc) into the body.
  • Penetrating wound: When the weapon pierces through the body and enters into a body cavity or viscus.
  • Perforating wound: When the weapon pierces through the whole thickness of any part of the body thus producing two surface wounds, i.e. wound of entrance and wound of exit.

questions.text: A 38-year-old chemist works at a research and development facility that specializes in manufacturing chemicals for various industries. One fateful day, an industrial incident occurs in the facility, leading to the release of toxic gases. She was immediately rushed to the emergency department.On examination, the skin & mucosa appears cherry red in colour along with , bitter almond smell from breath and frothy discharge from mouth. Which toxic substance would have caused this?
questions.solution:
Option C: HCN poisoning

  • Brick-red color of skin and mucous membranes is said to be characteristic of HCN poisoning.
  • Pure acid is a colorless gas with a bitter almond odor.
  • Odor of bitter almonds in breath, initially tachypnea and dyspnea, followed by rapid slowing of respiratory rate with severe respiratory depression and cyanosis.

Option A: H2S poisoning

  • H2S is a colorless, transparent gas with smell of rotten eggs.
  • Headache, vertigo, nystagmus, weakness, coma, Rhinitis, pneumonia, pulmonary edema, Arrhythmia, myocardial depression, Lacrimation, photophobia, and conjunctivitis can be seen.

Option B: CO poisoning

  • Most frequent acute symptoms are headache (dull, frontal and continuous), dizziness, weakness, nausea and confusion.
  • On examination, there may be tachycardia, hypertension or hypotension, hyperthermia, flame-shaped retinal hemorrhages and bright red retinal veins. Classic cherry red skin is rare; pallor is present more often.
  • PM staining in carbon monoxide (CO) is Cherry red discolorization.

Option D: OPC poisoning

  • OPCs and carbamates are one of the most common causes of self-poisoning seen in India. They are used as insecticides, herbicides, antihelminthics, ophthalmic agents, in chemical industry, and as nerve gas in chemical warfare.
  • OPCs are usually mixed with a solvent aromax, which is responsible for a kerosene-like smell in the breath and body secretions.

questions.text: A 25-year-old patient was posted for exploratory laparotomy due to an abdominal injury. An anesthetist decided to give him controlled anesthesia. Which circuit is most effective for controlled ventilation?
questions.solution:
Option D: Mapleson D

  • Mapleson D (Bains circuit) is a circuit of choice for adults on controlled ventilation.
  • It consists of a fresh gas inlet nearer the patient end, a corrugated rubber tubing at one end, which is connected with an expiratory valve, and then a reservoir bag.
  • It is mainly used for assisted or controlled ventilation. 
  • During controlled ventilation, there is little chance of rebreathing.
  • The FGF, which enters during the expiratory pause, accumulates in the patient end and is forced during the inflation. In spontaneous breathing during inspiration, the patient will inhale the fresh gas & gas in a corrugated tube depending on FGF, T.V., length of expiratory pause & volume of the corrugated tube.
  • Rebreathing can be minimized by increasing FGF 2-3 times the MV.
  • For an adult, 15L/min FGF, which seems uneconomical, is required.
  • In some cases, 250 ml/kg/min is required to prevent rebreathing.

Option A: Mapleson A

  • Mapleson A is also called the Magill circuit, the circuit of choice in adults for spontaneous ventilation.
  • It consists of a three-way T-tube connected to the fresh gas outlet, a reservoir bag and a corrugated tube.
  • The other end of the reservoir tube is connected to the patient and a spring-loaded expiratory valve.
  • Corrugated rubber or plastic tubing: 110-130 cm in length.
  • Reservoir Bag at the Machine end.
  • A.P.L. valve at the patient end.
  • Tube volume > Tidal volume.
  • Advantages:
    • Best among all Mapleson systems for spontaneous ventilation.
    • Minimal wastage of gases during spontaneous ventilation
  • Disadvantages:
    • Not efficient for controlled ventilation.
    • Wastage of gases & operation theatre pollution.
    • The expiratory valve required produces slight resistance during expiration.
    • The expiratory valve is heavy(Headbrink valve).

Option B: Mapleson B

  • The Mapleson B system features the fresh gas inlet near the patient, distal to the expiratory valve.
  • The expiratory valve opens when the pressure in the circuit
  • Increases and a mixture of alveolar gas and fresh gas is discharged.
  • During the next inspiration, a mixture of retained fresh gas and alveolar gas is inhaled.
  • Rebreathing is avoided with fresh gas flow rates of greater than twice the minute ventilation for both spontaneous and controlled ventilation.

Option C: Mapleson C

  • This circuit is also known as Water's circuit.It is similar in construction to Mapleson B, but the main tube is shorter. An FGF equal to twice the minute ventilation is required to prevent rebreathing.
  • CO2 builds up slowly with this circuit. 
  • Mapleson B &C: In order to reduce rebreathing of alveolar gas, F.G. entry was shifted to near the patient.
  • This allows a complete mixing of F.G. and expired gas.
  • The end result is that these systems are neither efficient during spontaneous nor during controlled ventilation.

questions.text: A 24-year-old female presents in the emergency department with sudden onset of diffuse abdominal pain and nausea one hour ago. She appears diaphoretic and pale. There is diffuse abdominal tenderness on abdominal examination. The pelvic examination shows a normal vagina, cervix, and uterus with right adnexal tenderness. Why should the dose of local anaesthetics for a peripheral nerve block be decreased in this patient?

choices.text: Preferential perfusion of vital organs in shock predisposes more to local anaesthetics toxicity.
Sensitivity of voltage-gated channel increases in shock

questions.solution:
Option A: Preferential perfusion of vital organs in shock predisposes more to local anaesthetics toxicity

  • The patient is of reproductive age, sexually active, uses OCPs inconsistently, and menstrual cycle is overdue about two weeks; the acute onset of abdominal pain, right adnexal tenderness, diaphoresis, tachycardia, tachypnea, and hypotension suggests that the patient is in hypovolemic shock due to ruptured ectopic pregnancy.
  • In hypovolemic shock, there is preferential perfusion of vital organs, so whatever drug is intravascularly absorbed goes to vital organs CNS and CVS and causes systemic toxicity. So dose reduction is necessary to avoid systemic toxicity.
  • The plasma content of the local anaesthetic is determined by the rate of tissue distribution and the rate of clearance of the drug.
  • The rate and extent of systemic absorption depend on the site of injection, the dose, and the intrinsic pharmacokinetic properties of the drug.
  • After administration, the drug's plasma concentration is paralleled by an initial high uptake into the lungs and the distribution of the local anaesthetic to highly perfused tissues ( brain, heart, kidneys).
  • Lipid solubility is important in this redistribution and a primary determinant of intrinsic local anaesthetic potency.
  • After distributing into the highly perfused tissues, it is redistributed into less well-perfused tissues(Skeletal muscles and fat).
  • Consideration of cardiac output is important for describing the overall tissue distribution.
  • Patient-related factors - Age, Cardiovascular status, and hepatic function influences the absorption and resultant plasma concentration.
  • Protein binding also influences the distribution and excretion. Less protein-bound drugs will give an increased proportion of active forms of local anaesthetic.
  • Protein binding parallels the lipid solubility of local anaesthetic and is inversely related to the plasma concentration of the drug.
  • The risk factors for developing LAST (Local Anesthetic systemic toxicity):
    • Drug
    • Patient factors( age, pregnancy, renal disease, cardiac disease and hepatic dysfunction)

  • Drug:

    • The cardiovascular collapse/CNS ratio is "the ratio of drug dose which is required to cause catastrophic cardiovascular collapse to the medicine dose required to produce seizures."
    •  A low cardiovascular collapse/CNS ratio can be associated with more cardiotoxic agents, while L.A.s with a higher cardiovascular collapse/CNS ratio have a greater safety margin.
    • This is due to the earlier presentation of CNS features can expedite earlier diagnosis of LAST before cardiovascular collapse ensues.
    • Ropivacaine and levobupivacaine, for example, have a higher cardiovascular collapse/CNS ratio than racemic bupivacaine, so it seems logical to preferentially use these medications when long-acting L.A.s are desired. Vigilance is always required, however, as all L.A. drugs may cause LAST.

  • Patient factors: Age

    • Patients with old age have consistently been shown to be at a higher risk of LAST.
    • Newborn infants have immature hepatic enzyme systems, and elimination is prolonged.
    • The potential for toxicity with lidocaine infusions is also increased by the accumulation of its principal metabolite, monoethylglycinexylidide(MEGX), which can cause seizures.

  • Pregnancy:

    • The pregnancy effects on local anaesthetic potency can reflect a combined effect of mechanical factors in pregnancy and (dilated epidural veins decrease the volume of the epidural and subarachnoid spaces) direct effects of hormones, especially progesterone, on the susceptibility of the nerves to conduction blockade.
    • Hormone changes are more important than these two as the susceptibility is noted in the first trimester itself before gross changes in vascular dimensions of epidural or subarachnoid spaces occur.
    • So the dose should be reduced in all stages of pregnancy.

  • Renal disease:

    • Patients with severe renal disease not only have hyperdynamic circulation and reduced clearance of L.A.s but also have an increased α1-acid glycoprotein concentration.
    • As a result, free plasma concentrations are highly unchanged, and dose reduction is mostly unnecessary unless the patient is uremic with metabolic acidosis.

  • Cardiac disease:

    • Dose reduction is unnecessary in mild to moderate heart failure, where tissue perfusion can be preserved, but it is recommended in severe heart failure.
    • The rate of disappearance of lignocaine from blood markedly prolonged in patients with congestive cardiac failure

  • Hepatic dysfunction:

    • Decreased hepatic blood flow are impaired hepatic enzyme function can produce an elevation of blood levels of aminoamide local anaesthetics. So dose reduction is necessary.

Option B: Drugs cannot be metabolized

  • In hypovolemic shock, the drug metabolizes and enters the vital organs.
  • The high dose or the normal dose of anaesthetic can lead to systemic toxicity.

Option C: Sensitivity of voltage-gated channel increases in shock

  • The sensitivity of voltage-gated channels decreases in hypovolemic shock.
  • So that the anaesthetic or any intravenous drug can perfuse and enter the vital organs more easily.

Option D: All of the above

  • In hypovolemic shock, there is preferential perfusion of vital organs, so whatever drug is intravascularly absorbed goes to vital organs CNS and CVS and causes systemic toxicity.
  • So dose reduction is necessary to avoid systemic toxicity.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman receives neuraxial opioids for postoperative analgesia. What is the most common side effect she is most likely to experience with this intervention?
questions.solution:
Option B: Pruritus

  • Pruritus is the most common side effect of neuraxial opioids. It may be generalised but is more likely localised to the face, neck or upper thorax.
  • Pruritus is a medical term that means itching. It refers to a feeling or sensation in which the patient wants to scratch on the skin.
  • Pruritus can be painful or irritating and could be localised to one area of the body or spread throughout several rooms.
  • The advantage of nalbuphine is that it is less likely to reverse the analgesic effects of neuraxial opioids. The pruritus is self-limiting, and the severity diminishes in the first hour.
