  • Most side effects are dose-dependent and may be more common if the opioid is administered intrathecally.
  • Epidural opioids enhance the analgesic effects of local epidural anaesthetics without prolonging the motor block. Combining local anaesthetic and opioids reduces each drug's dose-related adverse effects.
  • The analgesic benefits of neuraxial opioids must be balanced against the dose-dependent side effects. Lipophilic opioids such as sufentanil are found in lower concentrations in CSF than hydrophilic opioids such as morphine and hydromorphone and are readily absorbed in the systemic circulation. That is the principal analgesic mechanism.

Option A: Respiratory depression

  • The overall risk of respiratory depression after neuraxial opioids is less than 1%.
  • Most side effects are dose-dependent and may be more common if the opioid is administered intrathecally.
  • Respiratory depression is the most potentially dangerous adverse reaction to opioid administration.
  • An overdose of fentanyl can cause serious adverse effects and life-threatening symptoms. When people overdose on fentanyl, their breathing can slow or stop. That can decrease the amount of oxygen reaching the brain; a condition called hypoxia.

Option C: Urinary retention

  • Urinary retention is when the patient cannot empty all the urine from the bladder.
  • The symptoms of urinary retention can range from severe abdominal pain and the inability to urinate to few or no symptoms. Urinary retention results from either a blockage that partially or fully prevents the flow of urine or the bladder's inability to maintain a strong enough force to expel all the urine.
  • It can't always prevent urinary retention, but by staying in tune with the body and bathroom habits, taking medicine as prescribed, strengthening the pelvic floor muscles, and making good dietary choices.

Option D: Sedation

  • One common pain control type is sedation, which relaxes the patient and sometimes makes them fall asleep. Sedation, also known as monitored anaesthesia.
  • An analgesic is a medication used to achieve analgesia or pain relief and is often combined with sedation.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy child is being operated on for circumcision under general anaesthesia with caudal analgesic supplements. His past medical history is unremarkable. He is up to date with his current vaccination. On examination, his blood pressure is 100/70 mm Hg, his pulse is 110/min, and his respiratory rate is 18/min. Pulse oximetry shows an oxygen saturation of 95%. A respiratory examination reveals normal breathing with equal air entry bilaterally. The abdomen is soft and non-tender. Neurological examination is unremarkable. The chest x-ray is normal. Intravenous induction with propofol has been planned. Which of the followings is an advantage of propofol over sevoflurane inhalation in this child?

choices.text: Does not cause pain over injecting site
Blood pressure and cardiac output are better maintained
Propofol has a slower onset of action
Propofol has a quicker onset of action

questions.solution:
Option D: Propofol has a quicker onset of action

  • Propofol is an intravenous anaesthetic agent used to induce and maintain general anaesthesia.
Intravenous anaesthetic agents, e.g. propofol Inhalational anaesthetic agents, e.g. sevoflurane
  1. Intravenous induction is faster, smoother and has a rapid recovery
  2. No specialised equipment is required
  3. Extensively used in outpatients
  4. Can be used as a sole anaesthetic agent in short surgical procedures
  5. Lesser perioperative respiratory complications compared to inhaled agents
  1. Inhalational induction is done in paediatric patients who are not cooperating and if there is no intravenous line to give an intravenous induction agent
  2. Special equipment is required to deliver and monitor the inspired concentration of the inhalational agents. Scavenging systems are required for the disposal of exhaled gases
  3. Slower onset of action and slower recovery than intravenous anaesthetic agents
  4. Less use in outpatients
  5. Cannot be used as a sole anaesthetic agent
  • Uses of propofol:
    • Induction and maintenance of Anesthesia
    • Intravenous Anesthesia
    • Antiemetic
    • Antipruritic
    • Anticonvulsant
    • Attenuation of bronchoconstriction
    • Analgesia
  • Adverse effects of propofol:
    • Allergic reactions
    • Lactic acidosis(Propofol infusion syndrome)
    • Proconvulsant activity-Spontaneous excitatory movements of the subcortical region but no EEG activity of cortical epileptic activity.
    • Abuse potential
    • Bacterial growth-It strongly supports the growth of E.coli and Pseudomonas
    • Antioxidant properties
    • Pain on injection
    • Airway protection-Alters pharyngeal function leads to impaired airway protection and pulmonary aspiration

Option A: Does not cause pain over injecting site

  • Propofol irritates the skin and mucous membranes. Thus, bolus injection of propofol preparations can be expected to cause pain. Therefore, it is an incorrect option.

Option B: Blood pressure and cardiac output are better maintained

  • Propofol and sevoflurane both cause a limited reduction in blood pressure and can reflexively increase cardiac output; hence it is the wrong option.

Option C: Propofol has a slower onset of action

  • Propofol has a quicker onset of action as compared to sevoflurane, which makes this option incorrect.

questions.text: A patient comes with fever and acute left lower quadrant abdominal pain. Blood cultures on admission showed e.coli and candida albicans. Hence, vancomycin, metronidazole and gentamicin, and amphotericin were started. She has a CT scan that identifies diverticulitis. After 36 hours, her creatinine rises dramatically after the investigation contrast agent is identified as responsible for the given condition. Based on nephrotoxicity, which one of the following is least nephrotoxic?
questions.solution:
Option A: Iodixanol

  • The above given is a case of diverticulitis.

  • Contrast Agents with High Iodine: particle ratio tends to be less nephrotoxic.

  • Iodixanol is an iso-osmolar contrast agent, Nonionic Dimer with Iodine: Particle Ratio of 6:1 and tends to be less nephrotoxic than the other iodinated compounds given here.

Option B: Diatrizoate

  • Diatrazoate is a ionic monomer

  • The ionic monomer variety is most nephrotoxic.

  • Gastrografin contains Diatrazoate.

  • Cheap contrast agent

  • Hyperosmolar→ Promotes intestinal "hurry," plays 2 roles: diagnostic-prognostic and therapeutic.

  • A water-soluble contrast enema allows real-time evaluation of colonic anatomy and is most commonly used to test the integrity of surgical anastomoses.

  • It can cause diarrhea.

Option C: Iothalamate

  • It is an example of an ionic monomer

  • The monomer is more toxic than dimer and non ionic is more toxic than ionic

Other examples are the following:

    • Urografin.

    • Diatrizoate.

    • Iothalamate.

Option D: Ioxaglate

  • Ixoglate is an exmple of ionic dimer.

  • I:P Ratio 6:2

  • There are the following features of ionic dimers

    • Intermediate viscoscity.

    • Intermediate osmolarity.

    • Intermediate hydrophilicity.

  • Ionic dimer is used primarily for peripheral arteriography.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents to the emergency department following a road traffic accident with multiple injuries, blood loss and severe abdominal pain suggestive of organ injury. What are the four points of probe placement in focused abdominal sonograms for trauma (FAST)?

choices.text: SUBXIPHOID, UMBILICAL REGION, PLEURAL CAVITY, COSTOPHRENIC ANGLE
HEPATO RENAL POUCH, SPLENORENAL POUCH, PELVIS, UMBLICAL REGION
SPLENORENAL POUCH, PELVIS, UPPER CHEST , PLEURAL CAVITY

questions.solution:
ANSWER Option A SUBXIPHOID, HEPATORENAL, SPLENORENAL, PLEURAL CAVITY

EXPLANATION: eFAST

  • Focused assessment with sonography for trauma (FAST) examination is a bedside screening tool to identify free intraperitoneal, pleural and pericardial fluid. It is a limited ultrasound examination with 6 views.

  • The average time to perform a complete FAST examination is 2–4 minutes.

  • The four points of probe placement in focused abdominal sonogram for trauma (FAST) in thoracoabdominal trauma:

 

1) Subxiphoid To look for pericardial fluid & 4 chamber view of the heart
2) Right intercostal oblique view To look for right pleural effusion
3) Right coronal view To look for free fluid in Morrison’s pouch and paracolic gutter
4) Left intercostal oblique view To look for left pleural effusion, free view fluid in subphrenic space
5) Left coronal view For the left paracolic gutter
6) Pelvic (longitudinal/ transverse) views To detect free fluid in The cul-de-sac

 OPTION B: SUBXIPHOID, UMBILICAL REGION, PLEURAL CAVITY, COSTOPHRENIC ANGLE

  • THE UMBILICAL REGION IS NOT CHECKED IN FAST

OPTION C: HEPATO RENAL POUCH, SPLENORENAL POUCH, PELVIS, UMBILICAL REGION

  • THE UMBILICAL REGION IS NOT CHECKED IN FAST

OPTION D: SPLENORENAL POUCH, PELVIS, UPPER CHEST , PLEURAL CAVITY

  • UPPER CHEST IS NOT CHECKED IN FAST

questions.text: A 50-year-old patient chronic alcoholic male, after a large binge of alcohol, presents to the emergency department in a subconscious state. He vomited several times, a few of them mixed with blood. He had a history of heartburn and dyspeptic symptoms for the past few tears. On physical exam, he had a temperature of 102°F, a pulse of 110/minute, a respiratory rate of 20 per minute, and a blood pressure of 90/60 mm Hg. On physical examination, there was abdominal guarding and tenderness. A plane-erect chest X-ray reveals air under the diaphragm. The probable diagnosis is?
questions.solution:
Option A: Perforated peptic ulcer

  • History of:
  • Heartburn and dyspepsia.
  • Acute onset of bloody vomiting after binge alcohol.
  • General and physical examination findings and air under the diaphragm on chest X-ray.
  • All these indicate the air under the diaphragm on chest X-ray, and all these indicate the perforation of peptic ulcer.

  • In the above diagram, the arrow shows the air under the diaphragm, a suggestive feature of perforated peptic ulcers.
  • The above clinical picture suggests a perforated peptic ulcer, the most common cause of pneumoperitoneum (air under the diaphragm).
  • Perforation results in pneumoperitoneum, and the best view to see this is a chest x-ray in an erect position which detects air under the domes of the diaphragm.
  • Risk factors for peptic ulcer perforation are:
  • Old age more than 60.
  • Smoking.
  • Helicobacter pylori infection.
  • Use of nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs.
  • Chronic stress.

Option B: Acute MI

  • Acute MI have radiating pain from the chest towards the left arm.
  • There is no radiological finding on x-rays in MI.

Option C: Dissected abdominal aorta

  • It also has no findings on x-rays.
  • It has retrosternal pain, which is excruciating pain.

questions.text: A 1-month-old girl was brought to the physician's office with a complaint of cyanosis since birth. A chest x-ray was with the findings, as shown in the following image. Which of the following is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option A: TAPVC

 Total anomalous pulmonary venous connection

  • Also referred to as total anomalous pulmonary venous return
  • It is a congenital cyanotic defect in which all four pulmonary veins fail to make their normal connection to the left atrium.
  • This results in the drainage into the systemic venous system of all the pulmonary venous return.
  • Survival depends on the obligatory right-to-left shunting of the mixed pulmonary venous and systemic venous blood, usually at the atrial level.
  • In TAPVD, the pulmonary veins coalesce posterior to the left atrium but do not drain into it.
  • This drainage occurs to the right atrium via an ascending vein to the innominate vein and then to the superior vena cava.
  • The coronary sinus is directly into the right atrium; a descending vein passes through the diaphragm into either the inferior vena cava or portal venous system.
  • The dilatation of the ascending vein returns blood to the brachiocephalic vein, and the dilated superior vena cava forms the Snowman-shaped heart (figure of 8 appearances of the heart).

Option B: TGA

  • Transposition of great arteries
  • Show egg on string/side appearance of the heart (Globular heart with narrow mediastinum).

Option C: PTA

  • Persistent truncus arteriosus
  • Sitting duck sign on chest x-ray.
  • It is a cyanotic congenital heart anomaly in which a single trunk supplies both the pulmonary and systemic circulation instead of a separate aorta and a pulmonary trunk.
  • As a result, a single arterial vessel originates from the heart to supply systemic, pulmonary, and coronary circulation.
  •  It is almost always associated with a ventricular septal defect to allow circulatory flow circuit completion.

Option D: None of the above

  • TAPVC shows a figure of 8 snowman appearance
  • TGA shows an egg on a string appearance
  • PDA shows a sitting duck sign

questions.text: A 42-year-old female presents to the clinic with the complaint of vaginal discharge and burning sensations in the vagina. She was in her usual state of health until yesterday when she first experienced vaginal burning. Today, she noticed vaginal discharge. She also complains of intense vaginal itching. Her medical history includes diabetes for the past two years. Examination of the genital area shows vulvar erythema with satellite lesions. Speculum examination reveals a scant, white, homogenous discharge adherent to the vaginal wall. The vaginal epithelium appears inflamed and edematous. Vaginal pH is normal. Culture grows colonies that form germinal tubes and chlamydospores. Which of the following organism is most likely responsible for her current symptoms?
questions.solution:
Option C: Candida

  • This patient's history of whitish vaginal discharge, presence of erythematous vulva with satellite lesions, inflamed and edematous vaginal wall, a normal pH of vaginal fluid, and diabetes make candida vulvovaginitis the most likely diagnosis.
  • Following are the most important features of the candida:
  • Candida is the most common infection of the female genital tract in immunocompromised patients.
  • Candida species are normal commensals of the mouth, GI tract, and vaginal mucosa in patients with an indwelling catheter.
  • It is a dimorphic fungus that forms germinal tubes and chlamydospores.
  • Candida is an opportunistic fungus that causes various diseases, including oral thrush, pneumonia, endocarditis, vulvovaginitis, and candidemia.
  • Diabetes and immunosuppression are risk factors for candida infection.
  • Treatment of vulvovaginal candidiasis involves the elimination of precipitating factors.
  • For uncomplicated vulvovaginal candidiasis, topical azoles like clotrimazole are used.
  • A single dose of oral fluconazole is also an effective treatment for vulvovaginal candidiasis.
  • For complicated cases, multiple doses of fluconazole are required.

Option A: Cryptococcal infection

  • It rarely affects genital areas. However, in Fungal culture and serology, it grows on sabouraud agar and forms smooth, mucoid, creamy colonies.
  • It is a round yeast that forms narrow-based buds.
  • Germinal tube formation is characteristic of candida, not of cryptococcus.

Option B: Actinomycetoma

  • It causes mycetoma, also known as Madura's foot.
  • It includes Actinomycetoma and Eumycetoma.
  • This patient’s symptoms are suggestive of vulvovaginitis caused by candida.

Option D:Aspergillus fumigatus

  • It can cause systemic infections in immunocompromised and immunocompetent individuals.
  • It does not cause vulvovaginitis.
  • Also, it is not responsible for the formation of the germinal tube.

questions.text:
An 8-year-old child resident of Kashmir presents with a thick, foul-smelling crust over the scalp, as shown below. 



Wood's examination shows green fluorescence. Which of the following is the causative agent for these lesions?
questions.solution:
Option A: Trichophyton schoenleinii

  • This patient most likely has a favus.
  • The most likely organism responsible for his condition is trichophyton schoenleinii.
  • Tinea capitis is a dermatophyte infection. Dermatophyte organisms include Trichophyton and Microsporum genera which generally cause tinea capitis. Dermatophytes are divided into anthropophilic (human), zoophilic (animal), and geophilic (soil) fungi.
  • Anthropophilic and zoophilic dermatophytes are the most common causes of tinea capitis.
  • Trichophyton schoenleinii  is anthropophilic organism.
  • Favus is a unique clinical presentation of tinea capitis resulting from infection with T. schoenleinii (rarely other dermatophytes).
  • In favus, perifollicular erythema progresses to the characteristic development of cup-shaped, yellow crusts called scutula.
  • The scutula contain fungi, neutrophils, dried serum, and epidermal cells.
  • Scutula eventually coalesce to form adherent masses above areas of severe alopecia.
  • There may be an associated unpleasant odor.
  • The intense inflammation can result in permanent scarring.
  • If untreated, favus may persist indefinitely.

The different types of diseases caused by dermatophytes are listed below:

Inflammatory
  • Microsporum audouinii
  • Microsporum canis
  • Microsporum gypseum
  • Microsporum nanum
  • Trichophyton interdigitale
  • Trichophyton schoenleinii
  • Trichophyton tonsurans
  • Trichophyton verrucosum
Non-inflammatory
  • M. audouinii
  • M. canis
  • Microsporum ferrugineum
  • T. tonsurans
Black dot
  • T. tonsurans
  • T. violaceum
Favus
  • T. schoenleinii
  • Trichophyton violaceum
  • Trichophyton mentagrophytes

Option B: Tinea corporis

  • It is found in most parts of the world, particularly in hot, humid climates.
  • Clinically it presents as a solitary circular red patch with a raised scaly leading edge.
  • A lesion spreads out from the center, forming a ring shape with central hypopigmentation and a peripheral scaly red rim (ringworm).
  • This patient most likely has favus which is not caused by tinea corporis.

Option C: Tinea cruris 

  • It is a dermatophyte infection of the groin, proximal inner thighs, or buttocks.
  • Predisposing factors include copious sweating, obesity, diabetes, and immunodeficiency.
  • This patient’s scalp lesions are suggestive of Trichophyton schoenleinii.

Option D: Candida tropicalis

  • It causes candidemia and other diseases, including oropharyngeal candidiasis and vulvovaginitis in immunocompromised patients.
  • This patient’s clinical presentation is more suggestive of Trichophyton schoenleinii.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male presents to the dermatologic clinic with the onset of lesions on the extremities and mouth. Scarring alopecia, thinned nails, hyperpigmented macular lesions over the trunk, and oral mucosa are noted on examination. He also says that these lesions are itchy. His medical history has been consistent with chronic hepatitis for the past 5 years. He has been non-compliant with his medications. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option C: Lichen planus

Lichen planus (LP) is a papulosquamous disorder that affects skin, scalp, nails, and mucous membranes.

  • Lesions of Lichen planus can be described as 5Ps "Purple, Polygonal, Pruritic, Plane topped(flat), Papules".
  • The characteristic features include scarring alopecia, thinned nails, hyperpigmented macular lesions over the trunk, and oral mucosa.
  • Drugs that can cause lichenoid eruptions:
  • Thiazide diuretics,
  • Gold,
  • Antimalarial agents,
  • Penicillamine,
  • Phenothiazines
  • Chronic graft-versus-host disease.
  • Lichen planus is associated with many other autoimmune conditions.

Option A: Psoriasis

  • Scarring alopecia and thinned nails are the features of lichen planus.
  • Non-scarring alopecia and nail pitting are seen in Psoriasis

Option B: Leprosy

  • Scarring alopecia and thinned nails are the features of lichen planus.
  • Non-scarring alopecia is seen in leprosy.

Option D: Pemphigus

  • Scarring alopecia and thinned nails are the features of lichen planus.
  • Non-scarring alopecia is seen in leprosy.

questions.text: A 65-year-old female presents with indurated lesions throughout her body. The lesions are covered with a necrotic crust, the removal of which causes ulceration. She is taking chemotherapy for metastatic ovarian carcinoma. She is diagnosed with Ecthyma gangrenosum. Which of the following is associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
Option A: Pseudomonas Septicemia

This patient is diagnosed with ecthyma gangrenosum following chemotherapy for metastatic ovarian carcinoma. Chemotherapeutic drugs cause myelosuppression and lead to low neutropenic count. This predisposes the patient to develop pseudomonas sepsis, the main cause of ecthyma gangrenosum.

  • Pseudomonas septicemia is a terrifying condition that can only be successfully treated if detected early. The appearance of an ecthyma gangrenosum, a recognizable skin lesion, is a hallmark that aids in the identification of Pseudomonas septicemia.
  • Pseudomonas septicemia most commonly occurs in the severely immunocompromised host.

Option B: Lepromatous leprosy

  • Lepromatous leprosy is a mycobacterial infection.
  • It primarily affects nerves and skin.
  • Most commonly affected sites are the face, ears, wrists, buttocks, knees, and eyebrows.
  • Skin manifestations include hypopigmented patches. Other clinical features include progressive peripheral nerve damage resulting in muscle atrophy.

Option C: Ulcerative colitis

  • Ulcerative colitis is a chronic inflammatory disorder characterized by the following features
  • Bloody diarrhea along with systemic symptoms of fever and lethargy
  • Abdominal pain and weight loss.
  • Skin manifestations include rapidly developing painful ulcers known as pyoderma gangrenosum. This patient doesn't have features of ulcerative colitis and likely has neutropenia secondary to chemotherapy.

questions.text:
A 20-year-old male undergoes septoplasty for deviated nasal septum (DNS). The operation remains uneventful, and there are no immediate complications. Two days later, the patient returned with the complaint of severe nasal obstruction. Anterior rhinoscopy is performed, and the findings are shown in the image below:



Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for this condition?
questions.solution:
Option D: All of the above

  • It can be a septal hematoma/septal abscess. Fever with chills differentiates between hematoma & abscess.

Treatment of Septal Abscess

  • Abscess should be drained as early as possible.
  • Incision is made in the most dependent part of the abscess, and a piece of septal mucosa is excised.
  • Pus and necrosed pieces of cartilage are removed by suction.
  • The incision may require to be reopened daily for 2–3 days to drain any pus or to remove any necrosed pieces of cartilage.
  • Systemic antibiotics are started as soon as the diagnosis has been made and continued at least for 10 days.

Treatment of Septal Hematoma

  • Aspiration: Small hematoma can be evacuated with a wide bore needle.
  • Incision and drainage: Larger hematoma needs incision and drainage. It is done through a small anteroposterior incision that is parallel to the nasal floor. A small piece of the mucosa is excised, which facilitates drainage. Nasal cavities are packed to prevent reaccumulation of blood.
  • Systemic antibiotics prevent septal abscesses.

Option A: Incision and drainage

  • Incision and drainage are the first choice of treatment in septal abscesses.
  • In larger hematomas also, an incision is done as treatment; otherwise, it may get infected.
  • However, other options such as aspiration and antibiotic therapy are also true, making this answer incorrect.

Option B: Needle aspiration

  • Needle aspiration is done in smaller hematomas.
  • However, this is not the only correct option. Therefore, we cannot choose option B as the most suitable choice.

Option C: Antibiotic therapy

  • After drainage of the hematoma and abscess, antibiotics are given to prevent the development of infection.

questions.text: A 2-week-old male infant is brought to the pediatrician by his parents. He was born to a 21-year-old gravida 1 para 1 mother who admits she did not make any prenatal appointments. The infant was delivered in a home with the help of a midwife. According to the mother, it was a difficult delivery. She states that "he may have suffered some injury during birth ."Upon examination, everything is unremarkable except the nose has a deformity. Which of the following statements is false regarding the nasal deformity shown in the image?

choices.text: Can also be due to birth injuries

questions.solution:
Option C: Known as saddle nose

The picture shows a crooked nose deformity.

  • In the crooked nose, the midline of the dorsum from the frontonasal angle to the tip is curved in a C- or S-shaped manner.
  • In a deviated nose, the midline is straight but deviated to one side
  • Usually, these deformities are traumatic in origin.
  • Injuries sustained during birth, neonatal period, or childhood but not immediately recognized will also develop into these deformities with the growth of the nose.
  • Deviated or crooked nose can be corrected by rhinoplasty or septorhinoplasty.
  • The aim of these operations is to correct not only the outer appearance of the nose but also its function.

Option A: Mostly of traumatic origin

  • The crooked nose deformity is mostly of traumatic origin.
  • Hence it pertains to the criteria of crooked nose deformity, making it an incorrect answer.

Option B: Can also be due to birth injuries

  • The crooked nose deformity shown in the image is due to birth injuries.
  • Hence, this is a true statement regarding crooked nose deformity, making it an incorrect choice for this question.

Option D: Requires septorhinoplasty

  • Crooked nose deformity requires septorhinoplasty for correction.
  • Hence this statement is true regarding crooked nose deformity making it the wrong choice for this question.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy presents to the OPD with complaints of persistent nasal discharge. A week ago, he had a low-grade fever, cough, headache, and watery nasal discharge. However, all the symptoms resolved after 3 days except the nasal discharge. On anterior and posterior rhinoscopy, a trilobed mass is seen, and a diagnosis of antrochoanal polyp is made. Which of the following statements is correct about antrochoanal polyps?

choices.text: It is also known as Killian's polyp
It is seen in elderly patients
It grows in the nasal cavity towards the anterior choana

questions.solution:
Option A: It is also known as Killian’s polyp.

Antrochoanal Polyp (Killian's Polyp)

  Antrochoanal polyp Ethmoidal polyp
Age Common in children Common in adult
Number Solitary Multiple
Laterality Unilateral Bilateral
Origin Maxillary sinus near the ostium Ethmoidal sinuses, middle turbinate and middle meatus
Growth Grows backwards to the choana; may hang down behind the soft palate Mostly grow anteriorly and may present at the nares
Size and shape Trilobed (dumb-bell)with antral, nasal and choanal parts. Choanal parts may protrude through the choana & fill the nasopharynx obstructing both sides Usually small and grape-like masses
Recurrence Uncommon if removed completely Common
Treatment The treatment is only surgical About 50% of patients respond to steroid therapy

 

  • It arises from the mucosa of the maxillary antrum near its accessory ostium, comes out of it, and grows in the nasal cavity towards the posterior choana.
    • It has three parts:
      • Antral, which is a thin stalk.
      • Nasal, which is flat from side to side.
      • Choanal, which is round and spherical.
  • Antrochoanal polyp is seen in children and young adults.
  • It is usually single and unilateral.
  • It commonly occurs after an infection (e.g., sinusitis)
  • It causes unilateral nasal obstruction but can cause bilateral obstruction if the posterior choanal part extends into the nasopharynx and blocks both of the posterior choana.
  • Recurrence is uncommon if the polyp is completely removed by surgery.
  • The treatment of choice is functional endoscopic sinus surgery (FESS)

Option B: It is seen in elderly patients.

  • Antrochoanal polyp is usually seen in children, not the elderly.

Option C: It is multiple and bilateral.

  • Antrochoanal polyp is usually single and unilateral, not multiple and bilateral.

Option D: It grows in the nasal cavity towards the anterior choana

  • Ethmoidal polyps grow anteriorly towards the nares, not the antrochoanal polyp.
  • Antrochoanal polyp does not grow anteriorly towards the anterior nares. It grows posteriorly towards the posterior choanae.

questions.text:
A 54-year-old woman presents to the physician because of a 5-month history of weakness on the left side of her face, loss of taste, and dryness and redness of her left eye. She has no history of serious illness. Physical examination shows an inability to puff the left cheek and close her left eye. An MRI of the brain shows a contrast-enhancing mass in the posterior fossa. Which of the following statement is correct regarding facial nerve landmarks if this patient underwent surgery for his condition?

1. Tympanomastoid suture -Nerve lies 6–8 mm deep to this suture

2. Styloid process-The nerve crosses medial to the styloid process

3. Cartilaginous pointer - Nerve lies 1 cm deep and slightly anterior and inferior to pointer

4. Posterior belly of digastric- Nerve is found to lie between it and the styloid process
questions.solution:
Option A: 1, 3, and 4 are correct

  • It is a case of parotid gland tumor, which require parotidectomy for its treatment. 
  • Facial Nerve Landmarks in parotid surgery:
  • Cartilaginous pointer: Nerve lies 1 cm deep and slightly anterior and inferior to a pointer. A cartilaginous pointer is a sharp triangular piece of the cartilage of pinna and "points" to the nerve
  • Tympanomastoid suture: Nerve lies 6–8 mm deep to this suture (most reliable marker)
  • Styloid process: The nerve crosses laterally to the styloid process.
  • Posterior belly of digastric: If the posterior belly of the digastric muscle is traced backward along its upper border to its attachment to the digastric groove, a nerve is found to lie between it and the styloid process.

Option B: 1, 2, and 3 are correct 

  • It is an incorrect option because statement 2 is a false statement.
  • In statement 2, it is mentioned that the facial nerve crosses the medial to styloid process, which is false.
  • The facial nerve crosses laterally to the styloid process.

Option C: 1, 2, 3, and 4 are correct

  •  It is an incorrect option because statement 2 is a false statement.
  • In statement 2, it is mentioned that the facial nerve crosses the medial to styloid process, which is false.
  • The facial nerve crosses laterally to the styloid process.

Option D: Only 1 and 2 are correct

  • It is an incorrect option because statement 2 is a false statement.
  • In statement 2, it is mentioned that the facial nerve crosses the medial to styloid process, which is false.
  • The facial nerve crosses laterally to the styloid process.

questions.text:
Which of the following condition is associated with recurrent facial palsy?
1) Melkersson syndrome
2) Diabetes
3) Sarcoidosis
4) Bell's palsy
questions.solution:
Option A: 1,2,3,4 correct

  • Recurrent facial palsy is seen in Bell palsy (3–10% cases), Melkersson syndrome, diabetes, sarcoidosis and tumours.
  • Recurrent palsy on same side may be caused by a tumour in 30% of cases.

Learning Objective

Causes of facial paralysis

Central

  • Brain abscess
  • Pontine gliomas
  • Poliomyelitis
  • Multiple sclerosis
  • Intracranial part (cerebellopontine angle)
    • Acoustic neuroma
    • Meningioma
    • Congenital cholesteatoma
    • Metastatic carcinoma
    • Meningitis
  • Intratemporal part
    • Idiopathic – Bell palsy – Melkersson syndrome
    • Infections – Acute suppurative otitis media – Chronic suppurative otitis media – Herpes zoster oticus – Malignant otitis externa
    • Trauma – Surgical: Mastoidectomy and stapedectomy – Accidental: Fractures of temporal bone
    • Neoplasms – Malignancies of external and middle ear – Glomus jugulare tumour – Facial nerve neuroma – Metastasis to temporal bone (from cancer of breast, bronchus, prostate
  • Extracranial part
    • Malignancy of parotid
    • Surgery of parotid
    • Accidental injury in parotid region
    • Neonatal facial injury (obstetrical forceps)

Systemic diseases

  • Diabetes mellitus
  • Hypothyroidism
  • Uraemia
  • Polyarteritis nodosa
  • Wegener’s granulomatosis
  • Sarcoidosis (Heerfordt’s syndrome)
  • Leprosy
  • Leukaemia
  • Demyelinating disease

questions.text: An 18-year-old patient presents in the emergency department with complaint of pain and fullness in the ear. The patient has also noticed that his hearing has reduced over the last 2 years and presented with the following otoscopic finding. Similar findings can also be seen in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Option B: Secretory otitis media

Sequelae of chronic secretory otitis media:

  • The above given is a case of secretory otitis media.
  • Pain, ear fullness, and decreased hearing from 2 years are suggestive.
  • Atrophic tympanic membrane and atelectasis of the middle ear. In prolonged effusions, the fibrous layer of the tympanic membrane is dissolved. It becomes thin and atrophic and retracts into the middle ear.

Ossicular necrosis:

  • Most commonly, the long process of incus gets necrosed. Sometimes, stapes superstructure also gets necrosed. This increases the conductive hearing loss to more than 50 dB.

Tympanosclerosis:

  • Hyalinized collagen with chalky deposits may be seen in the tympanic membrane, around the ossicles, or their joints, leading to their fixation.

Retraction pockets and cholesteatoma:

  • Thin atrophic part of pars tensa may get invaginated to form retraction pockets or cholesteatoma. Similar pockets may be seen in the attic region.
  • Cholesterol granuloma: This is due to stasis of the middle ear and mastoid secretions.

Otoscopic findings:

  • The tympanic membrane is often dull and opaque, with a loss of light reflex.
  • It may appear yellow, grey, or bluish in color. A thin leash of blood vessels may be seen along the handle of the malleus or at the periphery of the tympanic membrane and differs from marked congestion of acute suppurative otitis media.
  • The tympanic membrane may show varying degrees of retraction.
  • Sometimes, it may appear full or slightly bulging in its posterior part due to effusion.
  • Fluid level and air bubbles may be seen when fluid is thin and the tympanic membrane transparent.
  • Mobility of the tympanic membrane is restricted.

Option A: Tympanosclerosis

  • It causes scar formation on the tympanic membrane.
  • The tympanic membrane appears like a chalky white drum.
  • It is caused by severe middle ear infections such as otitis media.

Option C: Otosclerosis

  • It is the overgrowth of the footplate of the stapes bone.
  • It causes tinnitus and vertigo.
  • The tympanic membrane appears like a pink drum.

Option D: Myringitis bullosa

  • It causes painful reddish blisters along the tympanic membrane in the ear.
  • Viruses cause it.
  • Streptococcus pneumonia is the most common bacteria causing this disease.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements is correct about the endocochlear potential?

1) It is a normal physiological potential

2) Endocochlear potential is an indirect current potential recorded from scala media.

3) Exchange of 3 Na+& 2 K+ in scala vestibuli is responsible for Endocochlear potential

4) Normal Endocochlear potential : +80 to +85 mV
questions.solution:
Option B: Only 1,4 is correct

  • It is a normal physiological potential.
  • Endocochlear potential is a direct current (DC) potential recorded from scala media.
  • Exchange of 3 Na+& 2 K+ in scala media is responsible for endocochlear potential.
  • It is +80 to +85 mV and is generated from the stria vascularis by Na+/K+-ATPase pump>Present at rest and does not require a sound stimulus.

Electrical potentials of cochlea and CN VIII four types of potentials have been recorded; three from the cochlea and one from CN VIII fibres. They are: Endocochlear potential, Cochlear microphonic, Summating potential from cochlea and Compound action potential from nerve fibres

  • Endocochlear Potential: It is a direct current (DC) potential recorded from scala media. It is +80 mV and is generated from the stria vascularis by Na+/K+-ATPase pump>Cochlear Microphonic (CM): When basilar membrane moves in response to sound stimulus, electrical resistance at the tips of hair cells changes allowing flow of K+ through hair cells and produces voltage fluctuations called cochlear microphonic. It is an alternating current (AC) potential.
  • Summating Potential (SP): It is a DC potential and follows “envelope” of stimulating sound. It is produced by hair cells. It may be negative or positive. SP has been used in diagnosis of Ménière’s disease. It is superimposed on VIII nerve action potential. Both CM and SP are receptor potentials as seen in other sensory end-organs. They differ from action potentials in that:
    • They are graded rather than all or none phenomenon,
    • Have no latency,
    • Are not propagated and
    • Have no postresponse refractory period.
  • Compound Action Potential. It is an all or none response of auditory nerve fibres.

Option A: Incorrect

  • Explanation given above.

Option C: Incorrect

  • Explanation given above.

Option D: Incorrect

  • Explanation given above.

questions.text: A one-month-old girl is brought to the clinic by her parents with the complaint of an enlarged head and noisy breathing since childhood. On examination, the head circumference is enlarged, the inspiratory stridor is audible, and there is a defect on the back with the herniation of a soft sac. MRI is done, which shows displacement of the midbrain, fourth ventricle, and cerebellar tonsils through the foramen magnum. Which of the following pathology of the larynx is associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
Option B: Congenital Vocal cord palsy

  • The MRI scan showing displacement of the midbrain, fourth ventricle, and cerebellar tonsils through the foramen magnum is diagnostic of Arnold Chiari malformation (or type 2 Chiari malformations).
  • Arnold Chiari malformation is commonly associated with hydrocephalus (enlargement of head circumference), meningomyelocele (defect on the back with herniation of spinal cord and meninges), cerebellar and brainstem dysfunction.
  • Congenital vocal cord palsy results from birth trauma when the recurrent laryngeal nerve is stretched during breech or forceps delivery or can result from anomalies of CNS.
  • Arnold Chiari malformation is one of the most common congenital central nervous system anomalies associated with bilateral vocal cord paralysis.
  • Arnold Chiari malformation is also known as type 2 Chiari malformation.
  • Vocal cord paralysis is a complication of the type 2 Chiari malformation (Arnold Chiari malformation), though rarely found also with type 1 Chiari malformation.
  • The vocal cord paralysis is due to herniation of the brainstem through the foramen magnum, which compresses the motor nuclei of the vagus nerve.

Option A: Laryngomalacia

  • Laryngomalacia is characterized by excessive flaccidity of the supraglottic larynx, which is sucked in during inspiration, producing stridor and sometimes cyanosis.
  • It is not associated with Arnold Chiari malformation.

Option C: Congenital subglottic stenosis

  • Congenital subglottic stenosis refers to the congenital narrowing of the subglottic part of the larynx.
  • It is not associated with Arnold Chiari malformation.

Option D: Laryngeal web

  • The laryngeal web is characterized by a web/membrane joining the anterior portions of the vocal cords.
  • It is not associated with Arnold Chiari malformation.

questions.text: A 63-year-old woman is referred to the ophthalmology clinic by her primary care physician, complaining of deteriorating vision in her right eye that had started four months prior without accompanying pain. She was a known case of squamous cell carcinoma of the left lung. A detachment was seen in the lower part of the retina during her ophthalmoscopic examination. In addition, any plaques, tumor masses, and metastases were absent. She was then diagnosed with unilateral paraneoplastic exudative retinal detachment. Which of the following condition causes exudative retinal detachment?
questions.solution:
Option A: Toxemia of pregnancy

  • Pre eclampsia is defined as systolic blood pressure more than or equal to 140 mm Hg or diastolic blood pressure more than or equal to 90 mm Hg or higher, on two occasions at least 4 hours apart in a previously normotensive patient.
  • In addition to this criterion, proteinuria of more than 0.3 gms in a 24-hour urine specimen or a PCR ratio of 0.3 or greater is required to diagnose preeclampsia.
  • The patient may present with retinal involvement as well.
  • Exudative retinal detachment can be found in 1-2% of the cases with preeclampsia/eclampsia.
  • Subretinal fluid accumulates in the space between the neurosensory retina and the underlying retinal pigment epithelium (RPE) due to leakage of vessels resulting in retinal detachment. Exudative retinal detachments have a convex configuration, no retinal breaks, and no holes or tears.

 

Underlying disease classification

Examples

Neoplastic

Choroidal melanoma

Choroidal metastasis

Choroidal haemangioma

Retinoblastoma

Inflammatory

Vogt-Koyanagi – Harada disease

Posterior scleritis

Sympathetic opthalmia

Infectious

Toxoplasmosis

Syphilis

Tuberculosis

Vascular

Coats disease

Malignant hypertension

Eclampsia or pre – eclampsia

Congenital

Morning glory syndrome

Optic nerve head pit

Coloboma

Nanophthalmos

 

Option B: Lattice Degeneration

  • Peripheral retinal degeneration comprises localized retinal thinning, overlying vitreous liquefaction, and marginal vitreoretinal adhesion.
  • Associated with atrophic retinal holes, retinal tears, and retinal detachments.
  • Patients are generally asymptomatic, and the lesions are usually an incidental finding of dilated ocular examination.
  • There can be blurriness in the distance due to myopia, commonly presented with lattice degeneration.
  • The sudden onset of floaters, flashes of light, peripheral field loss, or central vision loss may indicate the presence of retinal detachment.

Option C: CMV Retinitis

  • Cytomegalovirus (CMV) Retinitis is an acquired immunodeficiency syndrome (AIDS)-related opportunistic infection.
  • Cytomegalovirus (CMV) retinitis is an important ocular AIDS-associated illness. It is a full-thickness retinal infection that can lead to necrosis, retinal breaks and detachments, and blindness.
  • Most patients are without symptoms, but few may experience floaters, flashes and blind spots.

Option D: Diabetic retinopathy

  • Diabetic retinopathy can cause tractional retinal detachment or combined rhegmatogenous-tractional retinal detachment.
  • It does not lead to the development of exudative retinal detachment.
  • It has different stages depending on the severity.
  • Stage 1: background retinopathy
  • Stage 2: pre-proliferative retinopathy
  • Stage 3: proliferative retinopathy
  • Diabetic maculopathy

questions.text: A 70-year-old man from Europe living in India presents to a physician with complaints of gradual onset, painless, progressive blurring of vision for 1 month. He says he could earlier drive the car home by himself but cannot do so now. He is a retired navy officer. He is otherwise vitally stable. The fundus examination is given below. Which of the following is the best treatment modality for this the patient’s current pathology?
questions.solution:
Given the symptoms described (gradual onset, painless, progressive blurring of vision) and the patient's age, the most likely diagnosis is age-related macular degeneration (AMD). AMD is a common eye condition among people over 50 and can cause significant vision loss.

The best treatment modality for wet AMD, which is characterized by the growth of abnormal blood vessels behind the retina, is Anti-VEGF therapy. Anti-VEGF drugs (such as ranibizumab, aflibercept, or bevacizumab) are injected into the eye to inhibit the growth of these abnormal blood vessels, preserving the remaining vision and sometimes even improving sight. This approach has been a significant advancement in the management of wet AMD.

Therefore, the correct answer is

Option D. Anti-VEGF therapy.

Options A, B, and C are not appropriate treatments for wet AMD. Vitrectomy is a surgical procedure used for conditions involving the vitreous humor of the eye. Macular grid photocoagulation is a technique used in specific cases of diabetic macular edema and might not be suitable for wet AMD. Spontaneous healing is not a realistic option for progressive vision loss due to conditions like wet AMD.

questions.text: A 52-year-old male driver who has been diagnosed with type 2 diabetes mellitus five years ago. The patient is being monitored at two intervals. At the second interval, he is diagnosed with proliferative retinopathy, which occurred in the middle of the first and second interval; some factor that contributes to occupational stress plays an important role in the progression of proliferative retinopathy. One of the earliest signs is microaneurysms of this condition. In this condition manifestation, which of the following layers is involved?
questions.solution:
Option C: Inner nuclear layer

  • Microaneurysms are localized outpouchings, mainly saccular, of the capillary wall that may form either by focal dilatation of the capillary wall where pericytes are absent or by fusion of two arms of a capillary loop.
  • Most develop in the inner capillary plexus (inner nuclear layer), frequently adjacent to areas of capillary non-perfusion.

Fluorescein angiogram illustrating multiple leaks corresponding to areas of microaneurysms and exudation.

Option A: Outer plexiform layer

  • The eye's retina contains a layer of neuronal synapses known as the outer plexiform layer (external plexiform layer).
  • It comprises an intricate web of synapses between the inner segments of photoreceptor cells from the outer nuclear layer with the dendrites of horizontal cells from the inner nuclear layer.
  • The inner plexiform layer, which connects amacrine cells to retinal ganglion cells, is substantially thinner than this.

Option B: Layer of rods and cones

  • Besides the macula lutea, rod and cone cells are the two types of components that make up the Layer of Rods and Cones (Jacob's membrane) in the eye's retina. Retinal section.

Option D: Retinal pigment epithelium

  • A single layer of regular polygonal cells positioned at the retina's outermost layer makes up the retinal pigment epithelium (RPE). While the inner side of the RPE is related to the outer segment of photoreceptor cells, the outer side is connected to Bruch's membrane and the choroid.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male who has previously been diagnosed with diabetes mellitus and has untreated bilateral diabetic retinopathy. Diabetic macular oedema rapidly exacerbated after he underwent cataract surgery in both eyes at another clinic. Investigation of his medical history reveals that in addition to diabetes, he has reduced renal function (creatinine 427 U/L, eGFR 24.5 (30> eGFR ≥15) due to poorly controlled high blood pressure and diabetic nephropathy. Which treatment modality of the disease should be uncertain for the following given picture?
questions.solution:
Option C: Photodynamic therapy

  • Given OCT is of Cystoid Macular Edema
  • Photodynamic therapy is used for wet ARMD or chronic CSCR, not cystoid macular oedema.
  • Cystoid macular oedema (CME)
    • Most common cause: Post intraocular surgery.
    • IOC: OCT
    • FA Appearance: Flower petal appearance.
    • Drugs Causing CME: Tamoxifen, PG analogues, epinephrine.
    • Rx: Wait & watch > NSAID > Anti VEGF / Intravitreal steroids/ Laser
  • Clinically severe foveal oedema and retinal thickness of more than 300 m can be observed as a loss of the foveal reflex using a slit lamp or direct/indirect ophthalmoscopy; this is best visible with the green light to delineate the cystic spaces.
  • Retinal imaging makes subclinical foveal oedema, which is defined as oedema less than 300 m, easier to see.
  • Clinical examinations can also reveal enlargement at the head of the optic nerve and vitiligo.

Option A: Intravitreal steroids

  • In persons with diabetic retinopathy, diabetic macular oedema (DME), which results from leaking from damaged retinal capillaries and thickness of the central retina, is a major contributor to decreased central visual acuity.
  • Steroids injected intravitreally have been used to treat DME patients' retinal thickness and enhance their vision.

Option B: Ozurdex

  • Ozurdex is a dexamethasone intravitreal implant
  • An implant called Ozurdex is injected into the eye.
  • Adults with macular oedema-related vision impairment are treated with it if they have any of the following:
  • Obstruction of the veins that supply blood from the back of the eye; diabetes-related blood vessel damage in patients with prosthetic lenses in their eyes or in whom other treatments failed or were not appropriate.

Option D: Intravitreal VEGF

  • To offer clinical advice on how to treat ocular vascular diseases like diabetic macular oedema, neovascular age-related macular degeneration, myopic choroidal neovascularization, retinal vein occlusion, and central serous chorioretinopathy with intravitreal anti-vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF) medications, particularly bevacizumab.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female presents in the outpatient department with complaints of severe headache, nausea, vomiting and blurry vision. She also gives the history of seeing rings around the lights. On examination, the eye is red and tender. On further evaluation, she develops pain in the eyes after a prone dark room test. A diagnosis of glaucoma is made. Which of the drugs should be avoided in this patient?
questions.solution:
Option D: Atropine

  • Pain after the dark room test indicates that the patient has occludable angles. Hence, atropine is contraindicated because its a long-acting mydriatic and may precipitate angle closure.

Option A: Acetazolamide

  • It is used as a systemic treatment for angle-closure glaucoma. It reduces the formation of aqueous by inhibiting the action of carbonic anhydrase enzyme. Thus, there is decreased formation of aqueous humor.

Option B: Pilocarpine

  • It is used as a local treatment for angle-closure glaucoma. It should be started half to one hour after the commencement of systemic treatment, i.e. after the IOP is lowered a bit. At higher pressure, the iris sphincter is ischemic and unresponsive to pilocarpine.

Option C: Timolol

  • It is used as a local treatment for angle-closure glaucoma.

questions.text: A 30-day-old baby presents with excessive lacrimation, corneal edema, photophobia, enlargement of the eye with buphthalmos, and Haab striae. The child is agitated and restless. He has a large hazy cornea in both eyes. His lacrimal system is normal. On gonioscopy, the iris has a scalloped appearance. The trabecular meshwork appears unusually thick and seems to be covered by a membrane. What is the treatment of choice for this case?
questions.solution:
Option B: Trabeculectomy + Trabeculotomy

  • Trabeculectomy is a type of glaucoma surgery performed on the eye that creates a new pathway for fluid inside the eye to be drained.
  • Trabeculotomy removes barriers to aqueous outflow from a congenital angle deformity. 

Option A: Trabeculectomy + MMC

  • Mitomycin C (MMC) is an antimetabolite applied between the sclera and conjunctiva during the initial stages of a trabeculectomy to prevent excessive post-operative scarring and thus reduce the risk of failure. It is not used to treat congenital glaucoma.

Option C: Goniotomy

  • It is not the treatment of choice in the current situation, as the cornea is hazy, that the angle cannot be seen well enough for goniotomy under direct visualization.

Option D: Iridotomy

  • Iridotomy is not used to treat congenital glaucoma.

questions.text: A patient presented with the complaint of the need for frequent changes in eyeglass prescriptions. He also experiences sudden worsening or clouding of vision. The doctor advises Computerized corneal mapping. He also observes a V-shaped indentation in the lower eyelid when the patient's gaze is directed downwards. What is the characteristic sign called?
questions.solution:
Option B: Munson Sign

  • The sign discussed in the question stem is the indentation of the lower lid in a downward gaze - Munson's Sign in Keratoconus.
  • Munson's sign is a V-shaped indentation observed in the lower eyelid when the patient's gaze is directed downwards.
  • The medical sign is characteristic of advanced cases of keratoconus.
  • It is caused by the cone-shaped cornea pressing down into the eyelid.

Option A: Rizutti Sign

  • Rizzuti's sign -- In patients with advanced keratoconus, lateral illumination of the cornea from the temporal side produces a sharply focused conical beam of light near the nasal limbus.
  • The sign discussed in the question stem is Munson sign.

Option C: Bow tie pattern

  • Bow tie pattern is seen in cases of optic atrophy when chiasma atrophy takes place.
  • The sign discussed in the question stem is Munson sign.

Option D: Bull's eye sign

  • Seen in maculopathies.
  • The term bull's-eye maculopathy refers to the ophthalmoscopic appearance of a central area of retinal pigment epithelial depigmentation surrounded by relatively normal retinal pigment epithelium giving a "bull's-eye" appearance to the macula.

questions.text: Herpes zoster along the maxillary division of the trigeminal nerve is a rare condition caused by reactivation of the varicella-zoster virus that resides within the trigeminal ganglion after the primary infection of chickenpox. Mark the incorrect statement about the condition.

choices.text: The most specific nerve involved is the lacrimal nerve
The most common nerve involved is the Frontal nerve
The painful rash typically involves specific dermatome supplied by branches of the trigeminal nerve

questions.solution:
Option A: The most specific nerve involved is the lacrimal nerve

  • The nasociliary nerve is the most important nerve involved in herpes zoster infection.
  • HERPES ZOSTER OPHTHALMICUS
    • Most specific nerve involved: Nasociliary branch of the Frontal division of the Trigeminal Nerve.
    • H/o immunosuppression to be ruled out.

Option B:The most common nerve involved is the Frontal nerve

  • Causative agent: Varicella zoster infection
  • Ramsay Hunt syndrome (herpes zoster oticus) occurs when a shingles outbreak affects the facial nerve near one of the ears.
  •  In addition to the painful shingles rash, Ramsay Hunt syndrome can cause facial paralysis and hearing loss in the affected ear.
  • Most commonly, the rash occurs in a single dermatome around the body's left or right side. In other cases, the rash occurs on one side of the face.
  •  Shingles on the face can affect the eye and cause vision loss.

Option C: The painful rash typically involving specific dermatome supplied by branches of the trigeminal nerve

  • The painful dermatomal rash typically involves the dermatome supplied by the trigeminal nerve.
  • Trigeminal herpes zoster with Ramsay Hunt syndrome may produce cutaneous, intraoral, and otic vesicles, hearing loss, and mild facial palsy.
  • Herpes zoster of the maxillary division of the trigeminal nerve may begin with a toothache during its prodromal stage, followed by its vesicular eruption.

Option D: Hutchinson's Sign suggests corneal involvement

  • Hutchinson Sign: Involvement of nasociliary nerve, which produces lesions on the tip of the nose and suggests corneal involvement.
  • It reflects zoster involvement of the first branch of the trigeminal nerve and is concerning for herpes zoster ophthalmicus.
  • Herpes zoster vesicles may present as papular lesions or macular vesicles on an erythematous base.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy presents to the clinic with a complaint of fever chills and left thigh pain for the past 3 hours. Two days ago, he injured his thighs while playing football. His lower left thigh is hot, swollen, and tender on examination. The knee joint appears normal and has a full range of motion. The patient has a temperature of 38.3ºC. An X-ray of the left femur is done, indicating soft tissue swelling without any apparent abnormalities of the bone. Which of the following is the most commonly affected area in this condition?
questions.solution:
Based on the information provided, the most likely diagnosis in this case is osteomyelitis, which is an infection of the bone. Osteomyelitis can result from the spread of bacteria to the bone through the bloodstream or from direct introduction of bacteria into the bone tissue, often occurring after an injury. The presentation of fever, chills, thigh pain, swelling, and tenderness is characteristic of acute osteomyelitis.

Explanation of Options:

  1. Epiphysis: The epiphysis is the end part of a long bone that develops separately from the main bone. Infections primarily affecting the epiphysis are relatively less common than in other parts of the bone. Epiphyseal involvement is not a typical feature of osteomyelitis.

  2. Diaphysis: The diaphysis is the main shaft or middle part of a long bone. While osteomyelitis can affect any part of the bone, including the diaphysis, it more commonly affects other areas, particularly the metaphysis.

  3. Metaphysis (Correct Option): The metaphysis is the region of a long bone where the growth plate (physis) is located. It is the most common site for osteomyelitis, especially in children. This is due to the relatively slower blood flow and the presence of terminal vessels in this area, making it more susceptible to bacterial infections.

  4. Articular Surface: The articular surface is the portion of the bone that forms a joint with another bone. While joint infections (septic arthritis) can occur, the symptoms described in the scenario, including thigh pain, fever, and localized tenderness, are more indicative of osteomyelitis rather than a primary joint infection.

In summary, the correct answer is 3. Metaphysis. Osteomyelitis often affects the metaphyseal region of long bones, especially in children, due to the unique blood supply and growth plate anatomy in this area.

questions.text: A 5-year-old male patient presents to the hospital with multiple punched-out lytic lesions over the skull and trunk. The lesions present with granulomatous collections. IHC markers are positive for CD1a and CD201. Which of the following is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option B: Langerhans cell histiocytosis

  • The grooved nuclei and lytic lesion in the first decade suggest Langerhans cell histiocytosis.
  • Langerhans cell histiocytosis: Destruction due to histiocytes, idiopathic.
  • Treatment includes spontaneous resolution.
  • Highly radiosensitive and excision + curettage for resistant cases.
  • Histiocytosis-X defines as an unusual group of disorders in which cells of the reticuloendothelial system (histiocytes and eosinophils) form granulomatous collections, which may cause osteolytic lesions which resemble bone tumors.
  • Multiple osteolytic lesions in the skull have a characteristic punched-out appearance.
  • Vertebral collapse may result in a flat wedge (vertebra plana) which is pathognomonic.
  • Multiple myeloma is a malignant B-cell lymphoproliferative disorder of the marrow, with plasma cells predominating.
  • The patient is usually in the 4th to 5th decade of life, which in the case of histiocytosis is mostly in the 1st and 2nd decade.
  • Osseous hemangiomas consist of vascular channels (capillary, venous, or cavernous) and are usually seen in middle-aged patients, the spine being the commonest site.
  • The x-ray shows coarse vertical trabeculation, the so-called 'corduroy appearance' in the vertebral body.

Option A: Multiple myeloma

  • Multiple myeloma is a malignant B-cell lymphoproliferative disorder of the marrow, with plasma cells predominating.
  • The patient is usually in the 4th to 5th decade of life, which in the case of histiocytosis is mostly in the 1st and 2nd decade.
  • Punched out lytic lesions
  • Plasma cell leukemia> 20% plasma cells in peripheral smear

Option C: Hemangioma

  • X-rays show a Corduroy appearance and Vertical striations in the vertebra: "Jail bar appearance."
  • CT scan: Shows unequal dot signs known as "Polka Dot Sign," characteristic & very rare.

Option D: Osteolysis

  • Osteolysis is a progressive disappearance of bone associated with hemangiomatosis or multiple lymphangiectasis.

questions.text: A 5-day-old newborn baby is admitted to the hospital in an agonal state with pale mucosa and acute respiratory failure. The child's mother did not have a prenatal follow-up. She reports the non-existence of disease in the family. An X-ray of the child is given below. Which of the following is not true about the given condition?
questions.solution:
Option C: Cataract

Cataract

  • The given radiograph shows bowing of long bones due to multiple transverse fractures in the femur, humerus right 3rd, 4th, and 6th posterior ribs.
  • The most common cause of fracture in childhood is Osteogenesis imperfecta.
  • A cataract is not seen in Osteogenesis Imperfecta

Osteogenesis Imperfecta

  • Bone fragility (brittle "wormian" bone)
  • Short stature
  • Scoliosis
  • Tooth defects (Dentinogenesis imperfecta)
  • Hearing defects
  • Blue sclerae in Types I and II
  • Ligamentous laxity
  • Classification: Four types have been identified
Type Inheritance Sclerae Features
1A,1B A.D. Blue

Onset at preschool age (Tarda); hearing loss; involvement of

teeth (type I.A. only)
II A.R. Blue Lethal; concertina femur, beaded ribs
III A.R. Normal

Fractures at birth, progressively short stature

I.V.A., IVB AD Normal

IV-A,

IV-B		 AD Normal Milder form; normal hearing, involvement of teeth (type I.V.A. only)
  • Treatment:
    • Fracture management
    • Bracing
    • Bisphosphonates

Option A: Blue sclera

  • Because of collagen defects in the blood vessels of the sclera, the scleral vessels become thin.
  • This causes the underlying choroidal vasculature to be seen, giving the sclera a blue appearance

Option B: Multiple Fractures

  • Type I collagen is the major part of the bone.
  • It provides tensile strength to the bone.
  • A defect can lead to weak bone that results in multiple fractures.

Option D: Hearing loss

  • Osteosclerosis or fracture of the bones of the middle ear may result in hearing loss.

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy presents to the clinic for the evaluation of his arm deformity for the past 2 months. Four months ago, he fell from the roof and got his humerus fractured. At that time, he was treated by a local doctor for his injury. On examination, his arm findings are given below.Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's current deformity?
questions.solution:
Option B: Supracondylar fracture Humerus

  • The images show Cubitus varus deformity.
  • Cubitus varus (Gunstock deformity): Caused by supracondylar fracture of humerus leading to varus malunion, especially in medial comminution pattern.
  • Cubitus varus: Carrying angle decreases

Option A: Humerus lateral condylar fracture

  • Intra-Articular Fracture
  • This can also lead to ''Tardy Ulnar nerve palsy.''
  • Complication: Cubitus valgus is caused by the Non- union of fracture of lateral condyle of the Humerus bone.

Option C: Fracture shaft Humerus

  • Radial nerve injury leads to wrist drop.
  • The most common cause of radial nerve injury is the Fracture shaft Humerus.

Option D: Medial Condyle fracture of humerus

  • It is a type of avulsion injury.

questions.text: The introduction lecture on modern microbiology lab microbiologists tells about the electron microscope that which is a microscope that uses a beam of accelerated electrons as a source of illumination. It is used to investigate inorganic specimens, including microorganisms and macromolecules. Who is the founder of the Electron microscope?
questions.solution:
Option B: Ernst Ruska

  • Ernst August Friedrich Ruska was born on 25 December 1906 and died on 27 May 1988.
  • He was a german physicist who won the Nobel prize in physics in 1986 for his work in electron optics, including designing the first electron microscope.

Electron microscope:

  • A beam of electrons used instead of a Light beam focused by circular magnets instead of a lens object is held in the path of beam scatters the electrons by object image is formed on fluorescent viewing screen maximum resolution can obtain [0.2nm-0.5nm] (100 times better than light microscope) vacuum is used.

Option A: Antonie van Leeuwenhoek

  •  Father of microscopy.
  • The first person to observe and describe microorganisms accurately was amateur microscopist Antonie van Leeuwenhoek (1632–1723).
  • He coined the term " Little Animalcules" For microorganisms.

Option C: Robert Koch:

  • Father of modern microbiology.
  • Proposed KOCH POSTULATES.
  • Discovered TB and cholera bacilli.
  • Proposed hanging drop method, aniline dye staining, and solid media concept.

Note: Bacteria that do not follow KOCH postulates are Mycobacterium leprae and Treponema pallidum.

Option D: Louis Pasteur:

  • Father of microbiology.
  • Proposed fermentation principle.
  • Disapproved abiogenesis theory.
  • Proposed germ theory, autoclave & hot air oven, and pasteurization of milk.
  • Vaccines:
    • C → Cholera
    • A → Anthrax
    • R → Rabies

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1, at 37 weeks gestation, is admitted to the hospital in active labour. Her current pregnancy has been complicated by iron deficiency anaemia treated with iron tablets. She has received routine prenatal care but has not been tested for group B streptococcal (GBS) colonization. An infection complicated the pregnancy and delivery of her first child with GBS, which resulted in sepsis in the newborn. Concerning immunoglobulin, Which is the earliest immunoglobulin to be synthesized by the fetus?
questions.solution:
Option D: IgM

The earliest immunoglobulin to be synthesized by the fetus is IgM.

  • IgM is the first immunoglobulin synthesized by a fetus at about 20 weeks.

  • Maximum molecular weight is also known as MILLIONAIRE MOLECULE.

  • IgM is not transported across the placenta; hence, IgM in the fetus or newborn indicates intrauterine infection.

  • It has a maximum sedimentation coefficient.

  • The first immunoglobulin to be produced in any immune response.

  • It is the most efficient. Because its interaction with antigens can involve all ten binding sites, it has the highest binding capacity and cross-linking of all the immunoglobulins.

Option A: IgA

  • Most abundant immunoglobulin in the body but has a low serum concentration

  • Monomer in circulation and dimer when secreted (then containing J chain).

  • Uses transcytosis to cross epithelial borders.

  • Found especially on mucosal surfaces and in bodily fluids like saliva, mucus, tears, and breast milk.

  • Prevents the binding of pathogens to mucous membranes of host cells.

  • A secretory component acquired from epithelial cells protects IgA from luminal proteases (e.g., in the gastrointestinal tract)

  • No complement fixation.

Option B: IgG

  • Maximum in concentration.

  • Maximum t1/2 → 23 Days.

  • The Fc portion of IgG involves in opsonization (enhancement of phagocytosis).

  • Only Ig which pass through the placenta.

Option C: IgE

  • Binds to mast cells → cross-linking upon allergen exposure → release of histamine (involved in allergic diseases).

  • Binds to basophils.

questions.text: A 35-year-old female presents to the emergency department with complaints of an itchy lesion on her skin. The rash developed shortly after she took an antibiotic for a urinary tract infection. Her temperature is 37.5°C (99.3°F), her pulse is 88/min, and her blood pressure is 100/60 mm Hg. Physical examination shows swelling of the face and raised erythematous plaques on her trunk and extremities. A procedure is done to identify antigens and antibodies, shown in the image below. Which of the following is the investigation involved in this case?
questions.solution:
Option C: Oakley-Fulthrope procedure

  • This is a case of hypersensitivity type-1 reaction in which the patient presents with complaints of itchy lesions on her skin.

  • Double diffusion in one dimension (Oakley-Fulthorpe procedure)


                           Antibody incorporated in the gel

                                                ↓
                      A column of plain agar was placed above it

                                                ↓
                          Antigen layered on top of the agar

                                                ↓
Antigen and antibody move towards each other through the intervening column of plain agar

                                                 ↓
                     Band of precipitate at the optimum proportion

 

Option A: Oudin procedure

  • Oudin procedure → Single diffusion in one dimension.

Option B: Mancini method

  • Mancini method or radial immunodiffusion → Single diffusion in two dimensions.

Option D: Ochterlony procedure

  • Ochterlony procedure → Double diffusion in two dimensions.

questions.text: An 8-year-old girl is brought by her parents to the pediatric outpatient clinic with the complaint of recurrent falls due to difficulty maintaining balance. On examination, her pulse is 80 beats/min, blood pressure is 110/80 mmHg and respiratory rate is 18 breaths/min, and spider telangiectasia can be seen all over the face of the patient. The doctor ordered some lab studies that showed elevated AFP levels. Which type of defect is associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
Option C: Defect in DNA repair

  • A defect in DNA repair is associated with this condition.

  • The given scenario suggests the diagnosis of Ataxia Telangiectasia.

Ataxia Telangiectasia:

  • Autosomal-recessive disorder.

  • Due to a defect in the ATM gene (chromosome 11q), which is a sensor of DNA damage.

  • Defective DNA repair.

  • Abnormal isotype switching & increased cancer risk.

  • Clinical features: Present in the first decade of life with progressive telangiectatic lesions associated with deficits in cerebellar function and nystagmus.

    • Ataxia

    • Oculocutaneous telangiectasia

    • Immunodeficiency

    • Increased sensitivity to ionizing radiation

    • Increased risk of lymphocytic malignancies & adenocarcinoma

  • Diagnosis:

    • Low IgA, IgE & IgG2 levels.

    • Elevated AFP levels.

Option A: Defect in cellular transport

  • Transport proteins play an important role in the maintenance of homeostasis.

  • Genetic mutations lead to a number of hereditary diseases associated with cellular transport.

  • Examples include cystic fibrosis, nephrogenic diabetes insipidus, and Wilson’s disease, etc.

Option B: Defect in microtubule function

  • Defects in microtubule function can lead to cell death and aneuploidy.

  • It is mostly associated with neurodegenerative diseases.

Option D: Defect in cell surface receptor

  • Cell surface receptors are proteins found embedded in the plasma membrane and help maintain communication between internal processes and extracellular signals.

  • Examples include diabetes mellitus, hyperthyroidism etc.

questions.text: A 41-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of a cough, dyspnea, and fever for 1 day. The cough is productive of small amounts of green phlegm. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 22 years. His temperature is 39.1°C (103.1°F), the pulse is 112/min, respirations are 32/min, and blood pressure is 132/83 mm Hg. Pulmonary examination shows diffuse crackles and rhonchi. An X-ray of the chest shows a left upper lobe infiltrate of the lung. Concerning immunity, after a couple of weeks, a specific response from the adaptive immune system will appear in the patient's body. This high specificity or affinity maturation of T cells is due to the following:
questions.solution:
Option A: Somatic Hypermutation

  • The above is a case of pneumonia, just an infectious example to elaborate.
  • The fever, productive cough and x ray findings are suggestive.
  • Somatic hypermutation is a process in which point mutation accumulates in the antibody V-regions of both the heavy and light chains at rates that are about 106-fold higher than the background mutation rates observed in other genes.
  • Cells that emerge will have a stronger and more specific response to the antigen - and this is called affinity maturation.

Option B: VDJ rearrangement

  • VDJ rearrangement is the process by which T cells and B cells randomly assemble different gene segments – known as variable (V), diversity (D) and joining (J) genes – in order to generate unique receptors (known as antigen receptors) that can collectively recognize many different types of molecule.

Option C: mRNA splicing

  • During the splicing process, the spliceosome removes introns from the pre-mRNA, and exons are spliced back together.
  • If the introns are not removed, the RNA will be translated into a nonfunctional protein.
  • Splicing occurs in the nucleus before the RNA migrates to the cytoplasm.

Option D: Isotype switching

  • Immunoglobulin class switching (or isotype switching, or isotypic commutation, or class switch recombination (CSR)) is a biological mechanism that changes a B cell's antibody production from one class to another; for example, from an isotype called IgM to an isotype called IgG

questions.text: In most prokaryotic cells, glycocalyx forms a protective layer external to the cell wall called the capsule. A capsule is a negatively charged and smooth structure of a prokaryotic cell that prevents the adhesion of phagocytes and the engulfment of invading bacteria by the cells of the host immune system. Which of the following microorganisms lack this protective mechanism?
questions.solution:
Option D: Proteus

  • As mentioned in the question, the capsule provides the protective mechanism against the host immune system, and 'a-capsular' microorganisms lack the capsule and, therefore, the protection it provides.
  • A capsule is a well-organized polysaccharide layer outside the cell envelope.
    • It protects the host immune system and can cause various diseases.
    • It is found both in gram-positive and gram-negative microorganisms.
  • Based on the presence and absence of the capsule, microorganisms are categorized into encapsulated and non-encapsulated.
    • Encapsulated gram-negative bacteria include E. coli, Neisseria meningitides (meningococcus), Klebsiella pneumoniae, H. influenzae, Salmonella, and Pseudomonas aeruginosa.
    • Encapsulated gram-positive bacteria include Bacillus anthracis, Streptococcus pyogenes, Streptococcus pneumoniae (pneumococcus), Streptococcus agalactiae, Staphylococcus epidermidis, Staphylococcus aureus, and Lactococcus garvieae.
    • However, proteus is a non-encapsulated gram-negative microorganism.

Option A: Pneumococcus

  • Pneumococcus (Streptococcus pneumoniae) is an encapsulated gram-positive coccus.

Option B: Cryptococcus

  • Cryptococcus neoformans is an encapsulated yeast.

Option C: Meningococcus

  • Meningococcus (Neisseria meningitidis) is an encapsulated gram-negative microorganism.

questions.text: A 62-year-old male patient presents signs and symptoms suggestive of meningitis which has been resistant to antibiotics for his current illness for the last 02 weeks. His MRI brain is revealing ventriculomegaly and a brain abscess. Importantly, he has a pathognomic feature of fungal infection. Later he is suspected of having a fungal disease. His sample was sent for staining and further processing to confirm the diagnosis. Which of the following is a correctly matched stain in this patient?
questions.solution:
Option A: India Ink-Cryptococcus

  • Based on signs and symptoms patient is suffering from cryptococcus neoformans, which stains India Ink.
  • Entry to the CNS is a vital step in cryptococcal pathogenesis. Various reports revealed that internalised and free cryptococci enter the blood-brain barrier to reach the brain, either by transcytosis through barrier epithelial cells or between them via the break of the tight junctions.
  • The best-studied virulence factor of C. neoformans is its polysaccharide capsule.

C. Neoformans capsule images:

  1. Top row: Negative stain with India ink; quick-freeze deep-etch electron micrograph of a portion of the cell wall with capsule fibres extending to the left); thin section electron micrograph of three cells.
  2. Bottom row: Immunoelectron micrograph of a portion of a cell (capsule fibres extending upwards) stained with gold-conjugated anti-capsule antibody; differential interference contrast micrograph of a budding cell; confocal immunofluorescence micrograph with the capsule stained blue and the cell wall stained green.

 

  • A modified technique employs 2% chromium mercury and India ink. This technique identifies some external and internal structures of the organism.

 

 

Option B: Lactophenol cotton blue– Candida

  • Candida is a commensal of the human body and an opportunistic pathogen frequently responsible for hospital-acquired bloodstream infections.
  • Candida cells can merge with bacteria within biofilms, especially through chemical or metabolic indirect interactions and direct physical contact involving the yeast or hyphal form of the fungal cells.
  • Lactophenol cotton blue is a mixture of methyl blue and lactophenol (a solution of phenol, lactic acid, and glycerol in water).

 

Option C: Methanamine silver – Aspergillus

  • The major species known to cause disease in humans are found in five Aspergillus species: 
    • Fumigation
    • Flavi
    • Nigri
    • Terrie
    • Nidulante
  • In humans, Aspergillus fumigatus is the mainstream and life-threatening airborne opportunistic fungal pathogen, which is particularly important among immunocompromised patients.
  • Bronchoalveolar lavage (BAL) with methenamine silver stain is commonly used to detect pneumocystis carinii and fungal organisms as causes of infectious pulmonic disease in immunosuppressed patients.

 

 

Option D: Gram’s stain– Pneumocystis carinii

  • Whether P carinii is a fungus or a protozoan is not yet established. Antigenic differences have been found in strains derived from the various mammalian hosts.
  • Tachypnea, dyspnea and cough, and fever—are the usual symptoms of Pneumocystis pneumonia.
