  • In normal individuals, asymptomatic infection of the lungs occurs in early life. The organism remains inactive or latent unless the host becomes immunocompromised. Organisms add to the alveolar septal wall resulting in diffuse alveolitis and impaired oxygenation.
  • A Gram stain is a test that denotes bacteria at the site of a suspected infection, such as the throat, lungs, genitals, or in skin wounds. Gram stains may also identify bacteria in certain body fluids, such as blood or urine.

questions.text: A 26-year-old man presents to the dermatology clinic with a round, red and itchy rash on the nape of his neck for the past 3 days. On examination, it is inflamed with a scaly border and a slightly raised skin lesion. He reports that his dog sleeps next to him and has some localized areas of hair loss. The doctor takes skin scrapings from the lesion and sends it to the lab. The specimen is treated with KOH and examined microscopically. What is the most probable finding seen in these scraping?

choices.text: Clusters of yeast-like cells and short curved septate hyphae
Hyphae with little branching but possibly with some hyphae breaking up into arthroconidia
Budding yeast with some pseudohyphae and true hyphae

questions.solution:
Option B: Hyphae with little branching but possibly with some hyphae breaking up into arthroconidia 

  • It is a case of ringworm (dermatophytosis) acquired from the dog. Ringworms are circular, itchy, inflamed, and slightly raised. This particular type of ringworm is tinea corporis (body). On examination, dermatophytes would show hyphae and arthroconidia.
  • Dermatophytosis is a cutaneous infection caused by a large group of related fungi called dermatophytes. Infection is generally confined to the cornified layer of the skin and its appendages.
  • Zoophilic dermatophytes primarily infect animals and occasionally spread to humans through direct contact.
  • Dermatophytic fungi are hyaline filamentous fungi. They are classified into three genera: Trichophyton, Microsporum, and Epidermophyton.
  • Clinical classification is according to the anatomic site involved:
    • Tinea barbae (barber’s itch). It involves the beard on the face and neck.
    • Tinea corporis. It is a ringworm of the smooth or non-hairy skin of the body.
    • Tinea imbricata. It is a type of tinea corporis found in the tropics, which presents with characteristic extensive concentric rings of papulosquamous scaly patches.
    • Tinea capitis is a ringworm of the scalp. Favus and kerion are variants.
    • Tinea cruris involves the groin and perineum
    • Tinea pedis is ringworm of the foot
  • These lesions in the skin tend to be circular, dry, erythematous, scaly, and itchy.
  • A wet preparation of the specimen is made by placing the scrapings in a drop of KOH on a slide. Branching hyaline (non-pigmented) septate hyphae is considered positive for fungi; spores may sometimes be seen.

Option A: Clusters of yeast-like cells and short curved septate hyphae

  • Pityriasis Versicolor would reveal clusters of yeasts with short, septate, curved hyphae (spaghetti and meatball appearance), as shown in the image below.
  • It is a chronic, usually asymptomatic involvement of the stratum corneum.
  • The lipophilic yeast-like fungus Malassezia furfur is the causative agent.
  • Clinical features include characteristic discrete macular discolouration areas on the chest, abdomen, upper limbs and back skin.

Option C: Filariform larvae

  • Filariform larvae are the characteristic of hookworm, usually acquired from walking barefoot where dog faeces are present.
  • It would not be acquired from sleeping with the dog and would not cause localized hair loss in the dog.

Option D: Budding yeasts with some pseudohyphae and true hyphae

  • It is observed in Candida species.
  • Candida causes infection of the skin, mucosa, and rarely of the internal organs known as candidiasis. It is an opportunistic endogenous infection.
  • Candida albicans is an ovoid or spherical budding cell that produces pseudohyphae in the tissues and culture, as shown in the image below.

questions.text: A 28-year-old presents to the physician with complaints of bloody diarrhoea, stomach pain, fever and loss of appetite for 6 days. The patient gives no history of any other abnormalities. He has no history of any chronic illness. The patient is vitally stable. On examination, flask-shaped ulcers were seen. Which of the following is the best serological test to diagnose the given condition?
questions.solution:
Option A: ELISA

  • This is a case of intestinal amoebiasis in which the patient presents with complaints of bloody diarrhoea, stomach pain, fever, and loss of appetite for 6 days.
  • Flask-shaped ulcers are seen in intestinal amoebiasis.
  • The best serological diagnostic test for amoebiasis is ELISA.
  • Amoebic lectin antigen (Gal/NAG lectin) is the principal virulence factor present on the surface of trophozoites of pathogenic Entamoeba histolytica. Its various pathogenic mechanisms are adhesion, cytotoxicity, and complement resistance.
  • Serological tests (ELISA, IHA, etc.) become positive only in Invasive amoebiasis.
  • ELISA: detects 170kDa of lectin Ag in stool with 95% sensitivity and specificity. It can also differentiate pathogenic Entamoeba histolytica from non-pathogenic Entamoeba dispar (Negative for Lectin Ag).
  • IHA: it uses crude Ag to detect Amoebic Abs (IgG). IgG appears only in the later stage of intestinal amoebiasis.

Option B: Countercurrent immunoelectrophoresis

  • Electrophoresis: it is used for isoenzyme (Zymodeme) analysis.
  • Zymodeme (isoenzyme) analysis: -
    • E. histolytica possesses several isoenzymes like malic enzyme, hexokinase, isomerase, and phosphoglucomutase, and these isoenzymes contribute to pathogenesis.
    • When these isoenzymes are subjected to electrophoresis, based on the electrophoretic pattern (Zymodeme pattern) and mobility of these isoenzymes, Entamoeba can be diagnosed and speciated.

Option C: Haemagglutination test

  • The Haemagglutination test is a classical way of determining blood cell type.
  • It is not used in cases of intestinal amoebiasis.

Option D: Complement fixation test

  • Complement fixation test: it is not used in the diagnosis of amoebiasis.
  • It is used for determining the antibodies in the CSF.

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman attended the outpatient department with a lump measuring 5x4cm in the upper outer quadrant of her right breast. A fine needle aspiration cytology of the lump revealed invasive ductal carcinoma. As a result, she underwent a Patey's modified radical mastectomy. During the procedure, which structure is preserved?
questions.solution:
Option B: Pectoralis major

  • In Patey’s modified mastectomy, the pectoralis major is preserved.
  • Modified Radical mastectomy
    • Removal of level I, II, and III axillary lymph nodes with preservation of pectoralis major muscle and medial (anterior thoracic) pectoral nerve.
  • Anatomic boundaries:
    • Anterior margin of latissimus dorsi muscle laterally
    • The midline of the sternum medially
    • Subclavius muscle superiorly
    • 2 to 3 cm inferior to the inframammary fold inferiorly

Options A: Intercostobrachial nerve

  • Intercostobrachial nerve is not preserved during the modified radical mastectomy.

Option C: Pectoralis minor

  • Pectoralis minor is not preserved during the modified radical mastectomy.

Option D:  Axillary fascia

  • Axillary fascia is not preserved during the modified radical mastectomy.

questions.text: A 67-year-old female presents in the surgical outpatient department due to the progressively increasing size of her left breast for the last 2 months. She also complains of itching, heaviness, and an increased temperature in her left breast. Physical examination reveals widespread erythema, intense edema, and areolar erosion of the breast, with several enlarged axillary lymph nodes on the left side. Which of the following is the best treatment for this patient?

choices.text: Neoadjuvant chemotherapy followed by modified radical mastectomy and radiotherapy

questions.solution:
Option A: Neoadjuvant chemotherapy followed by modified radical mastectomy and radiotherapy

  • This elderly female with skin thickening, erythema, the warmth of her breast, and palpable axillary lymph nodes most likely has locally invasive inflammatory breast cancer.
  • Inflammatory breast carcinoma accounts for <3% of breast cancers.
  • Inflammatory breast cancer is a subtype of invasive ductal carcinoma which does not commonly present with a palpable lump.
  • It usually presents with an inflamed, swollen breast with thickening of the overlying skin (peau d’orange appearance) due to blockage of dermal lymphatics.
  • Inflammatory breast cancer can sometimes be misdiagnosed as mastitis due to its presentation.
  • At least 33% of skin over the breast is involved with a history of rapid onset and progression.
  • More than 75% of women have palpable axillary lymphadenopathy and distant metastasis.
  • This patient most likely has stage IIIB breast cancer (tumor spread to the chest wall and axillary lymph nodes with no involvement of other organs).
  • The treatment of inflammatory breast cancer includes neoadjuvant chemotherapy (given before the surgery) to reduce tumor size.
  • Neoadjuvant chemotherapy is followed by modified radical mastectomy (removal of the entire breast including skin, nipple, areola, and axillary lymph nodes with sparing of the pectoralis major and minor muscles).
  • Modified radical mastectomy is followed by radiotherapy to remove any residual tumor cells.

Option B: Radical mastectomy followed by chemotherapy

  • Radical mastectomy involves the removal of the entire breast, nipple, areola, overlying skin, axillary lymph nodes, and pectoralis major and minor muscles.
  • Patients with inflammatory breast cancer are treated with modified radical mastectomy as it has better outcomes than radical mastectomy.

Option C: Radical mastectomy followed by radiotherapy

  • The treatment of inflammatory breast cancer is initiated with neoadjuvant chemotherapy.
  • In addition, modified radical mastectomy is preferred over radical mastectomy for treating inflammatory breast cancer.

Option D: Chemotherapy followed by hormone therapy

  • Chemotherapy and hormonal therapy are the mainstays of treatment for metastatic breast cancer (that has spread to other body organs).
  • This patient has locally invasive inflammatory breast cancer that can be treated with chemotherapy, surgery, and radiotherapy.
  • Surgical treatment is the definitive treatment for stage III breast cancer to remove residual cancer from the chest wall and axilla.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presented to the OPD complaining of weight loss, palpitations, tremors, and increased sweating. Diffuse swelling in front of the neck is noted. Her TSH levels were low, and T3 and T4 were elevated.. Further evaluation narrowed down the diagnosis to Graves’ disease. In thyrotoxicosis, β-blockers are used for symptomatic control of symptoms. Which of the following symptoms are not controlled by β-blockers?
questions.solution:
Option D: Pretibial myxedema

  • Pretibial myxedema is also called thyroid dermopathy. It is an autoimmune manifestation of Graves disease. These patients have high concentrations of thyroid-stimulating hormone receptor antibodies that stimulate the thyroid hormone receptors in the connective tissue leading to an immune-mediated response. It involves the activation of the fibroblasts and the production of large amounts of glycosaminoglycans.
  • Therefore, such symptoms are not caused by a sympathetic or adrenergic-mediated response. Therefore, beta-blockers have no role in the treatment of myxedema.
  • Treatment is rather done by topical corticosteroids, systemic immunomodulation, and local compressive therapy.

Option A: Anxiety

  • The beta-blockers inhibit the peripheral adrenergic actions of catecholamines, causing inhibition of the sympathetic system-mediated effects. This leads to the suppression of anxiety.

Option B: Tremors

  • Tremors are one of the effects of increased sympathetic outflow. This is due to increased thyroid hormone levels stimulating the release of catecholamines.
  • Beta-blockers inhibit the effects of catecholamines by inhibiting the receptors, thus resulting in the suppression of tremors.

Option C: Tachycardia

  • Tachycardia is caused by increased activation of the beta-1 receptors by the catecholamines. Increased thyroid hormones cause increased sympathetic outflow, and thus inhibition of adrenergic effects of catecholamines is mediated by the beta blockers.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female presented to the surgery OPD with complaints of swelling in front of her neck. She gives a history of irradiation to her neck during her childhood for Hodgkin lymphoma, which was cured. Her neck examination reveals a hard mass in front of her neck. A FNAC of the thyroid lump is done, which confirms a thyroid carcinoma with no lymph node involvement. Her biopsy picture is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option A: Papillary carcinoma

  • In the case mentioned above, the patient's clinical features of swelling in the front of the neck associated with hoarseness of voice and biopsy findings suggest Papillary thyroid carcinoma (PTC).
  • Pathology of papillary thyroid carcinoma:
    • Papillary projections
    • Optically clear nuclei aka Orphan Annie Eye Nuclei
    • Pseudo-inclusion bodies
    • Dystrophic calcification- Psammoma bodies

  • Papillary thyroid carcinoma (PTC) is the most common thyroid malignancy and usually is associated with an excellent prognosis, particularly in young patients.
  • Occasionally, a metastatic PTC manifests as a painless lateral neck mass that is clinically detected before detecting the primary thyroid lesion called lateral aberrant thyroid
  • Prognostic risk classification for PTC includes the AGES and AMES scoring systems.
  • The absence of distant metastasis at initial treatment and size less than 4cm are other important positive predictors.
  • Total Thyroidectomy is recommended for all PTCs 1cm or larger
  • PTCs less than 1 cm in diameter are defined as microcarcinomas.

Option B: Follicular carcinoma

  • Follicular thyroid cancer is the second most common type, making up about 10 to 15% of all thyroid cancers.

Option C: Medullary carcinoma

  • Medullary carcinoma is a rare type of thyroid cancer.
  • Medullary thyroid cancer (MTC) cells can be secreted by various tumor markers, including calcitonin and carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA).

Option D: None of the above

  • The clinical case and biopsy picture above suggest Papillary carcinoma of the thyroid.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male patient presented to your clinic with complaints of abdominal pain radiating to the back, early satiety, and fullness. During his workup, an incidental adrenal mass was found on the abdominal CT scan. Which of the following is an indication for adrenalectomy in this patient?
questions.solution:
Option D: All of the above

Indications of surgery in Incidentaloma:

  • Suspicious imaging characteristics (irregular margins)
  • Size >5 cm
  • Bilateral adrenal metastasis
  • Functional tumor
  • Young age
  • Interval tumor growth
  • Patient preference
  • Patients with worsening hypertension, abnormal glucose tolerance, or osteoporosis

Adrenal incidentalomas:

  • Adrenal lesions discovered during imaging performed for unrelated reasons are referred to as incidentalomas
  • The incidence of these lesions identified by CT scans ranges from 0.4 to 4.4%

  • Arrow points towards non-functioning adrenal adenocarcinoma.

Option A: Size >5 cm

  • Incidental adrenal masses with a size > 5 cm have a high risk of being malignant. Therefore, adrenalectomy is indicated in such masses. 

Option B: Bilateral adrenal metastasis

  • Bilateral adrenal metastasis indicates malignancy; therefore, adrenalectomy is indicated in such cases.

Option C: Functional tumor

  • Functional incidental adrenal tumors produce troublesome symptoms; therefore, adrenalectomy is indicated in such cases.

questions.text: A 56-year-old female presents to the clinic with a palpable lump in the breast. After the triple assessment, the diagnosis has been labelled as locally advanced breast cancer. Which of the following does not classify as locally advanced breast cancer?
questions.solution:
Option A: Tumor >4cm

  •  According to the recent guidelines from the U.S. National Comprehensive Cancer Network, locally advanced breast cancer is described as AJCC stage III breast cancer.
  • The definition  of locally advanced breast cancer includes breast cancer that fulfils any of the following criteria in the absence of distant metastasis:
    • Tumours more than 5 cm in size with regional lymphadenopathy (N1–3)
    • Tumours of any size with direct extension to the chest wall or skin, or both (including ulcer or satellite nodules), regardless of regional lymphadenopathy
    • Presence of regional lymphadenopathy (clinically fixed or matted axillary lymph nodes, or any of infraclavicular, supraclavicular, or internal mammary lymphadenopathy) regardless of the tumour stage

Option B: Inflammatory breast cancer

  • Inflammatory breast cancer is considered a subtype of locally advanced breast cancer.

Option C: Chest wall involvement

  • Tumours of any size with direct extension to the chest wall or skin, or both (including ulcer or satellite nodules), regardless of regional lymphadenopathy a criterion to label as locally advanced breast cancer.

Option D: Matted axillary lymph nodes

  • The presence of regional lymphadenopathy (clinically fixed or matted axillary lymph nodes, or any of infraclavicular, supraclavicular, or internal mammary lymphadenopathy) regardless of tumour stage is a criterion to label as locally advanced breast cancer.

questions.text: A 48-year-old male chronic smoker presented with a swelling on the right side of the face for the past one and a half years. The onset was insidious, and the swelling gradually increased in size. The skin over the swelling is normal.  Examination showed a firm right preauricular mass. A mass biopsy showed numerous papillations covered by monomorphic oncotic cells and germinal centers. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option C: Warthin's tumour

  • Warthin's tumour, also called papillary cystadenoma lymphomatosum, is the second most common benign salivary gland tumour (after pleomorphic adenoma). It represents 10-15% of the total salivary gland neoplasms.
  • They are commonly seen between the fifth and seventh decade of life, and it has an apparent male predilection for their occurrence. They are typically found in smokers.
  • They almost exclusively occur in the parotid glands and can be bilateral in 10% of cases.
  • Histologically, it is composed of an oncotic epithelium and a lymphoid stroma.
  • It consists of an encapsulated mass containing numerous irregular cystic spaces lined by bilayered oncotic epithelium growing in the cystic spaces as papillary projections.
  • The underlying stroma separating the oncotic epithelium is typically a large lymphoid matrix with germinal centres.
  • Treatment is superficial parotidectomy, although they can be enucleated without danger of recurrence.

Option A: Pleomorphic adenoma

  • Pleomorphic adenoma is the most common parotid gland neoplasm. It is composed of a chondromyxoid stroma and epithelium. There are no germinal centres, and the tumour is pleomorphic rather than monomorphic, as in this patient.

Option B: Adenoid cystic carcinoma

  • It is the most common tumour of the minor salivary glands. It occurs most commonly in the palate, retromolar area and sinonasal tract.
  • It does not occur in the parotid gland. It commonly involves the facial nerve.

Option D: Mucoepidermoid carcinoma

  • It is the second most common salivary gland tumour. It has mucinous and squamous components. Germinal centres are absent.

questions.text: A 2-month-old female baby comes complaining of swelling on the posterior aspect of the neck. The patient is stable. On examination of the posterior triangle of the neck, a soft, compressible, and painless swelling that trans-illuminates is found. Which of the following clinical conditions may be associated with the presentation of this patient?
questions.solution:
Option A: Turner's syndrome

  • This patient most likely suffers from cystic hygroma associated with Turner's syndrome.
  • Cystic hygroma is a multi-loculated cystic space lined by endothelial cells.
  • It occurs due to the sequestration of a portion of the jugular lymph sac from the lymphatic system.
  • Cysts are filled with clear lymph and are lined by endothelium.
  • Turner's syndrome is associated with cystic hygroma.
  • Most cystic hygromas involve the lymphatic jugular sacs.
  • The most common site is the posterior neck region (Posterior triangle of the neck), as shown in the image below:

Option B: Klinefelter's syndrome

  • Cystic hygroma is not associated with Klinefelter's syndrome.

Option C: Down's syndrome

  • Cystic hygroma is not associated with Down's syndrome. Down's syndrome is associated with congenital cardiac abnormalities such as VSD and ASD.

Option D: All of the above

  • This statement is incorrect as cystic hygroma is not associated with Down's and Klinefelter's syndrome.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male presents to the emergency department with complaints of nausea, vomiting, and headache after a head injury due to accidental trauma caused by a hammer on his head while working. On examination, there are forehead, nasal bridge, and upper lip injuries. However, his eye movements and vision are normal bilaterally. His computed tomography (CT) scan of the facial bones shows Le fort II fracture. What are the most likely structures in this patient that have been damaged?

choices.text: Fracture Line Runs Above and Parallel to the Palate
Fracture Line Runs High Through the Nasal Bridge, Septum, And Ethmoids
Root of Nose, Lacrimal Bone, Orbital Floor, And Pterygoid Plate
Complete Disjunction of The Facial Skeleton from The Skull Base

questions.solution:
Option C: Root of Nose, Lacrimal Bone, Orbital Floor, And Pterygoid Plate

  • Le Fort II fractures transect the nasal bones, medial-anterior orbital walls, orbital floor, inferior orbital rims and finally transversely fracture the posterior maxilla and pterygoid plates.

Option A: Fracture Line Runs Above and Parallel to the Palate

  • Le Fort I level fractures are essentially a separation of the hard palate from the upper maxilla due to a transverse fracture running through the maxilla and pterygoid plates at a level just above the floor of the nose.

Option B: Fracture Line Runs High Through the Nasal Bridge, Septum, And Ethmoids

  • Le Fort III fractures result in craniofacial disjunction. This is the highest level Le Fort fracture and essentially separates the maxilla from the skull base.

Option D: Complete Disjunction of The Facial Skeleton from The Skull Base

  • Le Fort III fractures result in craniofacial disjunction. This is the highest level Le Fort fracture and essentially separates the maxilla from the skull base.

questions.text: A patient with cheek cancer has a tumor of 2.5 cm located close to and involving the lower alveolus. A single mobile ipsilateral lymph node measuring 6 cm is palpable. What is the TNM stage of this tumor?
questions.solution:
Option D: T4N2M0

  • Cheek cancer (2.5 cm) located close to and involving the lower alveolus (T4a); A single mobile ipsilateral lymph node measuring 6 cm is palpable (N2a); TNM stage is T4a N2a M0.
    • T4a (lip)→ Tumor invades through cortical bone, inferior Alveolar nerve, the floor of the mouth, and skin of the chin or nose.
    • T4a(oral cavity)→ Tumor invades the cortical bone, mandible, maxillary sinus, or skin of the face.
    • T4b → Tumor involves through masticator space, pterygoid plate Skull base, and/or encases internal carotid artery.
    • N2a → Metastasis to single ipsilateral LN up to >3-6 cm dimensions
    • N2b → Metastasis to multiple ipsilateral LN none >6 cm in greatest dimension
    • M0 → No Metastasis

Option A: T1N1M0

  • T1 → Tumor up to 2 cm in size; up to 5 mm depth of invasion
  • N1 → Metastasis to single ipsilateral LN up to 3 cm in greatest dimension
  • M0 → No Metastasis

Option B: T2N2M0

  • T2 → Up to 2 cm in size with >5 -10 mm depth of invasion → >2 - 4 cm, depth of invasion up to 10 mm
  • N2a → Metastasis to single ipsilateral LN up to >3 -6 cm dimensions
  • N2b → Metastasis to multiple ipsilateral LN none >6 cm in greatest dimension
  • M0 → No Metastasis

Option C: T2N1M0

  • T2 → Up to 2 cm in size with >5 -10 mm depth of invasion → >2 - 4 cm, depth of invasion up to 10 mm
  • N1 → Metastasis to single ipsilateral LN up to 3 cm in greatest dimension
  • M0 → No Metastasis

questions.text: A 50-year-old male presents with a complaint of pain in the right foot with a severe burning sensation. On examination, veins are dilated and tortuous. There is an ulcer that is causing serous discharge on the medial malleolus too. Doppler scan, revealed incompetent perforators. According to the CEAP classification for chronic venous disorders, how would you classify the patient's disease?
questions.solution:
Option D: C6

  • It is a case of a varicose vein due to dilated and tortuous veins with the presence of an active venous ulcer.
  • CEAP is a classification of chronic venous disease.
  • According to CEAP(Clinical-Etiology-Anatomy-Pathophysiology), C6 is for active venous ulcer, which is in the above-mentioned case.

Option A: C1

  • According to the classification, C1 is just reticular veins.
  • It is the start of venous disorder.

Option B: C3

  • C3 is varicose veins with mild to moderate edema.

Option C: C4a

  • C4a is for pigmentation and eczema.

questions.text: A 20-year-old boy presents to the physician with complaints of diarrhea and generalized swelling for two months. His parents reported that he does not participate in any college activities. A general physical examination is unremarkable. A double-balloon enteroscopy and multi-dot biopsy revealed that he had protein-losing enteropathy caused by intestinal lymphangiectasia. After treatment with total parenteral nutrition, he was relieved of his symptoms. A procedure was performed in this case, shown in the image below. Which of the following is true about the procedure involved in this case?

choices.text: The visualised vein is exposed through a small incision and cannulated with a 16- to 22-G needle
Sodium diatrizoate injected retrogradely under pressure into a small vein on the dorsum of the foot
Used in patients with Lymphangiectasia and Lymphatic fistulas
Lymphatic channels and nodes are then seen with ultrasonography

questions.solution:
Option C: Used in patients with lymphangiectasia and lymphatic fistulas

  • According to the clinical presentation, this is a case of intestinal lymphangiectasia.
  • Lymphangiography:
    • The procedure is performed under fluoroscopy; a blue indicator dye is injected between toes, resulting in thin bluish lines appearing on the top of each foot. These are your lymphatic vessels. Under local anesthesia, the interventional radiologist will cut into 1 of the larger blue lines of each foot and insert a needle or catheter into a vessel. Contrast dye will then be injected into the vessel, making the vessels more visible under imaging.
    • The interventional radiologist will use a fluoroscope, which projects the images on a TV monitor, to observe the dye spreading through your lymphatic system, up your legs, groin, and abdominal cavity. The X-rays will be taken to record any abnormalities and will be further X-rays the following day.
    • It is used in patients of:
      • Lymphangiectasia
      • Lymphatic fistulas
      • Patients being considered for microvascular reconstruction.

Option A: The visualised vein is exposed through a small incision and cannulated with a 16- to 22-G needle

  • The lymphatic segment is exposed through a small incision, cannulated with a 27- to 30-G needle.

Option B: Sodium diatrizoate injected retrogradely under pressure into a small vein on the dorsum of the foot

  • For lymphangiography, an oil-based dye is injected slowly into the lymphatics.
  • A coloured dye is injected into the dorsum of the hand or foot to visualise lymphatics.

Option D: Lymphatic channels and nodes are then seen with ultrasonography

  • In lymphangiography, the lymphatic channels and nodes are then seen with radiographs.
  • It is used in patients with lymphangiectasia and lymphatic fistulas.

questions.text: A 28-year-old female presented to the clinic with painful blue-colored fingers and nails on both hands that became blanched then changed color to blue after a month's trip to mountain areas. She had weak but noticeable upper-limb pulses on examination, and no other significant findings were present. She had no other co-morbidities and was taking no medications. No tobacco history is present. What is the most probable diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: Option A: Raynaud’s disease

  • The patient presents with pain and color changes in her fingers and nails after exposure to cold (Northern areas of Pakistan), indicating Raynaud’s disease.
  • Raynaud’s phenomenon is manifested by the sequential development of digital blanching, cyanosis, and redness of fingers and toes due to cold exposure or emotional stress.
  • Pulses are usually normal but can be weak due to arterial spasms of the region.
  • Blanching is due to a spasm of digital arterioles causing white digits that proceed to 2nd stage of cyanosis. The patient presents with cyanosis due to dilatation of capillaries and venule, which leads to a collection of deoxygenated blood and causes blue skin color.
  • The management is to stop cold exposure, calcium channel blockers (nifedipine, diltiazem), and angiotensin receptors blockers. These medications are used to relieve spasms.

Option B: Raynaud’s syndrome

  • It is associated with other disorders –most commonly SLE (systemic lupus erythematosus).

Option C: Buerger’s disease

  • Patient with Buerger's disease usually presents with a strong history of smoking.

Option D: Acrocyanosis

  • The cyanosis in this disease occurs with no pain, but paresthesia is present.

questions.text: A 24-year-old female arrives at the medical emergency department complaining of sudden onset chest pain and a nonproductive cough that has lasted 6 hours. The presence of frequent headaches is the only significant medical history. On admission, the patient has no dyspnea, and physical examination demonstrates a slight decrease in breath sounds over the left hemithorax. Heart sounds are normal, and there is no cyanosis, clubbing, or edema. A chest radiograph demonstrates the presence of a left-sided pneumothorax. Which of the following percentages of pneumothorax needs operative treatment in this patient?
questions.solution:
Option B: 20%

  • On chest radiography, if symptomatic, pneumothorax of approximately 25% or larger generally requires needle aspiration, and tube thoracostomy is to be done if it fails.
  • Pleurodesis is done in patients undergoing video-assisted thoracic surgery (VATS) to occlude pleural space.
  • Lung collapse occurs when the air pushes on the outside of the lung or air leaks into the dehiscence between the chest wall and lung, this causes pneumothorax. A pneumothorax can collapse a complete lung, or only a portion of the lung collapses.
  • Major causes of pneumothorax include chest injury that is blunt or penetrating, some specific medical procedures, and underlying lung disease that can also cause damage.
  • Major symptoms generally include sudden pain in the chest and shortness of breath. It can be a life-threatening event in some cases. And there might be no obvious reason for it.
  • To treat a pneumothorax, a needle or chest tube is inserted between the ribs to remove the excess air. However, usually, a small pneumothorax can heal on its own.

Option A: 10%

  • Over time a small pneumothorax may go away on its own. The physician may use a needle to escape air around the lung so it can fully expand. The patient only needs some oxygen treatment and rest.
  • Symptoms often resolve within 24 hours, usually even without treatment. In patients with a small pneumothorax, the physical examination may be normal.

Option C:  30%

  • In large (25% or apex to cupula distance > 3 cm) pneumothorax, there are persistent symptoms in the inpatient.
  • Treatment includes chest tube placement.
  • The most definitive initial treatment of a large pneumothorax is the chest tube (or intercostal drain). An area under the axilla, called the "safe triangle", is ideal for inserting a chest tube as the damage to internal organs can be avoided.

Option D: 40%

  • In large pneumothorax (40%), and mostly in cases of tension pneumothorax, chest tubes are the only option to treat as they cannot respond to needle aspiration.
  • In this method, a one-way-valve system allows the air to only escape and not re-enter the chest.

questions.text: A 40-year-old obese female comes to the clinic with the complaint of generalized pain and swelling in both legs for two months. Her job requires her to stand for long periods of time, which worsens her pain and is usually relieved by walking and raising her legs. She has a known case of varicose veins. Her Vitals show that her blood pressure is 130/90, her heart rate is 72 beats per minute, and her temperature is 37.7 degree Celsius. On examination, visibly distended veins, along with yellow-brown skin pigmentation, eczema, and painful, indurated, and hardened skin, are seen on both of her lower legs. Additionally, lipodermatosclerosis is found. According to the CEAP classification system, these examination findings can be categorized as?
questions.solution:
Option D: C4

  • This is the case of chronic venous insufficiency.
  • The CEAP classification can classify CVI based on clinical features. According to this classification, hyperpigmentation, eczema, and lipodermatosclerosis are seen in the CEAP C4 class.
  • Hyperpigmentation is a sign of chronic venous stasis, particularly if it is found along the medial aspect of the lower leg or ankle.

      Option A: C1

  • The C1 category of the CEAP classification shows telangiectasias (diameter of the vein is less than 1mm) and/or reticular veins (diameter between 1 to 3mm).
  •  Telangiectasias, commonly called spider veins, are small, dilated blood vessels within the dermis, while reticular veins are found subdermally.

Option B: C2

  • The C2 class of CEAP shows recurrent varicose veins in the lower extremities without eczema or lipodermatosclerosis.
  • Varicose veins are dilated, often tortuous, visible veins in the subcutaneous tissue with a diameter of >3mm.

Option C: C3

  • Edema is seen as the predominant clinical feature in CEAP class C3.
  • It usually presents as swelling and pitting edema in the lower extremities.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most preferred treatment option for Gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) that is irresponsive to medical treatment?
questions.solution:
Option C: Laparoscopic Nissen’s fundoplication

  • Gold standard treatment of GERD: Laparoscopic Nissen’s fundoplication 
  • Laparoscopic Nissen's fundoplication is a minimally invasive procedure to restore the function of the lower esophageal sphincter (the valve between the esophagus and the stomach) by wrapping the stomach around the esophagus.

Option A: Lifestyle modification

  • Lifestyle modification helps reduce the symptoms of GERD. Following are some of the recommended modifications.
    • Avoid lying down for at least two hours after a meal or after drinking acidic beverages, like soda or other caffeinated beverages.
    • Eat smaller and more frequent meals daily instead of a few large meals.
    • Cessation of smoking
    • Decrease caffeine intake

 

Option B: Double dose of PPI

  • Medical management: Double dose of PPI is the initial approach
  • Proton-pump inhibitors are a class of medications that cause a profound and prolonged reduction of stomach acid production
  • They irreversibly inhibit the stomach's H⁺/K⁺ ATPase proton pump. They are the most potent inhibitors of acid secretion available.
  • PPIs are generally believed to have few adverse effects and are generally well tolerated. Patients have experienced minor side effects of short-term PPI use, such as headache, rash, dizziness, and gastrointestinal symptoms, including nausea, abdominal pain, flatulence, constipation, and diarrhea.

 

Option D: Dietary modification

  • Dietary modification helps reduce the symptoms of GERD. 
  • Recommendations for the dietary management of GERD include:
    • Limit high-fat foods, e.g. fried foods, high-fat baked goods, cream, ice cream, high-fat cheeses, sausages, bacon, potato chips, etc.
    • Ensure adequate protein intake.
    • Limit chocolate and coffee.
    • Foods to eat:
      • Vegetables, Ginger, Oatmeal, Non-citrus fruits.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female with chronic NSAID abuse presents with massive hematemesis, hypotension, and tachycardia. Physical examination shows abdominal tenderness. IV proton pump inhibitors are administered, and endoscopy reveals a bleeding peptic ulcer in the proximal duodenum. Which of the following vessels needs to be ligated in this patient to stop the bleeding?
questions.solution:
Option A: Gastroduodenal artery

  • Peptic ulcers are open sores in the stomach (gastric ulcer) and the upper part of the duodenum (duodenal ulcer).
  • It usually presents with hematemesis and melena.
  • A peptic ulcer is the most common cause of upper GI bleeding, present in one-half to two-thirds of patients with upper GI bleeding.
  • It has the following two types:

 

 

Gastric ulcer

Duodenal ulcers

Abdominal pain

Pain increases with the meal.

Pain decreases with the meal.

H. Pylori infection

Chronic infection

Acute infection

Mechanism

Decreased mucosal protection against gastric ulcer

Decreased mucosal protection or increased gastric secretion

Causes

NSAIDS

Zollinger-Ellison syndrome

Risk of carcinoma

Increase risk

Benign

 

  • Ulcers (duodenal ulcers) is the most common cause of upper GI bleeding
  • Duodenal ulcer bleeds from the gastroduodenal artery.
  • Gastric ulcers mostly bleed from the left gastric artery.

 

 

Option B: Superior pancreaticoduodenal artery

  • It arises from the gastroduodenal artery.
  • It divides into anterior and posterior branches.
  • Both branches combine with the inferior pancreaticoduodenal artery branches to form the superior mesenteric artery.
  • It mostly supplies the pancreas and duodenum.

Option C: Left gastric artery

  • The left gastric artery is a branch of the celiac artery.
  • The lesser curve is supplied by the right and left gastric vessels, and the greater curve is by the right and left gastroepiploic vessels.
  • Gastric ulcers mostly bleed from the left gastric artery.

Option D: Left gastroepiploic artery

  • The left gastroepiploic artery arises from the splenic artery and runs within the gastrosplenic ligament.
  • The greater curve is supplied by the right and left gastroepiploic vessels.

questions.text: Mucinous cystic tumor of which of the following organs is most likely to be associated with pseudomyxoma peritonei?
questions.solution:
Option C: Ovary

  • Pseudomyxoma peritonei (PMP) is characterized by large quantities of encysted yellow-jelly material filling the abdomen and peritoneal cavity.
    • It is associated with mucinous cystic tumours of the ovary and appendix.
    • It is more common in females.
    • It may also arise from a primary appendiceal tumour with secondary implantation to one or both ovaries.
  • As mucinous cystic tumours of the appendix or ovary rupture, it leads to seeding of the peritoneum with mucus-producing cells, which continue to proliferate and produce mucus.
    • The progressive accumulation of copious amounts of mucinous fluid gradually fills the peritoneal cavity, resulting in the characteristic "jelly belly".

Option A: Pancreas

  • Mucinous cystic tumours of the pancreas are not associated with developing pseudomyxoma peritonei.

Option B: Kidney

  • Mucinous cystadenocarcinoma is a very rare epithelial tumour originating from the urothelium of the renal pelvis. It does not contribute to the risk factor for developing pseudomyxoma peritonei.

Option D: Abdominal Testis

  • Mucinous cystic tumours of the abdominal testis are extremely rare and are not associated with the pathophysiology of pseudomyxoma peritonei development.

questions.text:
A 1-year-old male baby is brought by his parents with a complaint of abdominal distention. The parents also complain of blood in the stool. A barium enema X-ray is ordered after the physical examination, which shows the following findings:



Which of the following findings are indicated in the Abdominal X-ray?
questions.solution:
Option C: Coiled spring sign

  • The above-shown picture depicts a coiled spring sign, and the most likely cause is intussusception.
  • Children with classic findings of intussusception need to be investigated with an enema, which is both diagnostic (the gold standard in the diagnosis of intussusception) and therapeutic.
  • On Barium enema:
    • Claw sign
    • Coiled spring sign

Option A: Meniscus sign

  • A highly specific radiographic roentgen finding for intussusception is called the meniscus sign (or crescent sign).
  • This is crescent shaped-gas in the bowel lumen (intussuscipiens) that surrounds the apex of the intussusceptum (invaginated segment), creating a well-demarcated soft tissue/gas interface

 

Option B: Pseudo kidney sign

  • The pseudo kidney sign is a characteristic ultrasound appearance in some cases of intestinal intussusception.
  • It refers to the longitudinal ultrasound appearance of the intussuscepted bowel segment, mimicking a kidney.

Option D: Target sign

  • A target sign is classically defined as a CT image associated with the thickening of the intestinal wall. A lower attenuated middle layer is surrounded on each side by layers of higher attenuation.
  • The diagnosis of a small bowel target sign most commonly correlates with intussusception.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man with Parkinson's is admitted with abdominal pain, irregular bowel movements, and weight loss, all associated with occasional flushing episodes for the past ten months. Physical examination revealed spider-like facial veins, and hepatomegaly. Urinary 5-HIAA level is 320 mg/24 h (range1200 ng/ml (range<98 ng/ml). A barium enema revealed a filling defect in the ileocecal valve. Which of the following is correct regarding this syndrome?

choices.text: Omeprazole injection reduces symptoms of flushing and diarrhea
It occurs when the tumours metastasize to the adrenal gland
Pale-looking skin is a typical feature

questions.solution:
Option A: Occurs in <10% of carcinoid tumours

  • The given condition with elevated 5-HIAA and chromogranin A indicates carcinoid syndrome.
  • Carcinoid syndrome occurs in <10% of patients with carcinoid tumours.
  • Intestinal carcinoid tumours / neuroendocrine tumours (NET) arise from enterochromaffin cells located at the base of the crypts of Lieberkuhn.
  • They occur most commonly in the appendix, ileum, and rectum.
  • They produce a number of vasoactive peptides, most commonly serotonin, but also histamine, prostaglandin, and kallikrein.
  • When they metastasize to the liver, carcinoid syndrome becomes evident.

Option B: Omeprazole injection reduces symptoms of flushing and diarrhea

  • Omeprazole is a proton pump inhibitor and has no role in reducing the symptoms of flushing and diarrhea.
  • These symptoms can be reduced by octreotide injection in carcinoid syndrome.
  • Octreotide is a somatostatin analog. It reduces GI motility, inhibits gastric acid secretion, and decreases IG mucosal blood flow.

 

Option C: It occurs when carcinoid tumours metastasize to the adrenal gland

  • When carcinoid tumours metastasize to the liver, carcinoid syndrome becomes evident.
  • In patients with no liver metastases, serotonin released by carcinoid tumours will become inactive in the liver.
  • In a patient with liver metastases, serotonin bypasses the first-pass metabolism in the liver and directly enters the bloodstream, causing symptoms.

 

Option D: Pale-looking skin is a typical feature

  • The most common presenting symptom of carcinoid syndrome is skin flushing.
  • The skin colour of the face and upper chest changes from red to purple, and it feels hot.
  • Bright-red patchy flushing is typically seen in Gastric carcinoids.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male presents with bloody diarrhea for two days. The patient is otherwise healthy but reports experiencing diarrhea for three months,  apparently started after consuming street food and did not resolve. There are no abnormalities on physical examination. A colonoscopy with biopsy is performed, and a specimen from the caecum is shown in the image. What is the underlying cause?
questions.solution:
Option B: Entamoeba histolytica

  • The colonoscopy of the patient revealed multiple flask-shaped ulcers in the caecum, which is suggestive of amoebiasis.
  • Amoebiasis is caused by entamoeba histolytica.
  • The organism enters the gut through food and water contaminated with the cyst.
  • The cysts hatch in the small bowel, and a large number of trophozoites are released.
  • Trophozoites of E. histolytica attach to the submucosa of the cecum and ascending colon to produce flask-shaped ulcers and causes an abscess.

Option A: Giardia lamblia

  • Giardia lamblia is a protozoan that causes giardiasis.
  • It is transmitted via the fecal-oral route, e.g. by drinking contaminated food or water.
  • The clinical features of giardiasis include abdominal cramps, excessive gas, and foul-smelling stools.

Option C: H. Pylori

  • H. pylori is a gram-negative bacterium that usually causes diseases of the stomach and the intestine.
  • It can cause:
    • Peptic ulcer
    • Type B gastritis

Option D: Enterobius vermicularis

  • Enterobius vermicularis is a pinworm.
  • It is transmitted via the fecal-oral route.
  • It usually causes anal or perianal pruritis.
  • It can also cause vulvovaginitis in children.

questions.text: A 35-year-old army personnel suddenly falls down while patrolling in the Thar desert of Rajasthan. He is immediately taken to a military hospital and is assessed by a medical officer. On examination, he is unconscious and unresponsive with no palpable pulse. ECG is done, and a diagnosis of PEA (Pulseless Electrical Activity) is made. Which of the following condition is less likely to be the cause of this condition?
questions.solution:
Option B: Hydrogen ion depletion

  • Pulseless Electrical Activity(PEA): PEA means electrical activity is seen on ECG, but the pulse is absent.
  • Hydrogen ion depletion implies alkalosis, whereas PEA occurs with acidosis.
  • The leading cause of PEA is hypoxia secondary to respiratory failure (40-50% cases) and hypovolemia.

Causes of Pulseless Electrical Activity(PEA):

  • The 6 H’s and 6 T’s of pulseless electrical activity are as follows:

6 H’s

  1. Hypovolemia
  2. Hypoxia
  3. Hydrogen ion (acidosis)
  4. Hypo / Hyperkalemia
  5. Hypothermia
  6. Hypoglycaemia

6 T’s

  1. Toxins
  2. Tamponade
  3. Tension Pneumothorax
  4. Thrombosis (MI)
  5. Thrombosis (lungs: massive pulmonary embolism)
  6. Trauma (i.e. myocardial contusion)

Option A: Low pO2 < 60mm Hg

  • Oxygen level <60mm Hg is consistent with hypoxia, which is associated with the development of the pulseless electrical activity.

Option C: Hypokalemia

  • Hypokalemia or hyperkalemia both can lead to pulseless electrical activity.

Option D: Hypovolemia

  • Hypovolemia is the leading cause of pulseless electrical activity.

​​​​​​​

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents to the office with complaints of pain and swelling in her right big toe for 2 weeks. The symptoms are worse at the end of the day. Apart from this, she also reports mild headaches and constipation for two months. Her medical history is notable for type 2 diabetes mellitus. On examination, swelling and tenderness were noted on 1st metatarsophalangeal (MTP) joint. The rest of her relevant review is unremarkable. Which of the following is the most likely cause of her condition?
questions.solution:
Option B: Lead 

  • Hyperuricemia and secondary (saturnine) gout are common findings associated with chronic lead toxicity and are thought to be due to proximal tubular defects resulting in increased tubular reabsorption and decreased secretion of uric acid.
  • Saturnine gout caused by lead poisoning is consistent with gout. The pain and swelling of 1st metatarsophalangeal joint mentioned in the scenario are constant with gout secondary to lead poisoning. 
  • The symptoms like headache and constipation in this patient are also due to lead toxicity. 
  • Lead Toxicity: Lead is a heavy metal and a fundamental earth substance. 
    • Causes: 
      • Paint (older homes, old toys, furniture, crafts) 
      • Occupational exposure 
      • Soil.
      • Drinking water.
      • Folk medicines, ayurvedic, and cosmetics.
      • Children's jewelry and toys etc 

Lead poisoning can have adverse effects on various organs. Signs and symptoms of lead poisoning are as follows: 

Option A: Arsenic 

  • Symptoms of acute arsenic poisoning are headache, confusion, diarrhoea, and drowsiness. Chronic arsenic toxicity can lead to vitamin A deficiency and night blindness.
  • Gout is not associated with arsenic poisoning. 

Option C: Mercury

  • Signs and symptoms of mercury toxicity includes loss of peripheral vision, paraesthesia, lack of coordination of movements, impairment of speech, hearing, ataxia, and muscle weakness.
  • Mercury poisoning does not cause gout. 

Option D: Antimony

  • Antimony is a silvery-white metal that is found in the earth's crust. Its poisoning does not cause secondary gout. 
  • Signs and symptoms of antimony poisoning include gastrointestinal disturbance, bitter taste in the mouth and a characteristic leucocyte count shift on complete blood count(CBC).

questions.text: A 14-year-old girl presented to the urgent care clinic with a complaint of an ulcer on the right toe. She does not remember when that ulcer developed. Examination shows a 3-4mm deep non-tender ulcer with punched-out margins. Her family history is unknown. She lives in an orphanage home and has little access to primary medical care services. Laboratory evaluation shows a serum HbA1c level of 8.7%. Which of the following statements is true regarding this haemoglobin?

choices.text: It is a prospective test indicating glycemic control for 8-12 weeks.
It is a poor indicator of long-term diabetic status in patients with renal disease
It contains haemoglobin with a sugar moiety

questions.solution:
Option C: It contains haemoglobin with a sugar moiety.

  • HbA1c is glycosylated haemoglobin. It can be used to diagnose diabetes. If serum HbA1c levels are >6.5%, it indicates the diagnosis of diabetes mellitus. If serum HbA1c levels are between 5.7-6.4%, it shows impaired glucose tolerance.
  • HbA1c circulates within red blood cells whose life span lasts up to 120 days; it generally reflects the state of glycemia over the preceding 8–12 weeks, thereby providing an improved method of assessing diabetic control retrospectively.
  • It is an excellent test indicating glycemic control in people with diabetes, especially those with renal disease.
  • It is a retrospective test indicating glycemic control for the last 8-12 weeks.
  • The accuracy of HbA1c values can be affected by haemoglobin variants or traits.
  • Falsely low levels of HbA1c are seen when:
    • High levels of haemoglobin F are present.
    • Decreased erythrocyte survival or lowered mean erythrocyte age (e.g., recovery from acute blood loss, hemolytic anaemia)
    • Intravenous iron and erythropoietin therapy
    • Vitamins C and E are reported to falsely lower test results, possibly by inhibiting haemoglobin glycation.
  • Falsely high levels of HbA1c are present in:
    • Conditions that increase erythrocyte survival (splenectomy for hereditary spherocytosis).
    • Iron deficiency anaemia is also associated with higher HbA1c levels.
  • HbA1c should be monitored every 3 months in diabetic patients. The goal is to maintain HbA1c levels of around 7%, which is often difficult to achieve. A low HbA1c value in serum is associated with a decreased risk of microvascular complications of diabetes. Microvascular complications of diabetes mellitus include diabetic retinopathy, nephropathy and neuropathy.

Option A: It is a prospective test indicating glycaemic control for 8-12 weeks.

  • HbA1c is a retrospective (not prospective) test which indicates glycaemic control for the last 8-12 weeks.

Option B: It is a poor indicator of long-term diabetic status in patients with renal disease

  • HbA1c is a good indicator of long-term diabetic status in patients with renal disease.

Option D: Half-life is 45 days in adults

  • It is glycosylated haemoglobin with a half-life of 120 days.

questions.text: A 55-year-old female presents to an urgent care clinic with complaints of tingling sensation in her hands and feet and pain in her legs, usually at night. She has had type-2 diabetes mellitus for 15 years. On examination, loss of ankle deep tendon reflex, loss of position sensation of great toe, and decreased pinprick sensation over ankles and wrists are observed bilaterally. Her recent HbA1c was 8.9%. She is currently taking insulin and metformin. She is diagnosed with diabetic polyneuropathy. Which of the following medications can be used to treat the pain associated with diabetic neuropathy?
questions.solution:
Option A: Duloxetine

  • Diabetic neuropathy
    • It is a microvascular complication of diabetes mellitus.
    • Peripheral neuropathy is a stocking and glove pattern of numbness and paresthesias.
    • Loss of sensation leads to ulcer formation with ischemia and Charcot's joints.
    • Cranial nerve complications can also occur, e.g. diabetic third nerve palsy.
    • Mononeuropathies such as median nerve and ulnar nerve neuropathies are also common.
    • Diabetic truncal neuropathy causes pain in the distribution of any intercostal nerve.
    • Diabetic foot is a combination of artery disease (ischemia) and neuropathy leading to infected ulcer formation, which may require amputation.
  • One common form of diabetic neuropathy is distal symmetric polyneuropathy which presents as distal pain and loss of sensations bilaterally. It can be treated by:
    • Improving glycemic control.
    • Alcohol and smoking should be avoided.
    • A proper diet with adequate vitamins should be ensured, as vitamin deficiencies in the elderly are common and can lead to neuropathy.
    • Duloxetine is a serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor. It treats depression, generalized anxiety disorder, and diabetic neuropathy. Duloxetine is also indicated for fibromyalgia.
    • Pregabalin is an anticonvulsant used to treat epilepsy, neuropathic pain, fibromyalgia, and restless leg syndrome.
    • Other agents that can also be used are:
      • Amitriptyline is a tricyclic acid antidepressant that inhibits serotonin and norepinephrine reuptake.
      • Gabapentin is an anti-epileptic drug used for partial seizures. It inhibits calcium channels in neurons and acts as a gamma-aminobutyric acid (GABA) analog. It can also be used for post-herpetic neuralgia and peripheral neuropathy.
      • Valproate causes sodium channel inactivation and increases the concentration of GABA by inhibiting GABA transaminase. It is used to treat generalized or partial seizures. It can be used in trigeminal neuralgia.
      • Opioids can also be used to treat the pain associated with polyneuropathy.

Option B: Topiramate

  • Topiramate is used as an anti-epileptic drug and for migraine prophylaxis.
  • It enhances the action of gamma-aminobutyric acid (GABA) and blocks sodium channels in neurons.

Option C: Piroxicam

  • Piroxicam is a nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug used as an analgesic, antipyretic, and anti-inflammatory drug.
  • It is not used in managing diabetic neuropathy.

Option D: Naproxen

  • Naproxen is a nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug that reversibly inhibits cyclooxygenase 1 and 2, inhibiting prostaglandin synthesis.
  • It is an analgesic and antipyretic but not used to treat diabetic neuropathy.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presents to the emergency department with occasional severe headaches, nausea, and vomiting. On his examination, blood pressure while sitting is 230/130 mmHg with a heart rate of 90 beats/min, but on standing, the blood pressure drops to 200/100 mmHg and the heart rate increases to 140 beats/min. A cardiovascular examination depicted tachycardia with normal S1 and S2 sounds. The patient's lungs are clear. The optic discs are blurred, but there are no exudates or haemorrhages. What is the most appropriate treatment for this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
Option C: Phentolamine

  • All features of the patient point towards the condition known as Pheochromocytoma.
  • Pheochromocytoma is a benign tumor of the neuroendocrine cells of the adrenal gland that produce excess amounts of catecholamines.
  • These catecholamines are released in an intermittent fashion, and such a surge causes an intermittent increase in heart rate, blood pressure and temperature.
  • The first line of management to give to a patient suffering from pheochromocytoma is a selective alpha-blocker.
  • Phentolamine is an alpha blocker, which works efficiently to decrease the symptoms of the disorder.
  • After alpha-blockers, beta-blockers are also given to decrease the symptoms further.
  • In the early phase of the disease, the BP will be elevated for a few min-hours, i.e., Episodic Hypertension.
  • In the late phase, the BP will show Postural hypotension (If Systolic blood pressure gets reduced by >20mmHg & Diastolic blood pressure gets reduced by >10mmHg on a change of posture)

Option A: Labetalol

  • Labetalol is a beta-blocker that is also used to treat hypertension.
  • But, in the case of a pheochromocytoma, alpha-blockers are given before beta-blockers, as selective alpha-blocking causes the surge of symptoms due to uninhibited alpha agonist activity.

Option B: Nitroprusside

  • Nitroprusside is a drug that causes smooth muscle relaxation.
  • It is used to decrease blood pressure.
  • It can be used in hypertensive encephalopathy and hypertensive emergency, but it is not used to treat pheochromocytoma

Option D: Hydralazine

  • Hydralazine is an anti-hypertensive medication used to treat hypertensive emergencies and can also be given in pregnancy to treat pre-eclampsia. It is not used to treat pheochromocytoma.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man comes to the clinic complaining of abdominal striae, weight gain and a hump in the posterior neck for the past 2 months. His B.P is 160/100 mmHg. Mark the incorrect statements regarding the condition shown below -
questions.solution:
Option C: Hyperkalemia

  • Presentation of Buffalo hump & Violet striae: Seen in CUSHING'S syndrome
  • In Cushing's syndrome, there is an increase in cortisol(three times) which have mineralocorticoid activity and activates the Epithelial Na+channels, leading to more salt and water coming in, but more K+ and H+ loss leads to Hypokalemic Alkalosis (Metabolic Alkalosis) but NO HYPERKALEMIA
  • Single midnight serum cortisol measurement helps in the diagnosis of the Cushings syndrome
  • Since cortisol is released in stressful situations in the body, so the midnight before sleep time, the body is at its lowest stress, and if the cortisol is increased in this situation, it means the patient is suffering from hypersecretion of cortisol irrespective of pressure and indicates Cushing's syndrome 

Option A: Hyperpigmentation

  • Hyperpigmentation in Cushing's syndrome is due to insulin resistance because of hypercortisolism

Option B: Purplish striae

  • Purplish striae are due to increased central obesity and skin thinning, and fragility

Option D: Metabolic alkalosis

  • Metabolic alkalosis is due to mineralocorticoid activity of the cortisol, which causes hypokalemic alkalosis

questions.text: A 40-year-old female presents to the outpatient department with complaints of excessive fatigue, constipation, and alopecia. She also gives a history of weight gain of around 5 kg in the last 3 months despite regular diet and physical activity. Her thyroid profile show TSH- 20 mU/L & free T4 is low. Which of the following is the next step in the diagnosis of aetiology?
questions.solution:
Option A: Antithyroid peroxidase antibody
 

Hashimoto's thyroiditis:

  • Characterized clinically by gradual thyroid failure, with or without goitre formation, primarily due to autoimmune-mediated destruction of the thyroid gland involving apoptosis of thyroid epithelial cells. (See 'Introduction' above.)
  • Clinical phenotypes:
    The two significant phenotypes of chronic autoimmune hypothyroidism are goitrous autoimmune thyroiditis and atrophic autoimmune thyroiditis, with the common pathologic feature being lymphocytic infiltration and follicular destruction and the common serologic feature being the presence of high serum concentrations of antibodies to thyroid peroxidase (TPO) and thyroglobulin (Tg).
  • Both cellular and humoral factors may contribute to thyroid injury and hypothyroidism in chronic autoimmune thyroiditis.
  • Cytotoxic T cells may directly destroy thyroid cells.
  • In addition, more than 90 per cent of patients with chronic autoimmune thyroiditis have high serum concentrations of autoantibodies to thyroglobulin, thyroid peroxidase (thyroid microsomal antigen), or the thyroid sodium-iodide transporter.
  • These antibodies have little, if any, functional activity. Many patients also have antibodies that block the action of TSH on the TSH receptor or are cytotoxic to thyroid cells.
  • Serum antithyroid antibodies need not be measured routinely in patients with overt primary hypothyroidism because almost all have chronic autoimmune thyroiditis.
  • However, a test for antithyroid peroxidase antibodies may be useful to predict the likelihood of progression to permanent overt hypothyroidism in patients with subclinical hypothyroidism or those with painless (silent) thyroiditis or postpartum thyroiditis.

Option B: Anti-endomysial antibody

  • The anti-endomysial antibody is found in Celiac disease.

Option C: Radioiodine uptake scan

  • It is performed to look for the functionality of the thyroid gland in the cause of hyperthyroidism.

Option D: Thyroid ultrasound

  • In case of thyroid nodule or swelling, ultrasound and TSH are recommended.
  • Thyroid USG tells whether the swelling is cystic or solid.

questions.text: After 8 days of birth, a woman comes to the clinic complaining of no milk flow started yet, fatigue, craving for salt and sugars. Her vitals are deranged with low blood pressure and pulse. She is diagnosed with Sheehan syndrome. Which is the first drug to be started in Sheehan's syndrome?
questions.solution:
Option D: Corticosteroids

  • Treatment of young women with hypopituitarism due to Sheehan syndrome usually includes Hydrocortisone first and then thyroid hormone and Estrogen replacement with or without Progesterone.
  • Hydrocortisone is replaced first because thyroxine therapy can exacerbate glucocorticoid deficiency and theoretically induce an adrenal crisis.
  • The standard dose of Hydrocortisone is 20 mg/d for an adult (15 mg every morning and 5 mg every evening).
  • Replacement of growth hormone is necessary for children with hypopituitarism but is controversial in adults.

other options

Option A: Gonadotropins

  • Gonadotropins are not replaced in Sheehan syndrome, but estrogen that is released due to pituitary hormones LH and FSH(gonadotropins) is replaced

Option B: Estrogen

  • Estrogen is replaced, but in the very end, after Hydrocortisone and thyroxine

Option C: Thyroxine

  • Thyroxine is replaced, but it comes second on the priority list after Hydrocortisone

questions.text: A 54-year-old male is being evaluated after the management of a femoral fracture due to a recent fall. The patient fell after losing his balance while walking on the street a few days ago and had a fracture of the femoral neck. His temperature is 98°F, his blood pressure is 126/80 mmHg, and his pulse is 90 beats per minute. He follows a healthy diet plan. His past medical history is significant for chronic kidney disease, and he is on dialysis. On laboratory evaluation, he is found to have high serum PTH, low serum Ca2+ and high serum PO4+. What is the most likely cause of his laboratory derangement?
questions.solution:
Option C: Reduced Kidney Function

  • This patient has a history of chronic kidney disease and is on dialysis.
  • His laboratory evaluation shows low serum calcium and high serum phosphate levels. He has had a fragility fracture of the femoral neck. This is due to decreased calcium levels.
  • His PTH is high due to hyperparathyroidism secondary to the high phosphorus and low calcium stimulating the parathyroid gland.
  • In secondary hyperparathyroidism, PTH levels are elevated in response to chronic hypocalcaemia. While any disorder that results in hypocalcaemia can lead to secondary hyperparathyroidism, chronic renal failure and vitamin D deficiency are the most common causes. Stimulation of the parathyroid glands by chronic hypocalcaemia results in hyperplasia of all glands.
  • Secondary hyperparathyroidism can also result from malabsorption (chronic pancreatitis, small bowel disease, malabsorption-dependent bariatric surgery).
  • In this patient, chronic kidney disease has caused the derangement of the calcium and phosphate levels, thus causing the release of PTH from the parathyroid gland.

Option A: Dietary Vitamin D Deficiency

  • Dietary vitamin D deficiency can also cause hyperparathyroidism secondary to decreased calcium levels in the body. But this patient follows a healthy lifestyle and diet. Therefore, his chronic kidney disease is the main cause of these laboratory abnormalities.

Option B: GI Malabsorption

  • GI malabsorption can result in Vitamin D deficiency, which causes decreased calcium absorption from the gut and decreased calcium reabsorption from the kidneys. It may occur due to pancreatitis or small-bowel disease. This patient’s history does not indicate malabsorption syndromes.

Option D: Pituitary Adenoma

  • 85% of the cases of primary hyperparathyroidism are due to solitary parathyroid adenomas. Parathyroid hyperplasia, multiple adenomas, and rare carcinoma cause the other 15% of cases. It causes excess PTH despite normal or increased Calcium levels in the body.

questions.text: A patient presented in OPD with symptoms of anaemia, acute abdominal bleeding, tarry stool and vomiting with blood in it. Endoscopy shows strips of watermelon on stomach walls. Which of the following conditions leads to the following endoscopic appearance?
questions.solution:
Option B: Gastric antral vascular ectasia

  • Gastric antral vascular ectasia (GAVE) syndrome, also known as watermelon stomach, is a significant cause of acute or chronic gastrointestinal blood loss in the elderly. It is characterized endoscopically by "watermelon stripes.”
  • Although it is associated with heterogeneous medical conditions, including hepatic, renal, and cardiac diseases, its pathogenesis is unknown.
  • The diagnosis of GAVE syndrome in patients with renal or hepatic disease is often problematic because there are more frequent causes of gastrointestinal bleeding in these diseases (vascular malformations, peptic ulcer disease, oesophagal or gastric varices, and colonic and rectal ulcers) that overshadow GAVE syndrome.
  • Gastric antral vascular ectasia:
    • Vascular information→Watermelon stomach

 

Option A: Intestinal lymphangiectasia

  • Biopsy: vacuolated cells because the fat will not be absorbed
  • Primary intestinal lymphangiectasia (PIL) is a rare disorder characterized by dilated intestinal lacteals resulting in lymph leakage into the small bowel lumen and responsible for protein-losing enteropathy leading to lymphopenia, hypoalbuminemia and hypogammaglobulinemia.
  • This disorder results from improperly formed intestinal lymph vessels or blockage of lymph flow from the intestines.
  • Diarrhoea and swelling of the legs are the main symptoms. The diagnosis is based on the results of a biopsy.

 

Option C: Amoebic colitis

  • Biopsy -Flask- shaped ulcer(Bleeding)
  • Amebic colitis is gradual in onset, with symptoms presenting over 1-2 weeks; this pattern distinguishes this condition from bacterial dysentery.
  • Diarrhoea is the most common symptom.
  • Patients with amebic colitis typically present cramping abdominal pain, watery or bloody diarrhoea, and weight loss or anorexia.
  • Amebic colitis results from invasive infection of the colonic mucosa by Entamoeba histolytica (E. histolytica).

 

Option D: Necrotising Enterocolitis

  • Diagnosed by Radiological findings (Pneumatosis intestinalis)
  • Necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC) is a severe illness in which tissues in the intestine (gut) become inflamed and start to die.
  • This can lead to a perforation (hole) developing, which allows the contents of the intestine to leak into the abdomen (tummy).

questions.text: 33 years male presented to the clinic with the complaint of recurrent episodes of abdominal pain. On examination, there is mucocutaneous hyperpigmentation over the lips. Histopathological examination showed arborisation and pseudo invasion. Genetic analysis revealed that the gene responsible for the condition is LKB1/STK11. Colonoscopy revealed multiple polyps. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option C: Peutz – Jeghers syndrome

  • It is an autosomal dominant disease
  • The most com­mon location in the small intestine is the jejunum. Although, it may occur in the stomach or colon & with much lower frequency in the bladder and lungs
  • There is germline loss of function mutations in the LKB1/STK11 gene.
  • There are multiple gastrointestinal hamartomatous polyps along with mucocutaneous hyperpigmentation.
  • Grossly the polyps are large and pedunculated with lobulated contour
  • On histopathology, they are characterised by the proliferation of the muscularis mucosae to form branching configurations covered by hypertrophic but normal mucosa

 

Option A: Familial adenomatous polyposis

  • FAP, also known as familial polyposis coli (FPC), is an autosomal dominant polyposis condition with different degrees of penetrance.
  • If left untreated, patients will grow hundreds to thousands of polyps throughout the colon and rectum.
  • Polyps commonly appear in the early adolescent years and, if left untreated, result in a nearly 100% lifetime risk of colorectal cancer by the age of forty.
  • Colectomy is required to significantly reduce the chance of developing colorectal cancer.
  • FAP is linked to various cancers, including gastric and duodenal cancers, hepatoblastomas, and desmoid tumours.

Option B: Hereditary non-polyposis colorectal cancer

  • Lynch syndrome, commonly known as hereditary non-polyposis colorectal cancer (HNPCC), is an autosomal dominant trait and the most common cause of inherited colorectal cancer (CRC).
  • It is distinguished by a substantial family history of HNPCC-associated malignancies involving first-degree relatives spanning at least two generations and at least one case identified before age 50.

Option D: Neurofibromatosis

  • Neurofibromatosis is a neurocutaneous condition characterised by nerve system and skin malignancies.
  • Types 1 and 2 neurofibromatoses are the Von Recklinghausen's disease, is an autosomal dominant condition.
  • Type 1 neurofibromatosis is characterised by neurofibromas, cafe-au-lait macules, freckling, and optic gliomas. It is a clinical diagnosis.
  • Neurofibromatosis type 2 (NF2) is distinguished by bilateral vestibular schwannomas (VS) and meningiomas. It is inherited in an autosomal dominant manner.
  • Clinical monitoring and medicinal intervention are the mainstays of treatment.

questions.text: A 9-year-old girl presents to the paediatrician's office complaining of abdominal cramps and diarrhoea. She recently lost eight pounds. She has no pre-existing health conditions and is up to date on her vaccinations. Blood pressure is 109/65mmHg, the pulse is 65 beats /min, and BMI is 21 kg/m². Given her history, the paediatrician suggests an endoscopy. A biopsy confirms the diagnosis of celiac disease. A diet restriction of gluten is recommended. Which of the following is not true regarding celiac disease?

choices.text: The most important complication of celiac disease is the development of cancer
Most sensitive test is the anti-tissue transglutaminase antibody
Classic changes in celiac sprue occur in the submucosa

questions.solution:
Option C: Classic changes in celiac sprue occur in the submucosa

  • The classic changes seen on duodenal/jejunal biopsy are restricted to the mucosa and include:
    • An increase in the number of intraepithelial lymphocytes
    • Absence or a reduced height of villi
    • A cuboidal appearance and nuclei that are no longer oriented basally in surface epithelial cells
    • Increased numbers of lymphocytes and plasma cells in the lamina propria

Option A: The most important complication of celiac disease is the development of cancer

  • The most important complication of celiac disease is the development of cancer. The incidences of gastrointestinal and non-gastrointestinal neoplasms and intestinal lymphoma are elevated among patients with celiac disease.

Option B: Most sensitive test is the anti-tissue transglutaminase antibody

  • IgA tissue transglutaminase (IgA TGT) antibody is recommended for diagnosis and has a 95% sensitivity and 95% specificity for detecting celiac disease.

Option D: Associated with dermatitis herpetiformis

  • Celiac disease is associated with dermatitis herpetiformis (DH), characterized by papulovesicular lesions that respond to dapsone.
  • Almost all patients with DH have histologic changes in the small intestine consistent with celiac disease.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents to the emergency department with right upper quadrant pain and jaundice. After a thorough, detailed evaluation, a diagnosis of primary sclerosing cholangitis is made. Which of the following is not associated with this condition?

choices.text: The extra-intestinal involvement of UC is Primary sclerosing cholangitis
Primary sclerosing cholangitis is characterized by both intra and extrahepatic bile duct inflammation
Primary sclerosing cholangitis never causes hepatic failure
Approximately 5% of patients with UC have Primary Sclerosing Cholangitis

questions.solution:
Option C: Primary sclerosing cholangitis never causes hepatic failure

Primary Sclerosing cholangitis:

  • PSC is a chronic cholestatic syndrome characterized by diffuse inflammation and fibrosis involving the entire biliary tree, resulting in chronic cholestasis.
  • This pathologic process ultimately results in the obliteration of both the intra- and extrahepatic biliary tree, leading to biliary cirrhosis, portal hypertension, and liver failure.
  • The usual clinical features of PSC are those found in cholestatic liver disease, with fatigue, pruritus, steatorrhea, deficiencies of fat-soluble vitamins, and the associated consequences.
  • As in PBC, the fatigue is profound and nonspecific. Pruritus can often be debilitating and is related to cholestasis.
  • The severity of pruritus does not correlate with the severity of the disease.
  • Patients with PSC typically are identified during an evaluation of abnormal liver enzymes.
  • The patients have at least a twofold increase in ALP and may also have elevated aminotransferases.
  • Albumin levels may be decreased, and prothrombin times are prolonged in many patients at the time of diagnosis.
  • One autoantibody, the perinuclear antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibody (p-ANCA), is positive in about 65% of patients with PSC.
  • Over 50% of patients with PSC also have ulcerative colitis (UC); accordingly, once a diagnosis of PSC is established, a colonoscopy should be performed to look for evidence of UC.
  • There is no specific proven treatment for PSC.
  • A recently completed study of high-dose (20 mg/kg per day) UDCA was found to be harmful. Some clinicians use UDCA at "PBC dosages" of 13–15 mg/kg daily with anecdotal improvement.
  • Endoscopic dilatation of dominant strictures can be helpful, but the ultimate treatment is liver transplantation.
  • A dreaded complication of PSC is the development of cholangiocarcinoma, which is a relative contraindication to liver transplantation

Option A: The extra-intestinal involvement of UC is Primary sclerosing cholangitis

  • PSC is associated with Inflammatory bowel disease, especially ulcerative colitis.

Option B: Primary sclerosing cholangitis is characterized by both intra and extrahepatic bile duct inflammation

  • Both intra and extrahepatic bile ducts are involved in PSC.

Option D: Approximately 5% of patients with UC have Primary Sclerosing Cholangitis

  • PSC causes fibrosis of both extra and intrahepatic ducts.
  • Seen in about 5% of patients with ulcerative colitis.

questions.text: A 7-year-old female child brought by her mother complains of bone pain and short stature. The mother also gives a history of 3-5 episodes of foul-smelling diarrhoea since 4 months. On Examination patient appears pale, the abdomen is soft, non-tender and non-distended, and bowel sounds are normal. Laboratory investigations show iron, folate, and vitamin D deficiency. The doctor also orders serology for IgA tissue transglutaminase, which comes back positive and a probable diagnosis of celiac disease is made. Which of the following statement is most appropriate regarding Celiac disease?

choices.text: Most common cause of malnutrition in developing countries

questions.solution:
Option A: Increases risk of GI lymphoma

  • Celiac disease is an autoimmune condition caused by an abnormal adaptive immune response to gluten-containing foods.
  • Individuals may experience diarrhoea with malabsorption, fatigue, weight loss bloating and gas abdominal discomfort, nausea and vomiting constipation.
  • Extra-intestinal manifestations include iron deficiency anaemia, Short stature, delayed puberty, osteopenia, skin disorders, and neurological problems.
  • Untreated celiac disease patients, particularly those identified at an older age, have a significantly elevated chance of acquiring enteropathy-associated intestinal T cells lymphoma (EATL).
  • The mechanism behind the high correlation between EATL and celiac disease is unclear. However, antigen-driven T cell proliferation and less direct pro-proliferative effects of chronic inflammation are plausible explanations.

Option B: Gluten diet is advised

  • Complete gluten free diet is advised in these patients
