  • Failure to respond to the dietary changes could lead to complications of celiac disease

Option C: Diagnosed on CT scan.

  • The best method for serological diagnosis is the enzyme-linked immunosorbent test (ELISA), which detects IgA anti-tissue transglutaminase antibodies in the blood (ELISA).
  • The intestinal biopsy obtained during endoscopy is the gold standard for diagnosing celiac disease.
  • A Computerised tomography (CT) scan is not utilised to diagnose celiac disease.

Option D: Most common cause of malnutrition in developing countries

  • Undernutrition is the most common cause of malnutrition in developing countries, not celiac disease.

questions.text: A pap smear from a woman with chronic cervicitis shows cytoplasmic inclusions within epithelial cells. Fluorescent antibodies identify both these inclusions as "elementary bodies." The intracellular organisms causing the infection are unusual because they cannot synthesize which of the following?
questions.solution:
Option A: ATP

  • The above clinical presentation is that of chlamydia infection.
  • The life cycle of chlamydia is in two forms:
    • Elementary body: Extracellular form, metabolically inactive, can not produce their own ATP
    • Reticulate body: Intracellular form, metabolically active, can produce their own ATP

Option B: Cholesterol

  • Chlamydia can produce its own cholesterol. Therefore, this option is incorrect.

Option C: DNA

  • Chlamydia can produce its own DNA. Therefore, this option is incorrect.

Option D: Proteins

  • Chlamydia can produce its own proteins. Therefore, this option is incorrect.

questions.text: A researcher is conducting a study on the morphological spectrum of iron deficiency anaemia on blood smear of anaemic patients. All of the following are true about iron deficiency anaemia, except?

choices.text: Most common cause of anaemia in India

questions.solution:
Option A: Hyper-segmented neutrophils

  • Hypersegmented neutrophils (more than 5 lobes of neutrophils) are seen in vitamin B12 and folate deficiency.
  • Therefore, this is not correct about iron deficiency anaemia.

Option B: Microcytosis precedes hypochromia

  • In peripheral smear, the red cells are small (microcytic) and pale (hypochromic). 
  • Normal red cells with sufficient haemoglobin have a zone of central pallor measuring about one-third of the cell diameter.
  • In established iron deficiency, the zone of pallor is enlarged; haemoglobin may be seen only in a narrow peripheral rim.
  • Therefore, it is characterized by a microcytic hypochromic peripheral smear.

Option C: Mean corpuscular hemoglobin concentration (MCHC)<50%

  • The reference range for MCHC in adults is 33.4-35.5 g/dL.
  • If MCHC is below 33.4 g/dL, it specifies low MCHC.
  • Low MCHC indicates iron deficiency anaemia.

Option D: Most common cause of anaemia in India

  • Iron deficiency anaemia is the most common cause of anaemia in India.

questions.text: A 28 years female comes to the office complaining of shortness of breath, weakness and fatigue. She has no history of smoking or other illicit substance abuse. Her past medical or family history is insignificant. On physical examination, she is anaemic, and her vitals are normal; lab studies reveal Hb 8.0 gm/dL. After a proper evaluation, she is diagnosed with the alpha-thalassemia trait. Which of the following will be found in this patient's electrophoresis study?
questions.solution:
Option B: Normal HbF & normal HbA2

Haemoglobin electrophoresis:

  • Electrophoresis is a screening test for haemoglobinopathies.
  • The separation of haemoglobin molecules in an electric field, principally as a result of variations in total molecular charge, is the foundation of this test.
  • It detects any abnormal type of haemoglobin while measuring the haemoglobin level.

Hb type

Normal

Sickle cell anaemia

α thalassemia

β thalassemia

HbA

95%

Absent

  

Less

HbF

2%

Present

Normal

Increased

HbA2

3%

Present

Normal

Increased

 

  • In the α-thalassemia trait, the haemoglobin electrophoresis will show normal HbF and HbA2 levels.
  • In sickle cell anaemia absence of HbA means the disease severity is very high. But in the sickle cell trait, HBA is present.
  • The screening test for both α & β thalassemia is NESTROFT (Naked Eye Single Tube Red Cell Osmotic Fragility Test).
  • The investigation of choice for both α & β thalassemia is HPLC (High-performance liquid chromatography).

Option A: Increased HbF & normal HbA2

  • In the case of β thalassemia major, HbF markedly raises with a normal or slightly raised HbA2.

Option C: Normal HbF & decreased HbA2

  • In the α-thalassemia trait, the HbF level is normal, but HbA2 will also be normal.

Option D: Decreased HbF & normal HbA2

  • This finding will be found in a normal adult individual.

​​​​​​​​​​​​​​

questions.text: A 30-year-old female presents to the hospital with a complaint of mucosal bleeding on trauma. She has a history of menorrhagia. On investigations, BT and PTT are prolonged. The Ristocetin assay is positive. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option D: von Willebrand disease

  • This patient with mucosal bleeding, menorrhagia, prolonged BT and PTT and positive ristocetin assay likely has von Willebrand disease.
  • It is the most common inherited bleeding disorder due to deficient von Willebrand factor.
  • Ristocetin fails to cause platelet agglutination, which is diagnostic of this disorder.
  • There is an increased bleeding tendency in this disorder.

Option A: Immune thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP)

  • In this disorder, there is immune-mediated destruction of platelets.
  • BT is elevated, but PTT is normal.
  • The ristocetin assay is negative in this disorder.

Option B: Hemophilia A

  • It is an X-linked recessive disorder resulting in factor VIII deficiency.
  • BT is normal, but PTT is elevated.
  • The ristocetin assay is negative.

Option C: Hemophilia B

  • It is an X-linked recessive disorder resulting in the deficiency of factor IX.
  • BT is normal, but PTT is elevated.
  • The ristocetin assay is negative.

questions.text: A 16-year-old male patient is brought to the emergency department immediately after an accident.. The patient is actively bleeding in multiple sites of the body. Primary interventions have not stopped the bleeding, and vitals are deteriorating. The physician has decided to give FFP's, but there is no time for cross-matching. Which of the following group's FFP's can be transfused safely?
questions.solution:
Option D: AB +

  • Fresh frozen plasma contains the labile clotting factors and plasma proteins.
  • After separation and freezing plasma at -30°C  from a donor unit of blood, FFP is collected.
  • FFP should be used within six hours after thawing, ideally within two hours, to prevent deterioration of clotting factors.
  • FFP does not need to be cross-matched but should be ABO compatible.
  • The first preference of FFP is that of the same ABO group as the patient.
  • In an emergency, FFP of a different ABO group is preferable if it has no significant anti-A or anti-B antibodies. 
  • FFP from the AB group no anti-A or anti-B antibodies and is usually preferred if blood grouping is not possible.
  • FFP doesn't need RhD compatibility as it is unlikely to cause RhD sensitization.

Universal Blood donor

O negative

Universal Blood Acceptor

AB positive
Universal FFP donor AB positive

Universal FFP acceptor

O negative

Option A: O –

  • O – blood group has anti-A and anti-B antibodies but no antigens in the plasma.
  • As it has significant anti-A or anti-B antibodies, it can't be used as a universal FFP donor. 

Option B: O +

  • O+ blood has no A or B antigens, and Rh antigen is present.
  • It has anti-A and anti-B antibodies, so it can't be transfused as a universal FFP donor.

Option C: A +

  • A+ blood has both A and Rh antigens. It also has an anti-B antibody.
  • The presence of any antibody in a blood group is a contraindication for being a universal donor.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male is admitted to the emergency ward with shortness of breath. On examination, he has a water-hammer pulse. After diagnosing, the cardiologist asks his junior residents about a special type of murmur called the Austin flint murmur. Which is correct about Austin Flint's murmur?
questions.solution:
Option A: Soft, low, pitched, mid-diastolic murmur

Auscultation findings in Aortic regurgitation:

  • The aortic valve closure sound (A2 ) is usually absent in patients with severe AR.
  • A systolic ejection sound is audible in patients with BAV disease, and occasionally an S4 also may be heard.
  • The murmur of chronic AR is typically a high-pitched, blowing, decrescendo diastolic murmur, heard best in the third intercostal space along the left sternal border.
  • This murmur is brief in patients with mild AR, but as the severity increases, it generally becomes louder and longer, indeed holodiastolic.
  • When the murmur is soft, it can be heard best with the stethoscope's diaphragm, with the patient sitting up, leaning forward, and with the breath held in forced expiration.
  • In patients with AR caused by primary valvular disease, the diastolic murmur is usually louder along the left than the right sternal border.
  • However, when the murmur is louder along the right sternal border, it suggests that the AR is caused by aneurysmal dilation of the aortic root.
  • "Cooing" or musical diastolic murmurs suggest the version of an aortic cusp vibrating in the regurgitant stream.
  • A mid-systolic ejection murmur is frequently audible in isolated AR.
  • It is generally heard best at the heart's base and transmitted along the carotid arteries.
  • This murmur may be quite loud without signifying aortic obstruction.
  • A third murmur sometimes heard in patients with severe AR is the Austin Flint murmur, a soft, low-pitched, rumbling mid-to-late diastolic murmur.
  • It is probably produced by the diastolic displacement of the anterior leaflet of the mitral valve by the AR stream and is not associated with hemodynamically significant mitral obstruction.
  • The auscultatory features of AR are intensified by strenuous and sustained handgrip, which augments systemic vascular resistance.
  • In acute severe AR, the elevation of LV end-diastolic pressure may lead to early closure of the mitral valve, a soft S1, a pulse pressure that is not particularly wide, and a soft, short, early diastolic murmur of AR.

Option B: Soft low pitched, mid-systolic murmur

  • The murmur of Austin-flint is mid to late diastolic, not systolic.

Option C: Harsh high, pitched, mid-diastolic murmur

  • The Austin flint murmur is soft and low-pitched.

Option D: Harsh high, pitched, mid-systolic murmur

  • The murmur of Austin flint is soft, low pitched and mid to late diastolic

questions.text: An 18 year old girl with primary amenorrhea having a karyotype of 45X0 presents with infantile uterus. What should be done next?
questions.solution:
Primary amenorrhea with karyotype of 45 XO with an infantile uterus is suggestive of TURNER SYNDROME

Management

  • Screen for associated abnormalities: cardiac (30% have coarctation of aorta), renal (esp.horseshoe kidney), autoimmune abnormalities (thyroiditis), diabetes, hypertension and hearing loss
  • Growth hormone therapy: accelerate growth velocity and improves final height
  • Gonadal steroids: start with estrogen therapy and add progesterones to induce puberty

questions.text: A 27-year-old nulliparous woman comes to the physician for the evaluation of fertility. She has been unable to conceive for 2 years despite regular intercourse with her husband twice weekly. Menarche occurs at the age of 12 years, and menses occur at regular 28-day intervals and last 4 to 5 days. She is undergoing evaluation for infertility. She is being monitored for ovulation with serial ultrasounds and LH levels. Ovulation in this patient is expected to occur how many hours after an LH surge is demonstrated?
questions.solution:
Option C : 36 hours

  • The patient in the question has regular cycles, thus are expected to be ovulatory
  • From the onset of the LH surge, it takes 34-36 hours, and from the peak, it takes 10-12 hours to ovulate.
  • The midcycle LH surge is responsible for a dramatic increase in the follicle's local concentrations of prostaglandins and proteolytic enzymes. These substances progressively weaken the follicular wall and ultimately allow a perforation to form.

Option A : 12 hours

  • From the onset of the LH surge, it takes 34-36 hours, and from the peak, it takes 10-12 hours to ovulate.

Option B : 24 hours

  • From the onset of the LH surge, it takes 34-36 hours, and from the peak, it takes 10-12 hours to ovulate.

Option D : 48 hours

  • From the onset of the LH surge, it takes 34-36 hours, and from the peak, it takes 10-12 hours to ovulate.

questions.text: A 36-year-old patient who is being treated for infertility gets ovulation induction with clomiphene and Inj. hCG. After 5 days, she comes to OPD with complaints of abdominal distension, pain, nausea, and vomiting. Physical examination is unremarkable. Ultrasonogram reveals subclinical ascites. The next step in management should be?

choices.text: Outpatient management with limited activity, daily weight record and fluid balance
Hospitalise, input output charting and iv fluid administration
Hospitalise, albumin infusion, input/ output charting

questions.solution:
Option A: Outpatient management with limited activity, daily weight record, and fluid balance

  • The patient has a history of infertility treatment with clomiphene and HCG and has symptoms after 5 days of Inj: hCG, which makes her a provisional diagnosis. A case of ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome (OHSS).
  • Ovarian Hyperstimulation syndrome (OHSS) is a medical complication that is completely iatrogenic and unique to stimulatory infertility treatment. Its symptoms are the result of ovarian enlargement and fragility, extravascular fluid accumulation, and intravascular volume depletion.
  • Here outpatient management is appropriate, as she has mild OHSS and no symptoms of severity such as difficulty in breathing or coagulopathy, so the patient should be instructed to limit her activity, weigh herself daily, and monitor her fluid intake (at least 1 L/day of mostly electrolyte-balanced fluid) and urinary output.
  • Mild OHSS is a self-limiting condition.
  • Management of severe cases of ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome is done by admitting the patient for monitoring and following strict protocols to prevent secondary life-threatening complications.

Option B: Hospitalize, input-output charting and iv fluid administration

Indications for hospitalization include a more severe grade of OHSS with:

  • Inability to tolerate oral hydration
  • hemodynamic instability
  • respiratory compromise
  • tense ascites
  • hemoconcentration
  • leukocytosis
  • hyponatremia, hyperkalemia
  • abnormal renal or liver function
  • decreased oxygen saturation

 

Option C: Hospitalize, albumin infusion, input/ output charting

  • Hospitalization is done for more severe forms of OHSS with the abovementioned indications.
  • Albumin infusion is required in a patient with low serum protein values with excess extravascular fluid loss.

Option D: Paracentesis

  • Paracentesis is required in tense ascites causing excessive abdominal distension or causing respiratory distress.

​​​​​​​​​​​​​​

questions.text: Which of the following investigations is least likely to help assess ovulation in a woman with infertility, irregular menstrual cycles, insomnia, and anxiety?
questions.solution:
Option D: Levels of oestradiol

  • Levels of estrogen start increasing in the proliferative phase, peak prior to ovulation, and then declines thereafter.
  • Measurement of estrogen levels is not done, therefore, to assess ovulation.

Option A: USG

  • USG, especially a transvaginal scan, can serially assess the growth of the follicle and its sudden shrinkage, suggesting ovulation.
  • It is done starting from day 9 when a dominant follicle should be seen, and then it is followed up for the increase in its size and subsequently rupture.
  • This follicular monitoring is also indispensable in patients with infertility on ovulation induction.

Test for ovulation

  1. Cervix mucus changes.
  2. Basal body temperature: Increases during ovulation by 0.5º F.
  3. Vaginal cytology: Vaginal smear microscopy for calculating the ratio of parabasal, intermediate and superficial cells.
  4. Serum progesterone: A simple blood test is done at D21 or 7 days before expected menses. A value of ≥ 3 ng suggests an ovulatory cycle.
  5. Endometrial biopsy: Demonstrate secretory changes in the endometrium.
  6. TVS - to see follicular rupture monitoring.
  7. Urinary LH kit.
  8. Diagnostic laparoscopy.

 

Option B: Levels of progesterone

  • Serum progesterone on day 21 of the cycle, a value >= 3ng/mL, is suggestive that ovulation has occurred.

Option C: Temperature changes

  • Progesterone is a thermogenic hormone. Secretion of progesterone following ovulation causes a temperature rise of about 0.5 to 1°F over the baseline temperature. Ovulation is assumed after 3 consecutive days of raised temperatures.

questions.text: A 30-year-old infertile patient presents with chronic lower abdominal pain, congestive dysmenorrhea, and dyspareunia. She has regular cycles and today is the 25th day of her period. On vaginal examination, there is pelvic tenderness and nodularity in the posterior fornix. The most probable diagnosis is?
questions.solution:
Option B: Endometriosis

This option is correct because a patient with endometriosis may present with infertility, chronic pelvic pain, congestive dysmenorrhea and dyspareunia.

Presentation of endometriosis:

  • Infertility
  • Pain: dysmenorrhea (congestive type secondary dysmenorrhea), dyspareunia (in lesions over POD), or chronic pelvic pain
  • Pelvic mass
  • Menstrual abnormalities
  • GI symptoms: pain, nausea, vomiting, bloating, distension
  • Specific symptoms of extra pelvic endometriosis

Examination findings of endometriosis

  • Per speculum: bluish spots in the posterior fornix
  • Per vaginum: pelvic tenderness, nodularity in POD, fixed retroverted uterus, adnexal mass
  • Per rectal: nodularity in POD and uterosacral

Note: An important differential here would be PID which may present similar history and findings. However, a nodular POD is more suggestive of endometriosis.

Also, we must remember that almost 30% of infertile women have endometriosis!

Option A: Ruptured ectopic pregnancy

This option is false because a ruptured ectopic pregnancy presents a history of amenorrhea/ early pregnancy with acute abdomen pain; here, pain is chronic and is associated with dysmenorrhea.

Option C: Cervical carcinoma

This option is false because cervical cancer presents with abnormal vaginal bleeding, vaginal discharge, and cancer cachexia.

Option D: Pelvic congestion syndrome

Chronic pain, congestive dysmenorrhea, and pelvic tenderness may all be seen in pelvic congestion, but the history of infertility and nodularity in POD point more towards endometriosis.

Pelvic congestion syndrome is likely when there is

  • Emotional stress
  • A larger mean ovarian vein diameter
  • Compression of the left renal vein at the origin of the superior mesenteric artery (“nutcracker syndrome”)
  • Diagnosis: Transuterine venography or MRI are the primary methods for diagnosis
  • Treatment is hormonal suppression with Low-estrogen, progestin-dominant continuous OCs, high-dose progestins, and GnRH analogs often provide pain relief.
  • Other methods are ovarian vein embolization or hysterectomy and salpingo-oophorectomy

questions.text: A 40-year-old obese woman with type 2 diabetes and hypertension presented in an outpatient clinic with the complaint of heavy menstrual bleeding. After the biopsy, microscopic examination reveals endometriod type of endometrial carcinoma. The most probable gene defect expected in this condition is:
questions.solution:
Option A: PTEN

  • This patient is diagnosed with an endometrioid type of endometrial cancer. Microscopic examination reveals proliferative endometrium with a variable degree of glandular complexity and cellular polymorphism, which confirms the diagnosis.
  • Endometrioid type of endometrial cancer is associated with PTEN gene mutation and is associated with a better prognosis.
  • It is the most common type of endometrial carcinoma histologically and of all uterine malignancies overall.
  • It is directly related to long-term estrogen exposure.
  • Risk factors include obesity, diabetes mellitus and hypertension.
  • The most common presentation is abnormal uterine bleeding.
  • It has 3 grades, mostly presents early, and shows a good prognosis.
  • Surgery and radiotherapy are the mainstays of the treatment.

Types of endometrial cancer:

Type 1(Endometrioid type) Type 2(Serous, clear type)
  • Associated with PTEN gene mutations
  • Good prognosis
  • Estrogen-dependent, develop in the background of endometrial hyperplasia
  • Develops in obese women
  • Associated with HTN, diabetes
  • Associated with P-53 gene mutations
  • Poor prognosis
  • Not estrogen-dependent, develop in the background of atrophic endometrium
  • Develops in thin women
  • Not associated with HTN, diabetes

Option B: p53 mutations

  • p53 is a tumour suppressor gene whose mutations lead to most cancers.
  • It is associated with non-endometrioid type endometrial cancer and Li-Fraumeni (SBLA) syndrome.

Option C: MSH2

  • MSH2 is a mismatch repair gene which is associated with hereditary non-polyposis colorectal carcinoma.

Option D: BRCA2

  • BRCA2 is a tumour suppressor gene which is associated with breast, ovarian, prostate and pancreatic cancers.

questions.text: 18 year old female presents with an ovarian mass, her serum LDH & placental alkaline phosphate are found to be elevated. What is the treatment of choice in this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: Option B : The given scenario suggests the diagnosis of Dysgerminoma

  • Most common germ cell malignancy
  • Can be bilateral in 10-15 % cases (all other non epithelial ovarian tumors are unilateral)
  • High risk: dysgenetic gonads, testicular feminisation syndrome
  • Tumour markers: LDH, PLAP, (hcg may be raised in some but AFP is normal)
  • In Dysgerminoma, conservative surgery (U/L Salpingo-Oophorectomy) recommended as most patient are Young girls
  • Post operative Chemotherapy gives 90% success
  • Dysgerminoma is also very sensitive to radiotherapy.

Option A : Bilateral oophorectomy is not done here in order to conserve ovarian function and fertility.

Option C :Treatment involves unilateral surgery which is followed up with chemotherapy or radiotherapy;

Option D : Hysterectomy is not done in order to conserve reproductive function in young patients, also a concurrent hysterectomy gives no added advantage.

questions.text: Which of the following ultrasound findings does not indicate PCOD?

choices.text: ≥20 Follicles that are 2-9 mm in size in one or both ovaries
Necklace of pearl pattern of Follicles

questions.solution:
Option B : Cysts arrange around the periphery of ovary giving Necklace of pearl appearance on USG is Characteristic of PCOD. The ovarian volume is usually >=10 cc, although not necessary for diagnosis.

Rotterdam PCOS Diagnostic Criteria for PCOS diagnosis :

The presence of two of the three criteria is sufficient to diagnosis PCOS:

menstrual cycle anomalies (amenorrhea, oligomenorrhea),

clinical and/or biochemical HA, and/or

Ultrasound appearance of polycystic ovaries after all other diagnoses are ruled out.

 

The sonographic criteria for PCOS morphology

Presence of 20 or more follicles (newer criteria mention 20 follicles instead of 12 since with better USGs, even smaller follicles can now be picked up) in either ovary measuring 2 to 9 mm in diameter

and/or increased ovarian volume (>10 mL).

Thickened ovarian stroma

A single ovary meeting these criteria is sufficient to affix the PCO morphology

Option A : PCOS is characterized by small follicles which do not grow in size and hence do not ovulate, these are arranged in the periphery. These are ≥20 Follicles which are ≤9 mm in size in either ovary.

Option C : PCOS is characterized by small follicles which do not grow in size and hence do not ovulate, these are arranged in the periphery appearing as a necklace of pearls.

Option D : Ovarian stroma is thickened in response to increased LH and is responsible for productions of excess androgens in PCOD.

questions.text: A 60-year-old post-menopausal woman presents to the physician with complaints of foul-smelling vaginal discharge. The patient is otherwise vitally stable, and other physical examinations are unremarkable. On examination, there is purulent discharge coming from the cervix. The ultrasound of the patient suggests pus in the endometrial cavity. The symptoms of the will not be seen in which of the following?
questions.solution:
Option C: Carcinoma of the vulva

  • Carcinoma of the vulva is the cancer of the vulva, which is the outer portion of the female genitals. It most commonly affects the labia majora. The clitoris and labia minora are less likely to be affected.
  • Its symptoms include itching, changes in the skin and bleeding from the vulva and not pyometra
  • Pyometra implies the presence of pus in the uterus.
  • Conditions associated with pyometra  
    1. Carcinoma of the cervix (Most common cause in India)
    2. Carcinoma of endometrium
    3. Pelvic radiotherapy
    4. TB
    5. Senile endometritis

Option A: Pelvic radiotherapy

  • Pelvic radiotherapy causes inflammation which results in foul-smelling vaginal discharge and may lead to pyometra

Option B: Carcinoma of the cervix

  • Carcinoma of the cervix is associated with foul-smelling vaginal discharge and pyometra

Option D: Carcinoma of the endometrium

  • Carcinoma of the endometrium is associated with pyometra

questions.text: A 60-year-old post-menopausal woman presents in the gynaecology clinic with complaints of vaginal spotting for 10 days. She has no other comorbidities except a known case of uterine prolapse for the last 2 years. USG reveals an endometrial thickness of 1mm and atrophic ovaries. All of the following are likely causes of her bleeding , EXCEPT?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: Option A: Bleeding disorder

  • Bleeding disorders are least likely to be associated only with post-menopausal bleeding.
  • Since the woman is 60 years old and post-menopausal with complaints of vaginal bleeding for the last 10 days only, bleeding disorder is unlikely in the absence of other symptoms in the past.
  • Bleeding disorders may also manifest as heavy menstrual bleeding (HMB), intermenstrual bleeding (PMB) and post-coital bleeding (PCB).
  • Coagulopathies and bleeding disorders usually start at a young age, and women may notice symptoms at the onset of menarche.
  • Coagulation disorders also present other symptoms, such as bruising and bleeding from other sites.

Option B: Vaginal atrophy

  • Vaginal atrophy is common in menopausal women due to estrogen deficiency and can lead to postmenopausal bleeding. Local estrogen is likely to help, once malignancies are ruled out.

Option C : Decubitous ulcer

 

  • The woman, in this case, has had uterine prolapse for the last 2 years. Therefore, decubitus ulcer appears likely to be the cause of her bleeding.
  • Decubitus ulcers occur on the most dependent part of prolapse and may cause bleeding.
  • It is due to venous congestion, abrasion and localized tissue damage to exposure of the uterus outside the pelvis.

Option D : Cervical cancer

  • Cervical cancer is usually associated with post-coital bleeding but manifests as post-menopausal bleeding.
  • A post-menopausal woman presenting with abnormal uterine bleeding should be investigated thoroughly to rule out possible cervical malignancy, since it is the most common cause of postmenopausal bleeding in our country.
  • Post-coital bleeding is a typical feature of carcinoma of the cervix. In the progression of the disease, patients may also present with several distressing symptoms such as incontinence, pain and anaemia due to vaginal bleeding.

questions.text: A 70-year-old woman presents to the OPD with complaints of itching, discomfort, and vaginal discharge for the last 2 years. She also complains of some degree of dysuria and vaginal spotting. On examination, she has vulvar growth. On a biopsy, the findings are suggestive of squamous cell cancer of the vulva. Which of the following is most  associated finding?
questions.solution:
Option A: Lichen Sclerosis

  • All of the above are associated with Vulvar cancer. The etiologic agents, however, differ according to the age group.
  • Two distinct etiologic entities of squamous cell carcinoma of the vulva exist.
  • Basaloid or warty types account for 40% of vulvar squamous cell carcinomas.
    • These tend to be multifocal, usually common in younger patients.
    • This type is directly related to HPV infection, Usual type VIN (VIN), immunosuppression and cigarette smoking.
  • Keratinizing type accounts for about 60% of cases of squamous cell carcinoma.
    • These tend to be unifocal, found Predominantly in older patients, and are not related to HPV.

 

 

Basaloid or warty types

 

 Keratinizing

 
40% of squamous

 

 60 % of squamous

 
Multifocal

 

 Unifocal

 
Younger patients

 

 Older patients

 
Related to HPV

 

 Not related to HPV, related to lichen sclerosis

 
Usual VIN, immunosuppression, smoking-related

 

 Differentiated VIN, chronic inflammatory dermatosis

 

 

risk factors of vulvar cancer:

  • HPV infection
  • Herpes simplex virus type 2 infection
  • History of smoking
  • Multiple sexual partners
  • Immunosuppression
  • Chronic vulvar disease
  • Previous malignancies of the lower genital tract
  • Age >60 years

 

Option B: Human papillomavirus

  • HPV is associated with the development of vulvar cancer in young and sexually active females and not post-menopausal women.

Option C: Immunosuppression

  • It can be a risk factor in the development of vulvar cancer but has no direct involvement in the development of vulvar cancer in older women.

Option D: Smoking

  • Smoking is an important risk factor for squamous carcinoma worldwide, but it is generally not directly related to the development of vulvar carcinoma in older women.

questions.text: A 25-year-old female undergoing hysteroscopic myomectomy for submucosal fibroid is noted to have a 500ml fluid deficit while using 1.5 % glycine as irrigating fluid for the cavity. What is the next step?

choices.text: Change the fluid to normal saline
Continue the surgery with careful monitoring of fluid status
Give furosemide to the patient and continue surgery

questions.solution:
Option C: Continue the surgery with careful monitoring of fluid status

  • Alert at a deficit of more than
    • 750 ml in non-electrolyte distention media like glycine
    • 1000 ml in electrolyte media like NaCl
  • Should stop if more than
    • 1500 ml deficit for non-electrolyte media
    • 2500 ml deficit for electrolyte media
  • Excess of non-electrolyte media like glycine can cause hyperammonemia.
  • Excess electrolyte media like saline of more than 2500ml can cause:
    • fluid overload
    • pulmonary oedema
    • cardiac failure.
  • In the abovementioned cases, furosemide must be given to remove the excess fluid.

Option A: Stop the surgery

  • Should stop if more than
    • 1500 ml deficit for non-electrolyte media
    • 2500 ml deficit for electrolyte media

Option B: Change the fluid to normal saline

  • Confers no extra benefit

Option D: Give furosemide to the patient and continue surgery

  • Furosemide needs to be given to remove the excess fluid in case of excess of electrolyte media.

questions.text: A 28-year-old female presents to gynecology OPD in an anxious state, reporting early pregnancy loss 1 day back. She reports spontaneous abortion in the 5th week of her pregnancy. She has been married for 5 months. Her HSG reveals two separate cavities of the uterus, cervix and vagina. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option A: Uterus didelphys

  • Uterus didelphys is a complete failure of fusion of Mullerian duct resulting in two uteri, cervix, and vagina.
  • The most common type of uterus anomaly is  septate uterus which causes spontaneous abortion in the first trimester.
  • It can lead to pregnancy complications and dysmenorrhea. Few patients may have surgery to treat uterus didelphys, but most cases don't require it.

 

 

Option B: Bicornuate uterus

  • It is described as a heart-shaped uterus, having two sides instead of one hollow cavity.
  • The cervix and vagina are single

Option C: Subseptate uterus

  • It is a mild form of congenital anomaly in which a half septum is present within the uterus, not infringing on the cervix.

Option D: Unicornuate Uterus

  • A unicornuate uterus is a rare disorder which causes a female to have only half a uterus.

questions.text: A 16-year-old woman presents to the OPD with irregular delayed cycles since her menarche at 13 years of age. She has normally developed secondary sexual characteristics. The onset of menstruation, along with cyclical changes that occur in ovaries and endometrium after puberty, is responsible for making a woman capable of reproduction. Which of the following event is related to oogenesis?

choices.text: Primary oocyte is arrested at prophase – II at birth
LH surge occurs 24-48 hours prior to ovulation
Second polar body is released at ovulation

questions.solution:
Option B: LH surge occurs 24-48 hours prior to ovulation

Oogenesis:

  • Oogenesis is the process of differentiation and maturation of the ovum.
  • Primary oocyte production occurs in fetal life, and these cells change into secondary oocytes.
  • The secondary oocyte is fertilized by a sperm.
  • The hypothalamus secretes GnRH, which acts on the pituitary gland to release LH.
  • The LH surge releases oocytes and induces the resumption of meiosis.
  • It induces the completion of the first meiotic division.
  • LH surge occurs 24-48 hours before ovulation.
  • After ovulation, the egg is released from the ovary and travels to the fallopian tube, where fertilization occurs.

Option A: Primary oocyte is arrested at prophase – II at birth

  • The primary oocyte gets arrested at prophase – I before birth (while the baby is still in-utero).

Option C: Second polar body is released at ovulation

  • The first polar body is released at ovulation and the second at the time of fertilization.

Option D: Meiosis-II is a reduction division

  • Meiosis-II is 'not' a reduction division, as it doesn't reduce the chromosome number in half.

questions.text: A 15-year-old girl presents in the gynecologic OPD with her mother with the complaint of not getting her menses. Her mother says she is worried because all the girls in her school have started getting their periods regularly. On examination, breast development is normal, axillary and pubic hairs are sparse, and the vaginal opening is small and ends in a blind pouch. USG revealed an absent uterus and solid nodular structures in bilateral inguinal regions. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option A: Androgen insensitivity syndrome

  • The ultrasound findings suggest the presence of testes, along with the sparsity of axillary and pubic hair, androgen insensitivity syndrome is the most probable diagnosis in the above case.
  • Androgen insensitivity syndrome is a disorder in which the individual has a male genotype and female phenotype.
  • Testes and testosterone are present, but receptor dysfunction leads to the development of female sexual characteristics.
  • It has 3 categories depending on the degree of genital masculinisation:
    • Complete androgen insensitivity syndrome (CAIS)
    • Mild androgen insensitivity syndrome (MAIS)
    • Partial androgen insensitivity syndrome (PAIS)
  • Management is symptomatic by hormone replacement therapy, genitoplasty, and genetic and psychological counselling.
  • Gonadectomy is indicated to reduce the risk of testicular neoplasm.

 

Option B: MRKH

  • Mayer Rokitansky Kuster Hauser Syndrome (MRKH) is a Mullerian agenesis syndrome. It is XX genotype but does not have Mullerian components such as the uterus and upper vagina. But it has normal ovarian function, and normal ovaries can be visualised on ultrasound.
  •   MRKH Androgen insensitivity syndrome
    Genotype XX XY
    Gonad Ovaries Testes
    Breast development Normal Normal
    Pubic and axillary hair Normal Absent (insensitivity to testosterone)
    Vagina Shallow and blind Shallow and blind
    Uterus Absent Absent
    Vulva Normal Normal

 

Option C: Turner syndrome

  • Turner syndrome is an XO genotype with an abnormal female phenotype, i.e., ovaries, breasts, and uterus are all underdeveloped.

 

Option D: Pure gonadal dysgenesis

  • These patients have a female phenotype, and the genotype can be XX or XY. The individual fails to develop secondary sexual characteristics and presents clinically with primary amenorrhea.

questions.text: A 27-year-old male comes to the physician for the evaluation of fertility. The patient has no offspring. He has been married for 4 years. He has intercourse with his wife twice per week. The doctor advised the patient to have a semen analysis. The patient collects his semen in the vial and gives it to the laboratory. A paramedical staff working at the laboratory uses a chemical to preserve semen samples. The role of this agent is to prevent the formation of ice crystals when semen is frozen at extremely low temperatures. Which agent is most commonly used for the procedure mentioned in this case?
questions.solution:
Option B: Glycerol

     Preservation of semen

  • The most common cryoprotectant used for semen is glycerol (10% in culture medium).
  • Cryoprotectant media may be supplemented with either egg yolk or soy lecithin.
  • Liquid nitrogen is the medium in which these 'Cassettes' containing' sperms and cryoprotectants' are stored.
  • Cryopreservation of sperm, ova and embryos is one big step in the field of infertility.
  • It avoids repeated aspiration.
  • It also permits donating eggs and sperm to couples whose husband is azoospermic or whose wife is incapable of ovulation.

Option A: Dry ice

  • Dry ice is often used to freeze and remove warts or other skin imperfections.

Option C: Liquid nitrogen

  • Liquid nitrogen is the medium in which the cassettes containing sperms and cryoprotectants are stored.

Option D: Liquid oxygen

  • Liquid oxygen is not used in semen preservation

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman who is a non-smoker, non-alcoholic, and has no chronic illnesses is diagnosed with a second-degree uterovaginal prolapse. She had two previous vaginal deliveries 8 and 10 years ago. All of the following historical points could have led to the present condition, except?
questions.solution:
Option D : Episiotomy

  • The main cause of prolapse is abnormal conduct of labour.
  • Pelvic organ prolapse is uncommon in nulliparous women, and the incidence increases with increasing parity.
  • Episiotomy will not cause prolapse. In fact, it is used as a protective measure to prevent uterine prolapse in future.
  • Abnormal conduct of labor
    • Prolonged labour
    • Premature bearing down
    • Faulty instrumentation
    • Large perineal tears, cervical or muscle lacerations
    • Pudendal nerve injury

 

Option A: Precipitate labor

  • A delivery occurring within less than 2 hours of onset of labor pains is known as precipitate labor. It is associated with excessive uterine contractions and excessive perineal stretching, cervical and perineal lacerations, all of which are associated with subsequent development of prolapse.

Option B: Prolonged second stage of labor

  • It is associated with excessive perineal stretching, muscular and soft tissue injuries, all of which are associated with subsequent development of prolapse.

Option D: Premature bearing down

  • It is also associated with undue perineal stretcing and cervical lacerations.

questions.text: Married couple seeks contraception advice in a Gynecologist's office. They meet infrequently due to work and sometimes have unprotected intercourse. They want to learn about emergency contraceptives and other methods. What's not a reason to use emergency contraception?

choices.text: Failure to use contraceptives in unplanned intercourse
As a first choice if not willing to use conventional contraceptives

questions.solution:
Option D: As a first choice if not willing to use conventional contraceptives

  • Emergency contraceptives are never indicated as the first choice of contraception.

Indications for the use of Emergency contraception are:

  • Failure to use contraception: unplanned intercourse, miscalculation of dates, rape.
  • Condom breakage or leakage, incorrect use of the diaphragm.
  • Missed pills (2 or more).
  • Expulsion of IUCD.
  • More than 2 weeks late for Injection: DMPA.

 

Option A: Failure to use contraceptives in unplanned intercourse

  • If the couples have unintentional unprotected intercourse, then emergency contraceptives are indicated.

 

Option B: Miscalculation of safe period

  • Emergency contraceptives are indicated if the female partner has miscalculated her period. 

 

Option C: Failed coitus interrupts

  • Emergency contraceptives are indicated if the couple had a failure of coitus interruptus.

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman seeks advice at the clinic regarding the use of Depo Medroxyprogesterone acetate. Which of the following statements is incorrect?

choices.text: It may be associated with Irregular spotting

questions.solution:
Option A : Depot medroxyprogesterone acetate(DMPA) is given in microcrystalline aqueous suspension and is NOT FOR INTRAVENOUS USE.

Disadvantages:

  • Menstrual irregularities: amenorrhoea, oligomenorrhea, irregular spotting
  • No protection from STD and HIV.
  • Delay in return of fertility
  • Weight gain, bloating
  • Depression
  • Mastalgia
  • Osteopenia.
  • Increases LDL but does not adversely affect the blood pressure.
  • Decreases libido, causes dry vagina

DEPO-medroxyprogesterone acetate is contraindicated in women with:


Known or suspected pregnancy or as a diagnostic test for pregnancy
Undiagnosed vaginal and/or urinary tract bleeding
Known or suspected carcinoma of the breast
Undiagnosed breast pathology
Known or suspected progestin-dependent neoplasia
History of or actual thrombophlebitis or thromboembolic disorders
History of or actual cerebrovascular disorders including cerebral apoplexy
History of or actual myocardial infarction or coronary artery disease
Presence of severe or multiple risk factor(s) for arterial or venous thrombosis:
- Severe hypertension (persistent values of ≥160/100 mm Hg)
- Hereditary or acquired predisposition for venous or arterial thrombosis, such as Factor V
Leiden and Prothrombin G20210 A mutation,etc... the acquired thrombophilias
- Severe dyslipoproteinemia
- Heavy smoking (>15 cigarettes per day) and over age 35
- Diabetes mellitus with vascular involvement
Any ocular lesion arising from ophthalmic vascular disease, such as partial or complete loss of
vision or defect in visual fields
Current or history of migraine with focal aura
Active liver disease or history of or actual benign or malignant liver tumours
DEPO-PROVERA should not be used before menarche.

Option B, C : Use of DMPA is associated with menstrual irregularities: amenorrhoea, oligomenorrhea, irregular spotting.

Option D : Long term use of DMPA may lead to thromboembolism

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman underwent a hysterosalpingogram for evaluation of tubal patency. The x-rays show a tobacco pouch appearance. Which of the following is the most likely route of infection of the fallopian tube in this condition?
questions.solution:
Option C: Through the bloodstream

Tuberculosis of the genital tract

  • Genital tuberculosis occurs most commonly due to a primary focus elsewhere, the commonest site being the lungs but rarely from other sites such as lymph nodes, kidneys, joints, gastrointestinal tract or as part of a generalized miliary infection.
  • The tobacco pouch appearance of tubes is suggestive of tubercular salpingitis. The fallopian tubes appear thicker and have a substance similar to a whip; they may also have surface tubercles with a tobacco-pouch appearance. The external surfaces are roughened by adhesions, and the diameter is increased. They may also reveal the presence of greyish tubercles.
  • The sliced piece of fallopian tubes reveals the presence of pyosalpinx and yellowish-grey caseous debris or serosanguinous fluid.
  • The mode of spread is generally hematogenous or via lymphatics and rarely from direct contiguity with an intraabdominal organ or affected peritoneum or adjacent infected extra-genital organs like intestines.
  • The classic modes of infection in various causes of PID are:
    • Through continuity and contiguity—gonococcal infection.
    • Through blood stream—tubercular

Option A: Through continuity

  • The spread of tubercular infection occurs most commonly due to hematogenous spread. Rarely does it occur from direct contiguity with an intraabdominal organ or infected peritoneum or from the adjacent infected extra-genital organ.

Option B: Adjacent organs

  • Hematogenous spread is the most frequent cause of tuberculosis infection dissemination. Rarely, it can result from proximity to an infected extra-genital organ, infected peritoneum, or intraabdominal organ.

Option D: Through lymphatics

  •  Hematogenous spread is the more frequent cause of tuberculosis infection dissemination than lymphatics.

questions.text: An intern of community medicine was conducting a study where 20 smokers were observed to develop lung cancer. This type of study pattern is known as a Cohort study. All are disadvantages of Cohort study except?

choices.text: Cohort studies involve a large number of people

questions.solution:
Option C: Recall bias

  • Recall bias is a disadvantage of a case-control study 
  • Disadvantages of a case-control study
    • Calculation of Odds ratio (Relative risk – more accurate than OR)
    • Recall bias

Other options

Option A: Cohort studies involve a large number of people

  • This is a disadvantage of a cohort study.
  • The cohort studies involve a large number of people.

Option B:  Cohort studies are expensive

  • This is a disadvantage of a Cohort Study.
  • The cohort studies are time-consuming and expensive.

Option D: Attrition

  • Attrition is a disadvantage of Cohort study.
  • Loss of follow-up and ethical issues are seen in a cohort study.

questions.text: Emergency thoracotomy can be defined as thoracotomy "occurring either immediately at the site of injury, or in the emergency department or operating room as an integral part of the initial resuscitation process". Following emergency thoracotomy, the overall survival rates for penetrating thoracic trauma are around 9-12% but have been reported to be as high as 38%.Emergency thoracotomy is indicated following chest trauma in the following conditions except:-
questions.solution:
The correct answer is: A. Scapular and sternal fractures

Explanation for all the given options:

A. Scapular and sternal fractures: Emergency thoracotomy is not typically indicated for isolated scapular or sternal fractures. These fractures alone do not typically result in life-threatening conditions that would require immediate resuscitation through thoracotomy.

B. Esophageal perforation: Esophageal perforation can lead to mediastinitis, infection, and sepsis, which can be life-threatening. Emergency thoracotomy may be considered in cases of severe esophageal perforation with significant mediastinal contamination.

C. Penetrating injury with cardiac tamponade: Cardiac tamponade is a life-threatening condition where fluid accumulates in the pericardial sac, compressing the heart. Emergency thoracotomy may be necessary to relieve the pressure and treat the tamponade.

D. Massive Hemothorax: Massive hemothorax refers to significant blood accumulation in the pleural space, which can lead to hypovolemic shock and impaired oxygenation. Emergency thoracotomy might be required to control bleeding and address the hemothorax.

In summary, emergency thoracotomy is indicated in cases of severe trauma with life-threatening conditions such as cardiac tamponade, massive hemothorax, and esophageal perforation. Isolated scapular and sternal fractures are not typically indications for emergency thoracotomy.

questions.text: A community medicine intern was asked to compare two study designs. What is the similarity between Cross-sectional study design and Ecological study design?

choices.text: Both studies are done at a point of time
Both are based on primary data
The unit of study is the population

questions.solution:
ANSWER Option A: Both studies are done at a point of time

  • Both cross-sectional and ecological studies are done at a point of time.
  • The cross-sectional study is also called a snap-shot study.

Option B: Both provide prevalence

  • The cross-sectional study provides prevalence.
  • The strength of association/prevalence cannot be calculated in an ecological study.

Option C: Both are based on primary data

  • The cross-sectional study is based on the primary data.
  • An ecological study is based on secondary data.

Option D: The unit of study is the population

  • The unit of study in a cross-sectional study is individual.
  • The unit of study in an ecological study is population.

questions.text: In a population having mid-year population of 1000, there are 150 children less than 15 years and 50 elderly more than 65 years of age. Calculate dependency ratio?
questions.solution:
Option C: 0.25

Dependency ratio:

  • Also known as " societal dependency ratio".
  • The proportion of persons above 65 of age and children below 15 years of age are considered to be dependent on the economically productive age group (15-64 years).

Dependency ratio = (Proportion of ppl in < 15yrs of age + > 65yrs of age) / Proportion of ppl in 15-64 yrs of age

= 150+50/800

= 0.25

Learning Objective

  • Dependency ratio defined as the proportion of persons above 65 of age and children below 15 years of age are considered to be dependent on the economically productive age group (15-64 years).

questions.text: A 25-year-old pregnant female presented to the OPD with concern regarding her diet to be followed in the entire pregnancy. What is the Extra caloric requirement in pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Option B: +350 Kcal/day

Additional caloric requirements during pregnancy and lactation

  • Extra caloric requirement during pregnancy is an additional 350 Kcal/ day.
  • During lactation (0-6 months) is an additional 600 Kcal/day.
  • During lactation period (7-12 months) additional 520 Kcal/day.

Important Points

  • Protein intake during 2nd trimester and 3rd trimester should increase additional 9.5 grams/day and 22 grams/day Respectively.
  • Protein intake during first 6 months of lactational period is an additional 16.9 grams/ day.
  • Calcium intake during pregnancy should be 1000 mg/day, and during lactation period 1200 grams/ day.
  • Iodine intake during pregnancy should be 250 mcq/day, and during lactation period 280 mcq / day.

Learning Objective

  • Caloric requirements during pregnancy is an additional 350 Kcal/day, and during lactation is an additional 600 Kcal/day.

questions.text: The uppermost line of the card depicted above is equivalent to:
questions.solution:
ANSWER

Option C: 50th percentile for boys

  • Weight for Age growth chart is the single best indicator for growth in children.
  • The upper line of the ‘Road to health card’ is equivalent to the 50th percentile for boys.
  • The lower line of the ‘Road to health card’ is equivalent to the 3rd percentile for girls.

Other options

Option A: 80% For boys

  • It is an incorrect choice because the Upper reference curve is at the 50 percentile for boys.

Option B: 50% for girls

  • It is also an incorrect choice because the Upper reference curve at the 50 percentile is for boys.

Option D: 3rd percentile for girls

  • This would be correct for the Lower reference curve in weight for the age chart.

questions.text: A community medicine intern was posted on duty to take care of malnourished children in the village. All of the following are true about Net protein utilization (NPU) except?

choices.text: Defined as Nitrogen retained / Nitrogen consumed × 100
Egg has the highest NPU value
1 gram protein is equivalent to 1 gram Nitrogen

questions.solution:
Option D: 1 gram protein is equivalent to 1 gram Nitrogen

  • 1 gram of Nitrogen is equivalent to: 6.25 grams of protein.
  • NPU of Indian diet: 50-80

Option A: Defined as Nitrogen retained / Nitrogen consumed × 100

  • NPU = Nitrogen retained in the body / total nitrogen intake × 100

Option B: Good for estimating protein quality

  • The NPU gives a more complete expression of protein quality than the amino acid score.
  • Therefore, this is also correct for NPU.

Option C: Egg has the highest NPU value

  • The egg has the highest NPU value of 96 (100).

questions.text: A 32-year-old vegetarian male presented to the OPD with pale skin, fatigue, and numbness. On examination, he was having vitamin deficiency for which only animal sources had to be consumed. Which of the following vitamins is deficient?
questions.solution:
Option C: Vitamin B12

  • A vegetarian male with pallor, fatigue, and numbness suggests the patient is having anemia with peripheral neuropathy, which is most likely due to B12 deficiency.
  • Vitamin B12/Cyanocobalamin is only obtainable through animal sources, therefore strict vegetarians develop B12 deficiency.

Option A: Vitamin B1

  • Since B12 only obtain through animal sources this patient is more likely to have B12 deficiency.
  • Thiamine deficiency can cause peripheral neuropathy but anemia would be uncommon.
  • Given Strict vegetarian, B12 is the more likely answer.

Option B: Vitamin B2

  • Vitamin B2 deficiency can lead to angular stomatitis, cheilosis, glossitis, and seborrheic dermatitis.

Option D: Vitamin C

  • Vitamin C deficiency is also known as "scurvy" present with bleeding gums, petechiae, poor wound healing, and corkscrew hair.

questions.text: Which of the following is false about ORS composition?
questions.solution:
Option D: K+ 65 mmol/L

  • WHO ORS contains 20 mmol/L.

Composition of WHO reduced Osmolarity ORS:

  • Sodium chloride: 2.6 grams/ litre
  • Glucose anhydrous: 13.5 grams/ litre
  • Potassium chloride: 1.5 grams/ litre
  • Trisodium citrate, dihydrate: 2.9 grams/ litre

Other options

Option A: NaCl 2.6 grams

  • WHO reduced Osmolarity ORS contains NaCl 2.6 grams.

Option B: KCl 1.5 grams

  • WHO reduced Osmolarity ORS contains KCl 1.5 grams.

Option C: Na+ 75 mmol/L

  • WHO reduced Osmolarity ORS contains Na 75mmol/L.

questions.text: A 26-year-old male from Bihar visited the petrol pump for refilling the petrol in his car. A condom vending machine at a petrol pump in a high prevalence area is an example of which of the following?
questions.solution:
Option B: Social marketing

  • A condom vending machine at a petrol pump in a high-prevalence area is an example of Social marketing.

Social marketing:

  • Concept: Seeks to develop and integrate marketing concepts with other approaches to influence behaviors that benefit individuals and communities for the greater social good.
  • Social marketing seeks to influence social behaviors not to benefit the marketer, but to benefit the target audience and the general society.

Option A: Appropriate technology

  • Scientifically sound.
  • Suitable for use in the area.
  • Acceptable to users and recipients.
  • Maintainable with available resources.

Option C: Socialization

  • It refers to the process whereby individuals develop qualities essential for functioning effectively in the society in which they live.

Option D: Community participation

  • There must be a continuing effort to secure meaningful involvement of the community in the planning, implementation and
    maintenance of health services, besides maximum reliance on local resources such as manpower, money, and materials.

questions.text: A multipurpose worker is chlorinating the water supplied to the rural village. Select the inappropriate statement about the Chlorination of water.

choices.text: Chlorine best acts at pH 7.2 in water
The minimum recommended concentration of free chlorine is 0.5 mg/L for one hour
Hypochlorous acid plays the main role in disinfection
A chloroscope instrument is used to measure residual chlorine

questions.solution:
Option A: Chlorine best acts at pH 7.2 in water

  • Chlorine best acts as a disinfectant when the pH of water is 7.

Chlorination of Water

  • Chlorine best act as a disinfectant when the pH of water is 7 because of the predominance of Hypochlorous acid.
  • 2.5mg bleaching powder can disinfect 1000 L of water.
  • Chlorine has no effect on spores, cysts, ova, Hep. A, Poliovirus, and cyclopes.
  • A chloroscope instrument is used to measure residual chlorine.
  • Hypochlorous acid plays the main role in disinfection.

Option B: The minimum recommended concentration of free chlorine is 0.5 mg/L for one hour

  • Free chlorine should be present at a minimum concentration of 0.5 mg/L for one hour.

Option C: Hypochlorous acid plays the main role in disinfection

  • The main role in disinfection is played by the hypochlorous acid.

Option D: A chloroscope instrument is used to measure residual chlorine

  • The instrument used to measure the residual chlorine is the chloroscope.

questions.text: McArdle’s Index is an index of thermal comfort. Which of the following is the correct maximum allowable sweat rate?
questions.solution:
Option A: < 4.5 litre/4 hours

  • Max P4SR (Predictable 4 hour sweat rate): <4.5lit/4 hours.

McArdle’s Index:

  • It is an index of thermal comfort.
  • Max P4SR (Predictable 4 hour sweat rate): <4.5lit/4 hours.
  • Beyond this death of person is imminent.

Option B, C, & D: This all are incorrect choices.

Learning Objective

McArdle’s Index

  • It is an index of thermal comfort.
  • Beyond this death of person is imminent.

questions.text: A child received full Rabies vaccination in December 2018 and now presented with an oozing wound on the Great toe and the pet had vaccination also. What is the next line of management?
questions.solution:
Option D: 2 doses of Rabies vaccine

  • 2 IM doses of Rabies vaccine on Day 0,3 for POST-EXPOSURE IN VACCINATED INDIVIDUALS.
  • New Recommended Regimens/ Schedules (NEW GUIDELINES)
Type of prophylaxis Regimen
POST-EXPOSURE INTRAMUSCULAR  
Essen Regimen (1-1-1-1-1) Day 0,3,7,14,28
POST-EXPOSURE INTRADERMAL  
Updated Thai Red Cross Regimen (2-2-2-0-2) Day 0,3,7,28
POST-EXPOSURE IN VACCINATED INDIVIDUALS Day 0,3
PRE-EXPOSURE PROPHYLAXIS Day 0,7,21/28

 

Option A: No vaccine required

  • The vaccine is required in the above-given case. Pet’s vaccination status is not so relevant in Indian guidelines.

Option B: RIG + 5 doses of vaccine

  • 2 IM doses of Rabies vaccine on Day 0, and 3 is recommended for POST-EXPOSURE IN VACCINATED INDIVIDUALS.

Option C: 5 doses of vaccines only

  • A previously immunized individual does not require 5 doses.
  • An unimmunized individual requires 5 doses post-exposure.

questions.text: Janani Shishu Suraksha Karyakram was launched by the government of India on 1st June 2011. All of the following are true about Janani Shishu Suraksha Karyakram (JSSK) except?

choices.text: Free diet to mother during hospital stay
Free transport from home to hospital and back
Free treatment of children up to 18 years age

questions.solution:
Option D: Free treatment of children up to 18 years age

  • Initially meant for up to 30 days of age then expanded to include sick infants.
  • Free treatment of children up to 18 years of age is not the correct statement regarding Janani Shishu Suraksha Karyakram.

Option A: Free diet to mother during hospital stay

  • Free diet for mothers during the hospital stay is one of the pregnant women's components (facility) in Janani Shishu Suraksha Karyakram.

Option B: Free delivery

  • Free delivery in public health institutions is a pregnant women component in Janani Shishu Suraksha Karyakram.

Option C: Free transport from home to hospital and back

Free transport from home to the hospital and back is also a component of Janani Shishu Suraksha Karyakram.

questions.text: A healthcare delivery system is an organization of people, institutions, and resources to deliver healthcare services to meet the health needs of a target population. Three – Tier system of Health care delivery in rural areas in India is based on the recommendations of which of the following committee?
questions.solution:
Option C: Balwant Rai Mehta committee

  • Balwant Rai Mehta Committee: Recommended 3-tier rural Health infrastructure "Panchayat - Panchayat samiti - Zilla Parishad".

Option A: Bhore committee

  • Bhore Committee (1946Q): Also known as ‘Health Survey and Development Committee.
  • Prepare Social Physicians: (3 months of training in preventive and social medicine in medical education).

Option B: Chadha Committee

  • Constituted to study arrangements necessary for the ‘Maintenance Phase of the National Malaria Eradication Programmme (NMEP).
  • 1 Basic Health Worker per 10,000 population (for malaria vigilance, collection of vital statistics, and family planning).
  • Family Planning Health Assistants to supervise 3-4 basic health workers.

Option D: Mudalair committee

  • It is also known as ‘Health Survey and Planning Committee.
  • 1 PHC per 40,000 population maximum.
  • Constitution of ‘All India Health Service’.
  • Strengthen district hospitals with specialist services.
  • Regional organizations in each state.
